main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: The people are great - professional, knowledgeable and passionate. There is huge emphasis placed on our priorities, values and expectations (which you can find on the website) - so if they appeal to you, then that really is what’s considered important.
cons_description: GSK has an amount of paranoia concerning the things they don’t think they’re good at: such as openness, and straight talk. Having worked at other organisations and joining relatively recently, I consider this to be the most transparent culture I’ve experienced!

summary: Worthing site - dying on it's feet
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: Location on the south coast, pay well compared to other employers in the local area, decent people.
cons_description:
Stale SLT

The site at Worthing is dead, they shut Primary, shutting Suspensions, shutting Steriles, shutting Solvent Recovery.........all that is going to be left is Tablets but that'll go as they can be made anywhere. The site had 1000+ a few years ago but small 200-300 redundancies mean the site is being shut slowly.

SLT don't live the GSK values that they spout.

summary: Great Place for your Industrial Placement
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: GSK had excellent lab facilities and you gain a variety of lab-based experience which I found really helped when I returned to University to do my master's research project. Staff were all friendly and willing to help you understand complex chemistry. Having a large intake of industrial placement students was such a benefit - it made the social side of the placement year a lot more fun!
cons_description: This is an extremely lab-based placement, which is as to be expected, but it would have been great to be exposed to a bit more of the  business side of the company. It would have been an added benefit to be included in project direction meetings - I think this could have given the students a better understanding of why they were doing certain things in the lab.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Good pay, good benefits, good career progression (mainly lateral moves) if you are in the right place at the right time and in the right hands. Lots of opportunities to learn if you have the right attitude and time to do heavy networking.
cons_description: Too slow in decision making and distinctively risk-averse. Too many re-organisations which do not help to keep you focused on the job as the risk to be axed is tangible.

summary: A pragmatic company with great values and plenty of common sense
author_title: Former Employee - Safety Evaluation & Risk Management
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description:
Having been with a different employer in the same sector for a number of years, I now feel that I am in a position to write an objective review of my time at GSK. As different teams at the same company can have very different dynamics and styles of management, these experiences may or may not be applicable to other teams at GSK - I write only based on my own experiences.

Pros:

1) Logical processes and organisational structures. I disgaree with some of the other reviews that claim that GSK has layers of unnecessary processes. This is a highly regulated industry and robust processes are an absolute (and legal) must. Compared to every other company I have worked for, I found the processes at GSK were highly logical, full of common sense, devoid of unnecessary complexity and only involved the people that actually needed to be involved. I found the organisational structures to be similarly logical and, unlike some other companies, I could easily the purpose of every role.

2) Innovation and improvement was encouraged. I found my suggestions for improvements were always taken on board and I was encouraged to pursue my ideas. This is in contrast to other major companies I have worked for where a suggestion backed by a careful, logical argument of why it would be beneficial to the business will simply be ignored by management with no rational reason given.

3) High integrity. Although GSK did suffer some unfortunate incidents, I never found any lack of integrity amongst my colleagues and was certainly never put in a position where I had to compromise my values.

4) Genuine empowerment. I never experienced any micromanagement and was trusted to take decisions independently.

Overall, GSK continues to exceed all of the other companies I have worked for in the above areas.
cons_description:
Despite my many positive experiences at GSK, I did decide to leave the company (reluctantly, but I believe it was for the best). This was due to the reasons which I have summarised below:

1) Very limited opportunities to develop in line with one's own ambitions. In my current company, my manager makes a great deal of effort to give me work which I find interesting and which allows me to develop the skills I need to achieve my career ambitions. At GSK, I felt that I was simply allocated whatever tasks 'needed doing' at the time, with very little thought or concern given to whether it was relevant to my aspirations at the company. I also found that management were very reluctant to let people explore opportunities elsewhere, be it in other teams in the same department or elsewhere in GSK. I found there to be an overriding emphasis on team retention to the point where managers appeared visibly uncomfortable if the subject of pursuing an opportunity in another team was raised. 

2) Some managers were reluctant communicators. Rather than managers taking the time to develop an open, honest and trusting relationship with their team members, I found that they frequently preferred to make assumptions about people and were often very reluctant to discuss changes or issues happening in the department. Decisions might be taken about your development 'in secret' without giving you the opportunity to voice your opinion. This is in contrast to my current manager who I enjoy a very open and trusting relationship with.

3) Very different expectations of team members. I found that the team relied heavily on a particular subset of individuals to complete the bulk of the work, especially when it came to non-routine and more complex tasks. Management appeared to have very different expectations of different team members, even those at the same grade. Some individuals would be given a limited workload of routine tasks and allowed to work at a slow pace, while others would be given crushing workloads and expected to deliver quickly. It appeared that excuses such as 'I don't have the right skills for this' would result in the task simply being reallocated to someone else, often a person who already had a high workload. Some individuals expect to be 'spoon fed' everything and do not make the effort to proactively learn new skills.

4) Office environment and locations. The office I worked in did not feel like those of the prestiguous international company that GSK is. It was very dated with stained carpets, dingy lighting and a generally downbeat atmosphere. Additionally, the Brentford, Weybridge and Uxbridge offices in particular are situated in areas with a very high cost of living and there was not a consistent policy on working from home. This is biased against individuals from a poorer background who cannot afford the affluent lifestyles in these areas which some of the older or more middle-class employees can.

I really value that I am trusted to deliver my role and that I able to flex my work pattern around my family - the focus on delivery rather than hours present sitting in the office is refreshing and motivating!

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for less than a year
pros_description: Great salary and work-life balance
cons_description:
Horrible dilapidated office in Stevenage, in winter office was like a freezer yet we were not allowed heaters, takes weeks/months to fix broken taps and toilets

Ridiculously corporate culture full of buzzwords, management speak and brown-nosing. Everyone would circlejerk every time CEO/head of R&D made a speech, going on about 'culture', 'innovation' and 'our great leader of our glorious company'. Like working in North Korea/Black Mirror.

Really dull, boring work, full of acronyms and pointless meetings, very slow and regulated, so many procedures/processes/documents for everything, spent more time on documents & meetings than doing my work

Dead atmosphere, rude colleagues who never spoke, no lunches or coffee breaks. Everyone sat for 9 hours a day staring at their screen. Colleagues seemed overworked while I had nothing to do.

Horrible overpriced Sodexo canteen with meagre portions and staff obsessed with social media. Food ran out at 12:15pm.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Working for a great cause, to help people Do More, Feel Better, Live Longer. Diverse, collaborative and supportive global organisation.
cons_description: When I first started working at GSK (a long time ago), it had a very liberal and collegiate culture, almost not like a profit making business. Over the years, the commercial focus has become much sharper, and with it greater challenges in the day to day operations.  But overall, this is to be expected, and it's still a great firm to work for.

GSK is widely known as science led innovative company and they are shifting their organisational focus in that direction by improving organisation capability and flexibility under operational excellence program, in which I worked there.
cons_description: Not really, by it is highly bureaucratic and sometimes many legacy systems come in front to barricade implementing changes as required.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Easy place to have a long career, jobs are 'comfortable'. Pay isn't bad, and there are lots of perks available such as healthcare, share schemes, tax free schemes, pension.
cons_description: Very little internal mobility or opportunities for development for people at the entry/graduate level leading to high turnover of staff, in part due to the very low turnover of career staff at the lower management level and above as there is a lack of opportunity for advancement until someone retires. Easy to get stuck in a rut. Pay could be better. Very reactionary management.

summary: Great organisation with few toxic managers in GSK Tech
author_title: Former Employee - Operations Manager - GSK Tech
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: GSK is one of the best organisation to work for.  Specially for Tech people, there is lot going on in GSK . GSK is at forefront of using latest technology to fulfil it mission of do more, feel better , live longer.  I was fortunate to work here for close to 5 years and highly recommend anyone thinking of pursuing career in GSK. Also it is one of the good payer and you can expect a good work life balance along with many learning opportunities.
cons_description: You may be working for great organisation but if your boss is control freak, do not allow you to make decisions , interfere in day to day work and do not support you when required, it makes no sense to work even in GSK. My life was made hell by my boss who considered himself absolute authority and wasted money like anything on his favourite contractors even though GSK management was trying to cut operational costs.   In today's world employee is not just looking for a job and salary but meaning in his job, learning opportunities and power to make decisions which unfortunately is not understood by manager in one part of GSK Tech.

summary: You can't get a more compelling purpose
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description:
- Do more, feel better, live longer - the company mission is compelling

- Improving our inclusive environment

- Career Opportunities
cons_description:
- Leaders are more performance than people led [hope this changes with review of leaders]
- Benefits are static and not flexible for stage of career, needs etc
- Flexibility is less than you would hope for in such a big organisation

summary: Favouring external recruitment over internal progression
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Good company and trying to change quickly
cons_description: Long term staff are now seen as a mill stone and no longer valued with most new opportunities (especially around Digital) are going to external recruits, who seem to get bigger pay and higher grades. Opportunity and career progression is now very limited to long term staff and most now moved to dead end jobs or made redundant despite consistent high performance. Culture moving towards “self promotion” and “me, me, me” rather than collaborating teams, leading to less loyalty and more transactional relationship from staff.

summary: A company with strong values and history of putting the patient first but slowly unraveling under direction of new CEO
author_title: Current Employee - Learning and Development Manager
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline part-time for more than 10 years
pros_description:
A truly global company, you can work across countries and cultures, while being united on a common purpose. Quite inspirational at times.
Also, lots of internal opportunities so a good company to join if you want to try different careers.
cons_description:
Be prepared for reorganisations every other year at a minimum. Really hard to stay focused and positive when you keep seeing the same things being done and then undone.
It’s a big corporation so it often feels like the right hand doesn’t know what the left hand is doing.
Although the values haven’t changed on paper, there has definitely been a shift in reality. If you want to work for a company that’s innovative and cool, then maybe you’ll like the new direction. If your purpose is to make the world a better place, then I suggest you look somewhere else.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description:
Share schemes are great
Some talented people, though they are dwindling in numbers.
There are some great managers, but....
cons_description:
Some appalling, inexperienced and incompetent managers in roles where they are well out of their depth...non transparent recruitment methods in the disguise of ‘talent management’. Though no one has any idea who is in the talent management pools and what the criteria are. Favouritism and nepotism are rife.
Constant restructures and reorganisation.. change in direct with new CEO.  Job insecurity.
Fewer people to do the same work, but that’s okay because processes will be simplified...not seeing a vast lot of evidence to support that!

author_title: Former Employee - Learning and Development Advisor
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description:
The teams are fantastic people, great benefits and overall nice place to work. 
Transparency, respect, integrity and patient focus are truly at the front of everything they stand for.
cons_description: Management have a lot to learn when redundancy looms. Mental health issues do not exist to management and loyalty counts for nothing. Too much “not what you know, it’s who you know” still abundant for a global company.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Inclusive, Diverse, Employee Focused and Genuine Patient Driven Focus.  Colleagues are supportive, driven and the company offers opportunities to develop in career to those who aspire for it and demonstrate impact.  Fair salary given balance of work/life.   Fantastic culture and values and company tries hard to stay true to them and re-assess them as needed.
cons_description: Given how large company is, at times people who shout loudest can be recognised in spite of minimal work/impact they have.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for less than a year

summary: Worked at Wellcome/GlaxoWellcome/GSK for 25 years and loved it

slow to take decisions as so many stakeholders to involve.

Very little career progression for scientists

Managment don’t know their team well  enough, more focused on managing up rather than leading the team, lack of vision and leadership
Promotion is based on who you know, merit based selection no longer exists
Salary is low compare to other companies
Too many restructure means you end up having career regression as oppose to progression

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years

Management talk about transparency, however are less transparent than before
Management don’t like your face then you want you out at drop of a hat and are citing the new perform system to do so. Yet if management miss sales targets by a large amount they seem to all survive
Drive for more diversity gone to far and leading to perception of positive discrimination

summary: The best culture I have worked in
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for less than a year
pros_description: The best company I have ever worked in, for it's culture - which in my opinion is the most important factor when choosing where to work. People work together and collaborate to get things right together.
cons_description: GSK is a large business, and very complicated. Therefore things can be slow to move, sometimes - but not always.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than a year
pros_description: Amazing building; great facilities including a 'high street' that provides everything; easy access for commuting; ability for flexible working to manage home life issues. A lot of communication channels.
cons_description: Awful middle management style! Not sure if it's a legacy of trickle down of 1980s blame culture from senior management but it is certainly not based in the 21st century. Not solution focussed, more keen on escalating every little problem upwards.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years

cons_description: Can be a stressful role in certain modalities, poorly paid in the UK for such a highly prized position.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years

A genuine belief that we are doing work that changes the world for the better. Even if that world is only one person. 
Strong company values and identity. 
Some of the best people I have worked with.
cons_description: We work hard, and sometimes that is exhausting

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for less than a year

cons_description: No ambition to grow. Only to divest or hold. Bureaucracy extreme. So risk averse it's stifling. No entrprenurial spirit.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description:
Work life balance 
Generally a friendly environment 
Working from home is possible in many areas of the business
GSK House is a superb office space
Excellent cycle to work support and facilities
cons_description:
Bonuses incentives can drive staff seeking to raise profiles rather than getting things done. This can result in unnecessary projects with overstated benefits being delivered.
There is large layer of senior management bloat  particularly in the support functions. 
The company promotes transparency but decisions on who to invest in (talent management), performance ratings and certain internal appointments are done in cloistered corners. 
Many meetings end with no decisions and no actions. 
Share price is flatlining
IT infrastructure sand internal systems creak at the seams

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for less than a year

cons_description: Brentford is a hell hole. The offices are dated and drab.  IT was something from the past think Office 2007 in 2017. Lots of 'grads' swanning around pretending to be grown ups.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years

High pressure

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Reasonable pay cheque every month
cons_description:
Never seen so many idiots in one place especially in management; look at the board - absolutely so scientific talents and full of penpushers and talkers who had never had a proper job in their lives
The words 'trust' and 'integrity' only live as words never in the culture - what happened in China and the US is only a tiny tip of a huge iceberg

summary: Proud to be an employee of GSK

summary: Great for career development and opportunities

Very inflated structure, too many layers, and relationships play a too big of a role sometimes.
Compensation is not the most competitive in the market.

summary: Lots of opportunities to develop your career

pros_description: Diverse range of roles and career opportunities.  Multinational environment with opportunity to move roles and divisions.  Great opportunities to make a real difference.
cons_description: The size and complexity of the organisation can make things difficult to do.

 Career Development

complexity 
decision making

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good opportunities, flexible working options, variety of work, great mission and people
cons_description: Lots of complex processes and often lengthy decision making with lots of people involved

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 3 years
pros_description: Culture of empowerment, Fantastic people, Values - leading the pharma industry's ethical transformation, Development opportunities
cons_description: Some members of senior management are disconnected from the reality on the ground; Bureaucracy, complicated processes, and hierarchy in some teams slows us down; Organisational memory lost because of capable people moving on very quickly

summary: Amazing people and culture, depends on department
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Great colleagues, work-life balance, responsibilities early on, independence
cons_description: Talent pipeline & review varies from department to department - can seem quite unstructured and feel lost in terms of finding a different job inside the company

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: Great people/colleague. Good awards (if you can get them) and good share rewards. GSK has a global presence and it is doing a lot of good work in Africa and developing nations. Very good work life balance. Huge focus on diversity.
cons_description: Poor leadership. R&D is poorly funded so opportunities for development are limited. Far too many restructuring, which are really disruptive to work. Need to hire more young people.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Fun environment, good people, strong values and emphasis on development
cons_description: Medium pay means you're always on back foot and location isn't great for those who want to be in London

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: People are empowered to make decisions, given a lot of freedom to manage your own business within a clear framework and has some fantastic brands.
cons_description: Typical large organisation in that there is a lot of stakeholder management required. Can take a long time for initiatives to see the light of day.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Multinational company with the potential of secondment to other departments abroad. Salary not too bad. Great colleagues. Strong drive overall.
cons_description: Continuous review and endless documentations.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description:
Great people (very friendly and helpful).
Exciting projects.
cons_description:
Things can be a bit complex at times. 
The company is very large which impedes efficient communication between platforms / teams.
Employee rating system is not very fair.
Can be a bit overwhelming to new people.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good atmosphere, nice building, open and honest environment
cons_description: limited career mobility.  Parking can be an issue

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: good pay, nice working environment and facilities.
cons_description: Rigid, lots of temporary workers, minimal career developement

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline

summary: Good work life balance but reducing career options
author_title: Current Employee - Head of Commercial Excellence
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description:
Good work life balance
Good people and honest transparent/trust culture 
Truly patient focussed and ethical culture despite past flaws 
Good Global opportunities
cons_description:
Slightly lower than average competitor pay
Reducing career options to to downsizing and top heavy organisation
A lot of under skilled individuals masked by years of excellent products performing well anyway

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Managers listen. Excellent coworkers. Provide training opportunities. In the Yorkshire dales.
cons_description: Poor pay for senior roles.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description:
Excellent working environment in the head office in Brentford that respects all cultures and religions.
Wealth of knowledge and training resources that can help you develop your career.
Very friendly environment.
cons_description:
You need to control your destiny. In other words, you need to make sure you invest in your own development. Do not rely on your managers to develop yourself. Not really a con though in my opinion.
Depending on which part of the organisation, you may find things progress quite slow. This is normal though in the Pharmaceutical industry due to the heavy regulations around it (you need to get used to this if you are in this industry).

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: GSK House at Brentford is a very smart large building with great food at all the outlets.   On the bottom floor there is a shopping centre with a two canteens, a coffee shop, a hair dresser shop, a bike shop and a Londis store.
cons_description: It is noisy on th ground floor as it is very busy.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good Working facilities and canteen.
cons_description: Some managers do not manage because they lack both technical and people skills. This leads to staff being untrained frustrated working longer hours and any good personnel leave.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for less than a year
pros_description:
Innovator company, 
Core Pharma company
No work pressure
cons_description: No MNC standards, As this is a new set up.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description:
industry leader, trying to change the face of big Pharma.
Typical Big Pharma Benefits
Excellent Graduate and apprenticeship schemes 
reasonably flexible working arrangements in any depts
cons_description:
Highly regulated business to be in.  Many procedures to follow.  
Top heavy organisation structure and too many meetings.
Constant state of change can result in low job satisfaction

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description:
Great Environment
Great Colleagues
Good Benefits
Reasonable work life balance
cons_description:
Confused Organisational structure - ways of working, roles and responsibilities and actually getting things done requires extensive stakeholder management and lining up of vested interests
Inability to commit to embedding strategic change - strategies are written and signed off, work begins but it's never really committed to and embedded in what is really a very risk averse organisation. This results in improvements being slow and incremental and hard to implement.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: There are no pros to working for this company.
cons_description: poor management. not what you know. awful culture. progression on who you are friends with out of work

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Large business with lots of opportunities to be had, hard work is recognized work life balance is pretty good. Management are generally understanding
cons_description: Company has a lot of competing priorities and the company seems to go through major reorganizations every couple of years, it can difficult to keep up

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
- Great company culture 
- Lots of opportunities 
- Encouragement from management 
- Lots of other activities to get involved with e.g. Charity meetings, volunteering for research
cons_description: - Didn't outline until the end of the year what criteria we were being assessed against for graduate scheme

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description:
Good long term incentives
Lots of opportunity for development and growth

cons_description:
Resource constrained
Complex processes and systems

summary: Place to learn not to grow
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Plenty to learn from process and technical prospective. There is a degree of flexibility if you wants to move around within the organisation.
Great work life balance.!
cons_description: Highly specialised departments, and as ka said not to grow which means no career ledder unless you are the chosen one or in grad scheme.!

summary: Good Corporate benefits, big gaps at site level
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good corporate benefits, excellent central training courses with management support to attend.
cons_description:
Not agile and very archaic documentation systems. 
Poor understanding of effective objective setting and performance management by local managers. 
Trying to implement a Lean culture and the links to the quality framework have not been effectively joined up.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Salary is higher than average for job level, company is a good steping stone due its big name.
cons_description: Long hours are uncommon, very pressure driven

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Some line managers really, really good
Flexible location working - closest site, HQ, WFH
cons_description:
Senior leaders more worried about their position than delivering best for business/patients.
Flip flop between latest management 'fad' as if it's the best thing on earth.  All work has to be a 'force fit' to the latest model/style...until it is forgotten or a new model comes along.  More concerned with following process than understanding requirements.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years

summary: Migrations Project Manager and Change Manager

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Good solid FTSE100 company with a values based culture. Corp HQ with a good range of facilities from gym to restaurant
cons_description: Pharma heritage can lead to slow decision making. It is a company where employees stay for their careers

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Large company with opportunity to move globally
cons_description: Lacks vision despite it being a blue chip company, people have been there too long so workplace can feel quite stagnant

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Good name to have on your CV
cons_description: Benchmark your back office processes with a comparable peer group; IT systems are a decade out of date; an unstructured mish-mash of an organisation means that whilst one group frantically works to get an activity done, the group down the corridor is working twelve hour days to unpick and reverse the same activity (e.g. Communications and co-joined thinking is in scant supply).

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Supportive culture & people friendly, strive for excellence, mission & values, investment in people,
cons_description: Speed of decision making, too many layers of management, risk taking not encouraged or rewarded

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Improving the quality of peoples lives by producing world class pharmaceuticals allowing them to do more, feel better and live longer
cons_description: Some of the tasks can be laborious and repetitive while others can be very stressful. In my opinion there is very little training with limited progression opportunities. Operators become pigeon holed into doing one task all the time unless your face fits. Blue eyed boy syndrome is prevalent throughout the factory.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Very inclusive environment, great people working there. Plenty of opportunities to develop other skills through training, seminars, etc. On-site sports centre, decent breakfast and lunch available in the cantine. Shuttle bus betwen Stevenage train station at GSK makes commute a bit less painful.
cons_description: Sometimes I struggle to tell who I actually report to, as my manager is in another department and works on the project from completely different angle. Also, fixing certain things takes a lot of time.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline part-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: Opportunities for new roles and development. Good salary and bonus. Feeling that it really is a different type of company from other pharmaceuticals - values really at the core.
cons_description: Less open to flexible working when you get more senior. 'Boys club' in senior positions - lots of white middle classed middle aged men.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: Excellent company to work for. Lovely environment and facilities.
cons_description: As with all huge companies it comes with a certain level of red tape, and especially the pharma aspect, it can be like wading through mud to get things done.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Safe environment to work in.
cons_description: Too many rules that are pointless.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Well known company. Bonus, shares, holidays.
cons_description: Cult like culture. No breakthrough science.

cons_description: Nothing that I can think of

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: Benefits, open plan office, promotion prospects, regular briefings, highly competitive, inclusive and diverse, organised, global organisation, culture, great place to work
cons_description: At junior-middle management more senior people can seem a bit hierarchal as in with any commercial company. However there are many opportunities to get promoted and be more visible

summary: Endless changes and not for the better

summary: The only really values based Pharma company

cons_description: Hard to fault GSK. I enjoyed my 16 tenure at the company.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline part-time

cons_description: Bureaucratic, Slow pace

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Brand reputation but living off past history
Good facilities, although often locational challenges
Many over paid for what they do
cons_description:
Outdated systems, processes, management
Lack of fresh blood, people have been there for many years and it shows, no perception of the real world
Too many old fat cats, jobs for the boys type scenario its who you know not what you know
Can be very sexist old guard over promoting women at expense of hard workers
Chaos over structure

author_title: Current Employee - Junior IT Business Analyst
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Staff are mainly friendly, often found someone who I could ask if I ever had a problem or needed to speak to someone about a specific task, flexible hours and holidays
cons_description: Very much a hierarchy in the business. Its very hard to approach some members of staff due to what I can only describe as a napoleon complex. You find a lot of the staff are not like this, but the ones that are... are the managers

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great company to work in, cutting edge technology, friendly environment, great personal development plans, etc
cons_description: No cons at all in this company

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 10 years
pros_description: Patient focused; research centric; finding good drugs to make people feel better and live longer. Seems to have ridden recent storms around compliance, key drugs going off patent, and sharp practices reasonably well
cons_description: Downward pressure on costs in support services such as IT is relentless. Now seems to be all about money and quality, customer service etc takes second place. That said, maybe it's the right strategy. Time will tell

summary: Good intentions but very slow to change
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Worked here for 3 years. Everyone has good intentions and wants to do the best and a big focus on the patients.  Benefits are good and great flexible working
cons_description: Poor systems and over complicated processes. Change takes forever and often lacks transparency.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than a year
pros_description: Great work life balance and supportive management. Salary packages are comparable or better to industry standards and stock options are available for relevant positions.
cons_description: No currents cons that can be mentioned.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good benefits, reasonable pay, flexibility
cons_description: redundancy after redundancy, lost the best talent

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good benefits, reasonable pay, flexibility
cons_description: redundancy after redundancy, lost the best talent

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Great place to work! They focus on doing good science and care for their employees.
cons_description: Salaries in GSK UK are not proportionally similar to that in GSK US. They need to pay their employees more here in the UK.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 8 years
pros_description: great people, flex working hours,
cons_description: difficult path to promote

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description:
GSK really cares about their employees. They have great employee benefits, including an excellent health and wellbeing programme. Work life balance is good, but of course depends on your manager and department, as well as timings of the year. 

GSK house in Brentford is a nice workplace. Everything you need is available in one building including a hair dresser, mini supermarket, restaurants and gym.
cons_description: Despite being such a large company with many great benefits GSK does not provide their employees with any free refreshments/food at work - not even a piece of fruit. Instant coffee is all there is. They have just introduced a new company policy which does not allow employees to buy lunch on behalf of the company for attendees when you are in a lunchtime working meeting. In addition there are now much stricter rules for expenses when travelling, so even if you have to spend time on a day off for business travel, the company does not pay for any food during the travels.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good Work life balance if you want to, lesser number of seniors so career progression is faster, free lunch, lesser number of work hours. number of vacations are more, good number of Sick and Casual leaves. good maternity leave benefits.
cons_description: more workload on junior/senior programmers. take home pay is lesser compared to CTC/12 months. you get LTA/Bonus etc only once in April.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Great name to have on your CV, and worth while severance package
cons_description: radically changing working environment, Pressure for delivery, Poor leadership strategically and day to day

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description:
Great for building a career in the long term.
The company is embracing change in a huge way transforming the business model.
cons_description:
Complex company with many interlinks and stakeholders in each position.
Can be more results oriented

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Excellent company, great training, loads of opportunities
cons_description: The size of the organisation - Just too big !!

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description:

-  state of the art facilities
cons_description:
- repetative procedures
- slow promotion processes
- isolated laboratory environement with little interaction with additional departments

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Amazing team, made friends for life
Helpful managers (though I have heard this has changed)
Good modern facilities with good staff perks
Busy administration experience

takes a bit of getting used to
minimal salary increase.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Great corporate culture and good values
cons_description: Bureaucracy can tend to be overwhelming

summary: very good company to work for
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline part-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: very good benefits, salary, working conditions, business cluster, management
cons_description: basically no cons, fantastic company to work for

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Good benefit, flexible working hours (however depending on your line manager). A good place to learn some of the best processes in the industry. Some experts in the company are just superb!!
cons_description: Very flat structure and very difficult to get promotion or even move side ways despite of what the company promotes. Salary is not great in the industry but made up by the benefit (e.g. shares which you will lose some when you leave and gym membership). It's a very big organisation and you are bound to see some very good experts in the field but also some managers not good at their jobs at all and you wonder how they get there. Company this size is difficult to manage to ensure everyone behaves professionally, so manage your expectations before you go in. Some managers are very reluctant to make decisions and very frustrating. Due to the good benefit there will be some people who stay there too long and become lazy meaning work is pushed to new/young people

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Excellent package, good people, opportunities if you work at it
cons_description: Challenging times and downsizing functions

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Fantastic culture
Interesting projects
Great graduate scheme benefits
Vast opportunities to expand into further business areas
cons_description: Work load can get a little slow at times, although this could be depending on the area you choose to work in.

summary: Expected more from such a big organisation
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Very good work-life balance, good benefits, nice environment
cons_description: Not very good evaluation of employees resulting in poor selections when promoting

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Great Company to work for
Very promising new product pipeline - future looks positive
Complicated business model - lots to learn and many opportunities
cons_description:
Objectives are not always clear and aligned - similar to a lot of large companies
Focus of functional leadership tends to be short term on the tactical completion of short term objectives
Not enough focus and value placed on the development of staff by senior management

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for less than a year
pros_description: Friendly employees, really comfortable working environment
cons_description: maximum of a 1.5 year contract

summary: Excellent Career Progression and Training Opportunities fantastic
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Support and Sponsorship to develop your career, great company to move around in and various programs are available to develop and be supported to continuously improve.
cons_description: Some of the senior IT Team Leadership had been promoted beyond their ability. It's easy to become marginalized if you do not have a good mentor / sponsor.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Good salary bonus shares options
cons_description: always restructuring ...... no effective systems

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for less than a year
pros_description: Large internal market, offering plenty of opportunities. Very good community feeling. Many projects and TAs to work with. Thriving discovery.
cons_description: Not appropriate for those in need of precise directions. This system needs proactive yet aligned contributors to maintain its dynamics and offer its rewards.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Good salary, challenging work, well resourced environment, good teamwork
cons_description: over competitive workplace, , too much focus on performance related pay

summary: Great culture but facing an uncertain future
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Friendly coworkers and a good sense of team spirit. Helpful and supportive supervisor. Some flexibility in working hours. Overall, a good working environment.
cons_description: Definite feeling of  'them & us' between contract & permanent staff despite all attempts at being inclusive. Same goes when applying for perm jobs ie decisions are made on politics and whether your face fits.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Well structured. Nice environment to work
cons_description: Too many Americanisms for my liking

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than a year
pros_description: Good working relationship with all stakeholders.
cons_description: Do not pay market rates.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 5 years
pros_description: Very Good benefits, flexible working, broad scope for opportunities to develop in different areas, reasonable security, ok ok ok ok ok
cons_description: Work life balance, under resourced, continued cost cutting, low morale, disengaged management and lower levels, aging unenthusiastic workforce ok ok

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 10 years
pros_description: Flexibility for working mums, fancy labs, friendly people to work with, generally a nice environment to be in and a great place to work.
cons_description: Pay is always below average for R&D, lots of restructuring generally every two years so lots of disruption. Manager changes too often

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good facilities, plenty of career scope
cons_description: Impersonal and huge - you're just a number.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 8 years
pros_description: Opportunities exist and you can make a real contribution to wider world healthcare community
cons_description: Leaders are often limited intellectually - CBS leaders especially when looking at the wider organisation.  Many SVPs and VPs take credit for their teams' work and achievements.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Flexible working hours, faciities including a gym and shop.
cons_description: People can be cold.Some are frustrated yet carrying on. Long decision making process.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than a year
pros_description: If a permanent GSK employee, amazing company to work for. Salary and perks amazing, as is occupational health support etc. Training provision  is excellent as is training courses such as NEBOSH etc for personal development.
cons_description: Agency staff treated appallingly, if you want to progess within GSK it seems to help if you have that ability to belittle and bully the employees. Rife throughout with certain members of the SLT and even above site level staff responsible for Primary operations. Certain people promise you the world on commencement of employment and then sit and revel when a role you have to perform after little or no training fails to generate the desired outcome. Worse is the fact that these people know  how to arrive at the desired result, but make themselves appear to be too busy to offer guidance and support. Leaving you with the feeling failure and incompetence! Plenty of coasters onsite who are simply waiting on the proverbial golden egg hatching as they hit the magical retirement age. These people stifle the change process and merely place unnecessary obstacles in your path, coupled with weak line management who continue to endorse this continual type of behaviour. Once you annoy one SLT member the chances of ever getting back on to the site are remote, similar for any other site due to the malicious falsehoods that are communicated to other hiring managers.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Kudos, good on CV, Technical
cons_description: do NOT stay and try to make a career. only good if networked, buddy system going strong.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: The company takes  care of its employees. There are lots of in work benefits such as share options and subsidised canteens. As far as I can tell they pay fairly.
cons_description: It is a massive company so there is a fair amount of bureaucracy. This is expected in such a large company and is not as bad as it could be.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description:
1) Some really great people to work with in all parts of the company - some of the R&D and technical folk are truly inspiring to work with.
2) Genuinely focused on putting the patient first
3) Work can be very challenging and rewarding especially when working on medicines that you can see make a difference to patients
4) Great working conditions especially in GSK House and R&D sites 
5) Good work life balance is promoted 
6) People looked after 
7) Think CEO has good long term strategy 
8) A few outstanding leaders
9) Good training and development as well as good career opportunities and scope to travel widely, if that's what you enjoy.
10) Despite current difficulties I believe GSK has bright long term future - and is still a great company to work for.
cons_description:
1) Loss of sales due to patent expiry means environment is one of consolidation rather than growth and many people are distracted as they are worried about jobs and reorganisation - this will improve I think.
2) Culture tends to be very cautious and risk averse - necessary in many parts of the business, but not for all decisions. People from faster moving industries might be frustrated about how long thing take to get done 
3) Although there are some outstanding leaders, some are very poor and unable or unwilling to engage with or provide leadership to their teams.

summary: Doesn't deliver on the flexible working it advertises as a core benefit
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Good bonus scheme and other benefits. Lots of opportunity if you have an appetite to try different things. Some nice people
cons_description: Doesn't deliver on the flexible working it advertises as a core benefit. Leaders are domain experts not strategic or people managers

summary: Doesn't deliver on the flexible working it advertises as a core benefit
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Good bonus scheme and other benefits. Lots of opportunity if you have an appetite to try different things. Some nice people
cons_description: Doesn't deliver on the flexible working it advertises as a core benefit. Leaders are domain experts not strategic or people managers

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for less than a year
pros_description: GSK takes care of its employees and ensures a work-life balance. Much attention is placed on the graduate programme so expect to receive the best training. Good company.
cons_description: The decision making process takes time but it us understandable being an health care company that wants to continually get everything right.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description:
-Nice peers 
-Three restaurants 
-Nice benefits and perks
cons_description:
-Supply planner: New comers get overworked and low pay as well as added in a lower ranking professional grade. Never accept a grade 8 on this role paying less than 40k, you are will be ripped off big times!. We have here people with 2 years relevant experience earning much more than that on a greater professional category (G6 or G7)
-Mafias inside function that negotiate how many people move from one team to another, so you might get blocked or an otherwise highly successful application will turn out into nothing 
-Consumer sell on the banner of 'GSK' but you will be working on a team that looks like a hybrid between L'Oreal and Reckitt. No value, no integrity and no transparency on the recruitment of succession plans

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Big international company with organized structure and processes
cons_description: Not very adequate salaries for the industry. No development opportunities. Too much cost savings and outsourcing. No clear vision and strategy

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Flexible working hours, good leadership
cons_description: little or no progression opportunities

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description:
Very collaborative people culture - people genuinely care about each other.
Attracts down to earth, 'decent' people, comfortable in their own skin
Works with world class agencies in marketing - so great place to learn
cons_description:
- Bizarre organizational structure with the functions only reporting into the business at the CEO level .. as a result company operates in functional silos versus to the needs of the business.
- Ratings, career highly dependent on your manager as your one up manager often has no visibility what you're doing
-Heavy on process and absurdly slow .. most probably since at its heart GSK is a drug company with all the regulatory hurdles that come with that
-Unclear roles/ responsibilities between the markets and the center
-Unclear whether consumer health will remain in GSK or be spun off
-management feels old. There is a sense that 'you have to do your time' at level no matter how strong you are

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Good work/life balance
Intelligent colleagues
Focus on the patient/consumer
cons_description: As a large organisation GSK is less agile than some.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Friendly, safe, clean, huge, close to London
cons_description: Slow, not flexible, hard to change something

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: The best lean sigma training you will find! Great use of Yammer.
cons_description: The worst Expenses system - don't spend any money! However they are all difficult to use.

summary: CH Labelling at GSK - good place to work
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Company has a good package and the people are friendly and there is a lot of flexibility
cons_description: A very busy department with priorities constantly changing

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: You learn a lot. It is a school with lots of learnings and best practices that build your career in the future
cons_description: bad work life balance and lots of politics

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description:
Large amount of other students.
Many learning opportunities.
Direct work and influence on projects.
Very new and modern facilities.
No price limit on procurement.
cons_description:
Some infrastructure problems.
Feedback can be patchy.
Involvement in higher level meetings is restricted.
Options to move out of chemistry from within limited.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than a year
pros_description: Friendly environment, flexible working hours, breadth of experimental techniques, good insight into industrial research
cons_description: Not easy to voice your opinion as a student intern - excluded from group meetings. No input into research objectives

summary: Great place if you have drive to succeed
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Lots of opportunities to progress and move between jobs are available
cons_description: None really, lots of change happening, which might not appeal to some people

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Very varied exciting work and some great people to work with
cons_description: Lack of resources and cost cutting

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Great team spirit (in the labs with other scientists and outside of the labs with management), great benefits, opportunity to grow, fantastic work/life balance (on-site sports, team days out etc.). Recognition of staff when they do something good (nomination system with monetary awards). Work was interesting and fun and I felt supported in my role. Good pay.
cons_description: The GSK site I worked on got shut down very suddenly and major redundancies came into effect. Remaining staff were moved to a bigger site where the team wasn't so tight-knit. At least full-time staff were offered other jobs I guess.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Strong focus on ethical behaviours and doing the right thing
cons_description: Extremely under resourced. Burned out staff. Demotivating bonus structure (quota system).

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 10 years
pros_description: Work hard and play hard
cons_description: Consolidated the majority of global jobs to the UK and US(HQs)

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Good development opportunities. Good benefit packages
cons_description: Can be too fast paced for some.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good salary and benefits, many excellent scientists.
cons_description: Jargon-infested management culture. Hugely inefficient and bureaucratic. Little evidence of mid- to long-term planning, encouraging unimaginative research strategies.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good salary and benefits, many excellent scientists.
cons_description: Jargon-infested management culture. Hugely inefficient and bureaucratic. Little evidence of mid- to long-term planning, encouraging unimaginative research strategies.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description:
Great company benefits and great compensation packages. Good company reputation and worldwide reach. 
Plenty of opportunity to change jobs within the company.
cons_description:
Large organisation makes it bureaucratic. 
Promotion can take a while and is slow process. 
As it is a large company you do not feel like a decision maker.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: GSK is the best company I worked for. The people are very smart, talented and really care about the company and the person at the end of the supply chain - the patient. The offices are brilliant and the compensation is good.
cons_description: The leaders always seem to recruit in their own image. I believe highly effective teams are diverse with different strengths. My own team is very diverse and we are surpassing every targets given to us - I wish more leaders would replicate our success model.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description:
Intelligent people taken from a variety of backgrounds. They care about the people and what they can give to the company. 

Learned a lot during placement year with an excellent social life and an inspiring work environment 

The ability to move around the business and have experience days with third parties e.g in a PR firm for a day 

Variety of different projects to work on and you work end-to-end. Enjoyed the project management side and level of responsibility
cons_description:
Some politics 
Placement students are overworked 
My manager left and I did their role as well as my own which was great for personal development but I wasn't offered a salary road. 

Very little extra benefits for placement students as you're not employed by the company. 

They don't invest in you to be with the company long term. They just use you on placement and then you move on to other things after uni

A lot of organisational change

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: large company. Pension benefits.health care.
cons_description: inpersonal. Little care for employees. Managers lie.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 10 years
pros_description: The Work- life balance is probably the only good thing right now
cons_description: After the joint venture there is a lack of structure seems like no one knows what is going on

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good job opps with different divisions
cons_description: Hq in the middle oh nowhere. Well beginning of m4

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: good company to work with
cons_description: far to travel to maidenhead

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than a year

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 10 years

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than a year

summary: Unsatisfied and taken for granted. Gsk is all about talking the talk.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description:
Good camaraderie amongst work colleagues makes working at Gsk bearable. 
Able to leave at 4pm. Good amount of holidays. Share schemes are excellent value.
cons_description: Crippled by pharma mantra. Unrealistic targets, no recognition.  No career progression. Low relative salary and lots of responsibility, stressful.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years

cons_description: Management does not move / change. All restructures never look at the senior positions.  Took much protectionism.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: GlaxoSmithKline is one of the best pharmaceutical companies in the world, specially in the OTC industry. Excellent corp culture and environment.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Large company, multiple divisions, international.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than a year

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Great Team, Knowledge Share is excellent and working with numerous teams means you understand more of the business at a quicker pace.
cons_description: Can be very busy at year end, but generally a great role.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Did an industrial placement year - was a good experience, felt valued even though I was a student and would definitely return.
cons_description: Not really many downsides, maybe more scientific roles in their graduate programmes would have been good as most of them are business-type schemes.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Surrounded by friendly and driven people
cons_description: There are very few problems wih colleagues.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Great people to work with, sound ethos generally and ethics getting better under current CEO - feel the company does its bit and more to better the world.
cons_description: Cumbersome and chaotic - constant churn and change - stressful to work in, reactive more than proactive

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than a year
pros_description: friendly atmosphere and easy to mingle with very nice
cons_description: lot of confusions in decision making

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline

cons_description: Very competitive graduate scheme which you have to be nominated for and very few people are recommended to progress onto it.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline

summary: Nice company to work for but be careful who you work with...

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Fab love it absolutely amazing

summary: great company to work for, until you are just a number!
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time

summary: FMCG body led by brain riddled with Pharma bureaucracy
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Many nice people, with most recruited to be a 'value' match. Good work to do at a junior level with some interesting brands.
cons_description: Incredibly tough to advance much internally due to entrenched leaders within many functions. There is a huge disconnect between the 'Let's be brave and fast' Consumer Healthcare rhetoric and the fact that the business ultimately remains GSK-branded, meaning decisions are made with a strongly risk-averse Pharma lens... resulting in indecision and delay appearing out of nowhere, despite lots of layoffs in an attempt to make the business faster! Many decisions are made on the basis of 'it's possible someone may complain to the CEO'. Layers of extra bureaucracy appear as if by magic!

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description:
Value based culture. Integrity is really driven 
Increased move to flexible working, permits an attempt at work life balance
cons_description:
Hot-desking is the standard wgay of working and will not suit everybody
In a negative growth phase - signifiacnt down-sizing and restructuring at the moment
Instability of senior leadership to go along with the restructuring

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
- Lots of employee benefits
- Relaxed working environment
- Good, safe salaries
-
cons_description:

- Some roles were not enriching, whilst others were really good roles

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Excellent salary and benefits. Excellent training and opportunities
cons_description: Repetitive sometimes tedious. Cold factory floor.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great people, some fantastic brands with a desire to do more for consumers

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: It was very friendly and I was given alot of support if i needed help. It was also very flexible as my mentor allowed me to change my projects if I wanted to do something different
cons_description: Alot of the work was quite tedious and boring. I re

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline

cons_description: not always busy, lots of free time (can be seen as a pro if you have other things you want to do / uni work to complete)

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 3 years
pros_description: Good benefits package - ability to sacrifice pre-tax salary to buy extra holiday time, childcare, shares, etc.
cons_description: Typical big corporation culture.  Flat operating structure means it's difficult to get promoted.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Excellent flexible environment to work in.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year

cons_description: Clinical data, hard to get out of once you have experience in it. Can be stressful at times of year

Perfect Work/Life Balance
attention to development and providing all the tools to progress in your career

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 10 years
pros_description: Struggling to come up with any positives about working at GSK, or about GSK in general, other than, it's a job.
cons_description:
Morale among staff is poor. Staff are undervalued which is reflected in pay - blanket 1% pay rise for 2015, however expectation to do more with less people, lower budgets greater than ever.
Facilities are tired and in need of updating at some sites but budget allocation is restricting projects to renovate the production areas.
Many Line managers are incompetent at best, and bullies at worst. There are some great ones, but they are few and far between. 
Promotions appear to be be prevalent among those who go drinking with the boss.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Great HEAM team across the UK. package is good
cons_description: Leadership structure is too confusing resulting in no accountability. Focus is on processes, GSK have forgotten about their people

summary: Great place to work for a while
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Great global company - mission and values at heart of organisation. Andrew Witty is a great leader. Company taking steps in the right direction in last few years- mergers/programmes/partnerships. Lots to enjoy about work - good development opportunities and perks to be there.
cons_description: Head office can be a bit out of touch with other sites. Some people worked there for years and get by with not doing much. Sometimes frustrating / slow decision making.

summary: Dedicated production employee for more than a decade
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Job security maybe... There is a fairly good team spirit at the production level though this may be a result of shared agony....
cons_description:
I have given over a decade of blood, sweat and tears to this company but in the process have realised that GSK sadly exists only to serve it's management and it's shareholders. Patient focus though discussed is not really our driving force and the production staff to team leader level are largely disregarded and disrespected. 
       Management dither aimlessly on decisions that they seem inexperienced and ill equipped to make and they lack all of the necessary human skills to run an efficient, effective, harmonious business... 
       The company bleeds money on irrelevant projects while live production lines and staff are largely unsupported and left to make do with outdated equipment, insufficient staff numbers and extremely limited training given the importance of our products. Decisions are often made that have devastating impacts on the personal lives of employees but little regard, remorse or flexibility is shown in trying to make transitions smooth. We are frequently lied to, bullied and generally abused by our over stressed team leaders, one of whom has been solely responsible for at least five employees leaving the company abruptly but has never been scrutinised for his actions. 75%+ of the production team in my department are desperate for redundancy and long to leave this company at the first opportunity.
      I personally have been tortured by the company who chose to leave me on a production line for several months despite it causing me serious pain due to a previous back injury which was being massively aggravated by the ergonomics of the line, I was called a liar when I tried to confront the problem and am still living with the damage months later, additionally I have one of the most severe levels of depression a person can get which I have do deal with alone day in day out, year in year out, when I made GSK aware of this I was subsequently black-marked as a result, duty of care was not even considered and my situation has got much worse, life threatening in fact, as a result of GSK's interference into my personal life... oh... and they made me take a weeks holiday to attend my dying fathers bedside some years back!
           If you are looking for a corporate management position then this could be the place for you but as a production employee responsible for manufacturing a life saving product administered to millions of people all over the world I am hugely disappointed by the company that I no longer trust or respect. 
           I am both proud and sad to say I don't use a single GSK product and never will again.

summary: Once a great employer, struggling since an overhaul of senior leadership in 2010/11

cons_description: Consistent under-performance in the global company ever since the senior management team was changed about 4 years ago, Possibility of divestment in the near future, mediocre salaries after a recent re-structuring

The have an excellent benefits package, one of the best for a FTSE 100.
HQ in Brentford is an impressive building with great canteen, restaurant, bike shop. They even have a hair dressers!

'Talking' is what counts - I mean opening mouth to say something, doesn't matter what it is- no one cares about who walks the walk
Full of new graduates under the title 'CMT' who have absolutely no knowledge of the industry, products, customers or pretty much anything but they go far with their short skirts and the 5-inch heels

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Exciting business. Lots of ambition to deliver. Lots of exciting opportunities. Great (existing) products and very professional place to work with systems and decision making tools
cons_description:
Senior Management is very personality based. The decision making tools that work well at lower levels break down at high levels. Expectations such as costs and schedules are unrealistic and if/when they don't like the message the messenger is the first to get it. 

Bad news is often buried as a result. 
Poor corporate memory and mistakes repeated all the time.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years

My experience has been positive - good leaders, good development and opportunities, good exposure to the 'workings' of the organisation and the strategic decision-making (even when in roles that weren't senior). Fun people to work with who genuinely care about the work they do. Excellent at allowing balance of work and home commitments.  

However all the above is highly dependent on which part of the organisation you're in and who your senior and immediate leaders are - I've heard other people with totally different experiences.
cons_description: The organisation has lost its mojo over the past couple of years.....lots of cost-cutting and reductions, highly risk-averse approach (especially after China).  The CEO, who has been universally liked and respected since coming in and who has changed the culture of the organisation for the better, has become almost invisible and is 'losing' his staff.
