The size of the company means there are lots of opportunities though, because something is always changing - so you can get very broad experience if you are willing to re-apply your skills in a different way.  Very good at work/life balance and very supportive of flexible working.  Salaries seem to be competitive and the bonus and benefits packages are good.
cons_description: A bit old fashioned and slow moving.  Can be overly risk averse, even for a pharma company.  Lack of clear ownership and accountability in some areas makes it very hard to get clear decisions and direction.  Good, clear strategy from the very top, but often doesn't get well translated into activity further down the organisation.

summary: Great place to be a lawyer.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Well supported by management.  Work/life balance is exceptionally good.  Respected (if a little distant) from the business.  Reward is good overall, but base salaries are not as good as peers. Fantastic values, which the company genuinely lives (scandals are the result of very isolated and vehemently rejected behavior).  High performing colleagues across the business.
cons_description: Bureaucracy is endemic.  A slow moving company internally and strongly influenced by its scientific base (i.e. do everything technically properly without thinking about the commercial realities).  Getting better, but some way to go. Career progression opportunities limited, but many people find a level that they are happy with and stay until retirement.

summary: Great people, great products - pity about some of the current behaviours being accepted within the organisation
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: GSK tends to employ lovely people who are great to work with.  The company has some great brands that can really help people.
cons_description: There is currently a disconnect between the stated values of the company and some of the behaviours being conducted and accepted within the company.  The recent poor results are causing great stress and anxiety within the organisation.  Recent corruption scandals in China and elsewhere were very disappointing to see as an employee

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description:
Excellent free coffee.  high quality stationary, colour printers, pens
Good training which is easy to go on. Nice business trips
cons_description: The company is Somewhat hierarchal, it not always transparent, and there are some questionable work ethics despite what is stated

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description:
GSK is a very people focused enjoyable place to work. The office in Brentford is amazing!

The culture is the best thing about GSK - they focus on their employees and reward very fairly.
cons_description:
Lack of process - sometimes too much focus on the people with meetings about meetings.

Slow changes / slow decision making due to the size of the company.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Great people and great science, lots of passion
cons_description: It is a big company so sometimes it might be a challenge to get things done; Salaries are not the best when compared with competition

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Great package, trusted by management and opportunities. Given room to develop and grow, great links with other sites across the company.
cons_description: The local culture could be overwhelming on occasion, they were the largest employer in a small town with long serving staff, who had been through a lot of change in a short period.

cons_description: Changing work environment, Unsure about the Organisations Strategic direction

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year

cons_description: Pay element of benefits lower than industry average. Global opportunities not as easy to access as I expected or was led to believe. Going through major change which can lead to slow decision making.

salary is OK

summary: Generally a nice place to work.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Overall GSK seems a good place to work with the Barnard Castle site set in a beautiful location. Most people are really friendly and helpful. Also good share and pension scheme.
cons_description: Poor pay compared to rest of site, unable to get holidays and time off when you want. Morale  seems very low.

summary: A chance to work with smart colleagues in a place where innovation genuinely happens
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for less than a year
pros_description: The company really focuses on its people. This ranges from ensuring that you aren't overworked, through to training sessions about maximising your energy at work or working to the best of your potential without burning out. You work alongside some of the smartest people in the industry, and many of these people have been within the company a long time (20-30 years in many cases). This isn't due to being institutionalised or being afraid to move - it is because GSK always manages to offer them with new challenges and opportunities (some quite extreme, such as moving function entirely). You are given the chance to change things for the better, and the environment really does allow for innovation.
cons_description: Stakeholder management can be a full-time job! An awfully large range of people can have a say in any initiatives you want to get off the ground. And although innovation is encouraged, if you don't properly manage your stakeholders then things can fall apart when it comes to implementation or ongoing engagement. There are also a lot of meetings, that can get in the way of getting your 'day job' work done.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: It's got fantastic values and behaviours to aspire to.  Work is interesting and potential to work on projects that provide real value to society is there.
cons_description: Struggling with a new identity and walking the talk of those values.  Consider if you are young talent, but beware if you are over 50.  They are looking for youn talent and pushing out older employees to save costs.

summary: Not my best every employer, wouldnt go back as the culture was toxic
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: Great facilities and pleasant work environment
cons_description: Back stabbing to get on ahead of your colleagues- always looking over your shoulder at who was coming for you next! Didnt get much satisfaction from what I was doing and found no-one willing to be accountable for their actions. Too much 'the emperor has no clothes'!

summary: Great experience, high throughput research and development
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Team work was superb, health employee benefits, Great R&D facilities
cons_description: High Pressure situations to produce results. Segregation between the different departments i.e invivo, invitro, dmpk

summary: Company attempting to make massive jump in how it works, but too much deadweight might pull it down.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Good working environment, some very capable people. Lots of growth potential. Not as open to new ideas as previously thought.
cons_description:
Pay is all over the place. Same seniority ranking can have over 30% difference, doesnt matter amount of direct reports or work hours. Company has restructured benefits, bonuses, and pensions to be as low and as cheap as possible.

Work hours can be quite tense at time, and culture represents a hit or miss and you're out.

Recognitions are a bit of a joke when they do happen.

Organization very burocratic and slow to react at times, very seniority driven.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Interesting and with many opportunities to learn and develop;
cons_description: Very stressful environment; open space with dense population on a sq. meter.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for less than a year

cons_description: slow pace industry, too many layers of management,

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Positive, friendly place. Genuine motivation to help people do more feel better live longer

summary: My experience with this company is difficult to say.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline

summary: Silo mentality in comparison to the rest of GSK

pros_description: Fantastic product innovation. Leading edge brands. World class scientific background. Great place to work if you want to learn in a fast moving environment.
cons_description: Silo mentality. Thinks itself above and beyond the rest of GSK. Stuck in the past with very old management style driven by senior management.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great company to work for.  Family friendly policies

summary: Great Experience so far and lot of energy in the company
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: I love the culture in GSK

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
It's possible to commute from North London to most GSK R&D sites, so you don't have to live somewhere miserable, like in other big pharma R&D departments.
Some members of staff are keen to encourage cross-departmental knowledge sharing and collaboration, and there is an internal network to facilitate this. Also lab books were kept electronically, online, and were visible to others.
During my internship I was given the freedom to create my own project. I also worked in a group that maintained good links with academia. Some fellow interns even published their projects.
Apparently lots of scope to go part time later.
cons_description:
Regular reorganization leaves some departments feeling empty. 
The pay doesn't compare to other big pharma R&D departments, and it's expensive to live in north London.
There's no atmosphere outside of regular working hours as no one seems to feel the need to work overtime.

summary: Working here provided an insight on how the Pharmaceutical indutry works.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Provides good exposure to:
-how the Pharmaceutical industry works.
-how the Pharmaceutial industry is very business orientated.
-new cutting edge technologies.
cons_description:
Provides insight on:
-how not to run a Pharmaceutical company.
-how out of touch the management are with reality.
-their very short term goals and interests.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Great company and great people! You can really learn a lot.
Good benefits, holidays.
cons_description:
Very tight budget.
Pretty much no opportunities for employees for any training courses or conferences.
Very difficult for a promotion to a management position

summary: Only a nice place to work if you are permanent employee
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Knowledgeable co-workers, professional attitudes, wide variety of training provided, and earnest effort to provide tools needed to carry out work.
cons_description: Two tier staff system with excellent benefits for GSK staff but no benefits, no security, no advancement for contract staff - very clear 2nd class status for contractors particularly total lack of parking. Lower level managers often poorly trained.

summary: Great place to work, good quality people & work/life balance

cons_description: Poor base pay in relation to similar roles in other companies and promotions are few and far between and take a long time to happen. Systems are poor for such a successful company. Can be quite political at times.

summary: Amazing place to work for Finance - ample opportunities to progress if you desire
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline

Intelligent and talented colleagues to work with and learn from
Strong corporate culture in Finance
Ample opportunities to climb the career ladder, if you so desire
cons_description:
Difficult to transfer quickly to opportunities in the US, because of the 18 month rule.
Some employees are '100% fat' ie.  they give little value to GSK. If GSK was to make these employees redundant, they would most likely not find employment at the renumeration level they were on and would struggle to sell themselves in the wider job market.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline

summary: Overall a descent place to work.

The personal development/performance review system is fairly well established. There are good chances to do secondment on different jobs for people who would consider a career change.
cons_description: Base salary not very high in compare with some of the competitor companies. Room for promotion is limited and takes long time

summary: Great company in a troubled industry
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
There are varied carrer opportunities, the ability to progress within and between roles.  The benefits package is excellent and the company can be flexble in accomodating personal needs.

The focus on delivering benefit to to patient and value to the payer is excellent and to my mind places GSKahead of many others in the industry.
cons_description:
The climate in the pharma industry and the attitude of society towards big pharma is driving rapid change and cost cutting.  this is not specific to GSK, but GSK is not immune.  Andrew Witty seems to have solid appreciation of the issue.

Head office location at Brentford has to be one of the worst locations in London from a transport and ammenity perspective.  Car parking is very restricted and public transport links are poor.

summary: GSK - Pharma giant that cant make up itsmind
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Branching into a number of different areas of research at the moment with some opportunities being created here. Pay and benefits comparable to others within the sector.
The pipeline and product replacement is probably the best in the industry right now and GSK will probably be the largest pharma within a few years. Expansion across the globe means opportunity overseas could be available.
cons_description:
The company continually changes its targets (which is in itself good) but never allows enough time for them to be met.
Shareholders mean everything to GSK now and staff are just an unavoidable expense. 
If you want to work for GSK, ensure as good a pay deal and as high a grade as humanely possible because your chances of progress within this organisation are very limited. They would rather buy in skills than develp staff. There is a huge amount of 'restructuring' at this company which will likely continue for the foreseeable future, making staff morale quite low.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good place to apply science and engineering and a leader in the field. Attractive product pipeline when compared to the rest of the industry and the presence of a new CEO who will make change happen
cons_description: Politics, Beurocracy. Takes too long to do anything and only those that brownose seem to suceed. Management is very retracted from the issues that cause us problems in production so there proposed solutions for better operational efficiency is somewhat blurred. R&D is not a productive environment compared to other companies that seem to do development far better than GSK

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description:
- Benefits are solid (401k match, pension plan, health care)
- Managers generally flexible if you leave early for appointments 
- People are very helpful if you have questions
cons_description:
- Pay is below industry in the area
- Commercial manufacturing support hours are scheduled around the manufacturing process, so you can get calls even when off / out of the office
- Poor work-life balance
- A lot of politics and red tape to get any simple thing done
- Fixed bonus structures so it's based on tenure and not your actual performance anymore, so you have a lot of loafers that don't do enough but still get paid as much if not more because they've been with the company longer
- Change is poorly managed (parking, people seating allocations)

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Nice people for the most part and beautiful office. Good benefits.
cons_description: Epitome of icky corporate culture at its worst. Fake, back-stabbing, leadership that act like sheep. Speak out against the grain and you risk being reprimanded or pushed out. The emphasis on transparency is complete and utter BS- people tiptoe around the truth. Unbelievably difficult to get information you need to get the job done at such an “innovative” organization. People are not open to change or doing things differently- everything is for optics. I have never worked with a more incompetent HR team, either. Totally siloed organization in a poor strategic position.

author_title: Current Employee - Head of Trade Marketing
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description:
Good inclusive culture not only in terms of gender but also in terms of accepting outside ideas and people with different backgrounds. The organization is very humble as they know they have a lot to do to be in the same level of the big FMCGs and CH companies, it is not arrogant at all. 
Very strong brands such as Advil, Panadol, Sensodyne, etc.
cons_description:
Too few career opportunities for people that are in the organization. In the last 5 years, it integrated with two different companies and the leading mindset came always from the company that was integrated to GSK. Moreover the tendency is always to seek talent from outside and not give chance to the people inside the organization.
Brands have sometimes a limited level of investment compared with their main competitors

summary: Headed in right direction with few bumps on the way
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for less than a year
pros_description:
Overall culture is improving.

- Flexible working hours and working remotely.

- Health and Well-being focused (Free Massage, Health Checks, Boxing class, and Lunch Walk group)

- Weekly Morning Tea (Lots o' food)

- Social Event (Xmas in July, Oktoberfest, R U OK day)

- A shift towards to digital solutions

- You will be surrounded with smart, hard-working people.

- Decent Pay

- EAP

- Novated Lease
cons_description:
- Many forms to fill even for a simple access request

- Long turnaround time (good luck if your support team is overseas)

- Not agile (yet) as a company

- Site is quite remote (lack of food options mainly)

- Politics can still be felt and visible (inevitable in a company of GSK's size)

- Won't push you to grow unless you are proactive about it.

cons_description:
Field sales is so toxic. Pharma has issues, but GSK tries to be the best toxic place of them all.
- Patient first has made everything subjective.
- Managers have scripted ratings aka calibration.
- There’s tons of busy work, you must put on an act in order to appease management.
- Success is based on how your manager likes you.
- Several layoffs in past years.
- Company has questionable ethics, Search this one.
- They commonly force people out they don’t like.
- They just changed to reward sales again, but this could mean easier layoffs.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description:
Fantastic place to learn but only suitable for employees that are really aligned to making a change to patient's life.  

Detailed investigation process and structured systems available as layers of governance to prevent any undesirable outcomes such as safety incidents / quality incidents. 

Every single employee have the potential to change the direction of the company is going in the name of investigation lead.
cons_description:
Without having a higher purpose, one will not be able to survive staring at your salary slip by the month. It is not sustainable. 

One must be detailed in nature in terms of personality and have perfected multitasking as a skill to be able to survive but not excel. 

Unlimited amount of projects to undertake with very stretched timelines. Be prepared to be swarmed and not only challenged. Being challenged is an understatement. 

Compliance is at its at it's pinnacle for both complexity as well as broadness of scope. Every single entry recorded as part of manufacturing will be scrutinized by quality in the name of FDA data integrity requirement. 

Heavy reliance on interns for routine work to be completed. Staffs can no longer cope with routine work, let alone improvements.

author_title: Current Employee - Senior Immunology Account Specialist
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description:
Great pay, good benefits

Lots of job openings due to qualified people leaving for better opportunities.
cons_description:
Inept managers and even more inept senior leaders.  Keep promoting people based on politics and loyalty and it will be GSK 2009 all over again.

Seems like most major decisions are made by throwing a dart at a dartboard - all done without input from the actual people that have to carry out the inane marching orders.

The latest sales initiative with the  creative moniker, COCO, is a disaster and encourages reps to act in a manner that is different when their managers are not around.

Don't expect recognition or promotion if you're not a female and/or minority.

Restructuring every 18 to 24 months.  Don't expect to keep your same territory or manager.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description:
Great place to work, competitive salary, nice work-life balance  & supportive coworkers.

Cons

Too much beaurocracy and needless paper work. Could not focus on customer needs anymore had go by numbers. Last year I was there (2010) GSK offered voluntary retirement and it fit for me. My job was so unique there was no replacement found for the work I did.

Advice to Management

Pay more attention to your users of the tools they need to do their job and do away with unnecessary paperwork
cons_description: Do not expect to fully control your career destiny. Changes impact the general employee.

summary: GSK is a Great SHORT Term employment opportunity.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description:
Great Pay, Benefits and Work Life Balance.
Great People
You will learn a lot about the details of Pharma industry.
cons_description:
You will be temporary. Your personal life will be on hold while you await to see if you dodged the latest reorganization. You will never know when your time will be up.
GSK has a fully staffed HR Severance division. It runs like clockwork and well tested. They have a displaced employee outsourcing company on retainer!
No one works in the US for 10 years at GSK anymore. Keep your resume ready.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Your experience at GSK will completely depend on which department you work for. Some departments only work 7hrs, others have the expectation of working longer and weekends if needed, and others have shifts. Some departments get a lot of funding so you get to go to multiple conferences, and some barely get funding so no travel. Also, some departments heavily push career development and others are the exact opposite. Finally, some departments tolerate poor leadership and some have little tolerance for bad leaders and management... So if you interview here, ask what the work hours, work/life balance, and career development opportunities are like. Ask about the culture! I've seen combinations of everything. Also, lots of reorg has been going on, leaving a lot of people a bit stressed.
cons_description: Great when it's great, but the bad can get really frustrating... Also the people who have worked at GSK for like ever never want to be innovate, which holds everyone else back

summary: Mediocrity, silent discrimination, personal progress based on origin, poor people management and worst leadership ever!
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: My severance package was the best thing I saw in the company.
cons_description: Since the new CEO stepped in there are only cuts in all depts. For instance the respiratory medical representatives in over 10 countries were layed off and their work was outsourced to Berlin Chemie. At the same time many positions are being centralized in London, people are not offered relocation and the only criteria which qualifies you is to live in the city. The mediocrity is at all levels in the company as they don't invest in trainings. The company propaganda blows every day 'positive news' but the reality is that they don't have a pipeline and due to this people are laid off in large groups trying to balance the books and satisfy the shareholders. The systems are behind everything modern nowadays - the DOS like JDE is still used for invoicing and Excel is your main tool. They are trying to compensate all these negatives with building an image of best LGBT inclusive company, engagement in the NGO sector through their pulse program but this is all fake.

author_title: Former Employee - Senior Medical Sales Representative
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Here is No pest reason
cons_description: Mainly qualified business at this company

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Pay is great, one of the highest in the area. Great benefits. Work life balance is good and the  site lead and upper level management work hard to make sure you are not only safe at work but also during any inclement weather events. Pretty relaxed atmosphere with alot of nice people to work with.  I worked in two different departments. Solid dose is great, great people, everyone works together to make a great product. The other area I was in which I choose not to disclose was a mess and I have elaborated below in the cons section.
cons_description: The particular department I was in was not managed well. Alot of gossip on every value stream level, backstabbing, finger pointing,  childish workplace conflicts between coworkers on every shift. Lack of communication and collaboration between management, production, planning and maintenance. My department was understaffed and required over time every weekend( although not mandatory). There was talk of going to a 12 hour shift schedule the whole time I was in the department but it always fell through due to staffing issues and not having everyone on board. Newer employees were always in the shadows of senior techs/ favorites  in management's eyes even if performance level was equal or better. No recognition for going above and beyond, the job can be very stressful depending on where your shift starts during the production process with no support and sometimes not having the right tools or the right people/resources to do the job correctly and efficiently. Equipment would break down with repetitive problems, no fix from engineering or maintenance. It was always a temporary band-aid repair or nothing causing it to just happen the next night or next week exc. Inappropriate relationships between supervisors and coworkers. The training program is flawed and almost non existent. The main trainer for my area would not give you the correct training to do your job and would with hold alot of information from the trainee in spite. There were a lot of shortcuts taken in my area behind closed doors not aligning with sop's, instances of falsification, back dating the list goes on.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: Big Pharma has deep pockets and GSK is no exception. Scientists have the opportunity to work with the latest cutting edge technology, interact with therapy area KOLs, and generally be surrounded by great colleagues. The company mission is noble, and there is the opportunity to make a real difference if you are part of a program that leads to an approved medicine.
cons_description: Employees can sometimes get lost in a huge company, and GSK could do a better job at rebooting the careers of the lost rather than letting them wander aimlessly through the halls like well compensated zombies. Priorities can change fast at GSK, and you never knew when you may find yourself on the losing side of a program, or site closure. Frequent re-orgs and layoffs maintained a certain level of anxiety for most. Often people would not speak up for fear of retribution.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline part-time
pros_description: One of the only jobs in a long career where I felt there was no hesitation to compensate me at a level that matched my experience; my incoming salary as a PT employee (35 hrs per week) was $25K more than my fulltime salary at SAS after a number of years in which the majority of people in my dept. saw very little growth in compensation and zero opportunity for professional advancement/changes in job descriptions. While I was only at GSK for a few years and did have a PT position, I saw a number of examples of FT, longtime employees getting opportunities to spend six months in a different department, job-share, get training, etc.  Benefits were also great.
cons_description: As a newcomer to the company working many (great) people who had been there for decades, I found that it could sometimes be difficult to break into the 'inner circle' and be included in certain projects. I brought a lot of good, relevant experience into the department, but I had to keep reminding them that I was happy to help and had some expertise with certain kinds of projects. As a PT person, I knew some of that was just a given, but it was also a shame to be under-utliized sometimes. At the end of my time there, we shifted to open workspace and 'hoteling' -- where you never sit in the same place every day and keep your belongings in a file drawer. I saw few benefits - it was a drag to have no bit of real estate to call your own and put personal touches on, and my team was less connected instead of more, simply because we no longer sat together. Everyone was far-flung.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: Fantastic people work here ( in gsk and in the 3rd party) and they are extremely supportive- please tell them this
cons_description:
Not cons but possible areas for improvement....
Calling the speakup line- if you do not disclose a country they won’t take the report. There are instances where country and content would disclose identity. Some issues are not country specific.
- password not given to provide follow up.

Online system- must choose a country. Same comment as above. 

Not all elements of report are always investigated- may be related to understanding of nuances. 
Some reports are not investigated eg harrassment cases the victim is asked if they wish for an investigation putting them in a vulnerable position as by default it’s not an anonymous investigation. (Not only example I have heard of)
Gaps identified are not all followed up to check they are closed.

There is very little confidence in the no retaliation policy. Know many who left or claim to have left after speak-ups both callers and people investigated)
Have heard many managers discourage use of speakups over last year because of accelerate and concern on impacting accelerate decisions. 
There is no periodic follow up to ensure there is no repercussions retaliation or follow on issues related to initial issue.

author_title: Former Employee - Senior Pharmaceutical Sales Representative
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Excellent pay and benefits.   I represented drugs that truly made a difference in patient outcomes, and therefore it was easy to passionate about my job.   Great manager.  Training was not easy.  However, I  was last employed 13 years ago.  GD doesn't offer ability to note that above.  Before being hired, I was given a pharmacology book on a Friday, and had to take a 100 question multiple choice test the following Monday - before I was hired.   I  then had a month of home study for each product, each month being followed by a trip to Orlando to take a test.  All of that was followed by 3 weeks of intense sales training in the home office.  I hear the training is not as intense any longer,  that there may be a few trips to home office for a period of a few days at a time.  Some of it is done online now.  I would love to return to GSK!
cons_description: My only real complaint is that I was due an earned promotion before I went out on maternity leave.  I was told they'd just process it while I was out.   Turns out I had a child born with a birth defect, and was unable to return at that time.  So now my resume doesn't reflect that promotion.

Transparency is lost between top level management and workforce.

cons_description: I don't believe pay practices are fair. The company is in an industry with the strongest balance sheet and I don' t think the company shares the proceeds appropriately with its employees. The average pay rise is below the inflation rate. The compensation mechanism should be focused on position, person and performance. The company only pays for position and performance. There is no focus on the unique skills and value that a person brings to the company.

summary: Early talent falls through the cracks and innovation falls on deaf ears
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description:
- Global company - there's opportunity if you're willing to move & lots of people to learn from
- Nice people
- Work/life balance is valued, but is often used as an excuse not to do company engagement activities
cons_description:
- Interns, graduates and early talent recycled year on year  - very little opportunity to progress
- Systems and processes stifle progress - new ways of doing things are not appreciated
- Some departments seem to have excess people while others are incredibly under resourced.
- Inclusion and Diversity strategy seems to be in full swing in head office but nothing transfers over to Ireland.
- Career development and progression is next to non existent. Once people are in a job, that's where they stay forever
- Employee engagement is all but forgotten - there are never any social events or staff activities.
- Performance is deemed the most important of the company's three priorities while 'innovation and trust' is pushed aside. If you're not performing at 100% every moment of the day, the company doesn't care about you.
- The Irish business has only one priority - profit. If you're not making money for the company they will cast you aside.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than a year
pros_description: I worked for the pharmaceutical division as a management trainee and as an area manager later. GSK Bangladesh followed all the global vision, mission, values set by the GSK headquarter at UK. Unlike most other pharmaceuticals in Bangladesh,  fields sales force was treated with respect.
cons_description: Due to global guideline restriction, there has always been a push to cut down promotion cost and focus more on detailing. However, considering Bangladeshi doctor visit detailing practice, that is a huge drawback. I always struggled to motivate my team to go to doctors barehanded, whereas other companies used a variety of promo materials.

summary: Talent development programs (post MBA) do not meet expectations
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Strong and consistent mission-orientation for patients.  Friendly co-workers.  Executives and CEO care and want to turn the business around.  40 hour week lends itself to work/life balance.
cons_description:
a) As a post-MBA graduate, I joined the company's rotation program called ESPRIT with the expectation to learn and build leadership skills and then 'graduate' in a fulfilling mid-level role after 4 years.  Rotations were great learning grounds, but finding a permanent role in the organization was challenging.  Demand for interesting roles greater than supply.   The team running the ESPRIT program does not communicate well the vision and goal well to senior leaders, leading to confusion about the differences between post-MBA and post-BA graduates.
b) Large company means that for some roles, you may have limited ability to make impact. Some teams feel overstaffed and this reduces motivation.

Very good place to do an internship!
cons_description:
Mostly French and therefore a big influence of the French culture. (not as punctual as Flemish culture) - in the quality department 
Advice to future interns: you need to be very proactive, seek/ find/ define your own tasks and speek up when necessary.

pros_description:
Friendly, hard-working staff
Staff shop
Annual conference
Established, globally recognised brand

cons_description:
Poor culture & high turnover - when leadership asked what they were doing to address this, their answer was 'we have implemented a HR policy around this'
Lack of leadership - most of senior leadership have left in past two years - draw your own conclusions why - as a result, lack of direction from leadership team on tough decisions 
Short-term focus by leadership to chase unrealistic targets.  This has lead to under-resourcing  at the expense of brand equity and employee happiness caused by crippling workloads
Poor work/life balance in many teams due to employees leaving and this being absorbed as a 'saving' instead of the position being filled
Technology is caught in the past decade - needs to catch up

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: Health Care, Salary, promotes diversity
cons_description: Long hours, struggling to change, central function Infrastructure very poor with little manufacturing site suppport. There is very little in the way of positive support for HR site leads. Site leads don’t involve themselves until it is time to block forward progress. IT systems are poor and continue to be behind. The company works on two extremes of production and QA. The daily site message in produce and release with little in the way of investment to support making this easier. The functional QA groups are equally as extreme introducing ways of working that add little more than  bureaucracy.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Gsk most top growing company in the world
cons_description: I am waiting for your response

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Flexible working arrangements, smart people, great benefits.
cons_description: If you are an NC-based employee, the carousel of people leaving is never-ending as R&D is moved to Philadelphia. Atmosphere in the building is terrible and it is sad to see a place decay after so many good years in North Carolina. The amount of experience GSK let walk out the door is shocking. Senior management doesn't care though. Emma Walmsley is about as fake and uninspiring as, well, I don't know what. She is the opposite to Andrew Witty, who made me proud to be an employee. Long history of senior managers making terrible decisions and then getting promoted and not having to face the fallout from their decisions (hope you are reading this Moncef).

summary: Does Not Value Employees and Does Not Give Opportunities

cons_description: There is little opportunity to grow and develop within the company. If you are good at little task, you will forever stay doing those tasks. After many meetings with managers and Supervisors to allow growth and development, the only was to do so was leave the company and go elsewhere. Meeting with management is like talking to a wall as they do not value most people. You will be valued and heard if you are in their circle.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description:
Great people. Great talent.  On paper things are good.
Good benefits, vacation,  year end shutdown.
cons_description:
Bad leadership.
Too many redundant initiatives and not always sure who owns what or why. 
Favorite employees get promoted.
Otherwise it’s almost impossible to move from a grade 7 to a 6. Been trying for about a decade - with good year end reviews each year, so at this point I’m close to giving up and leaving - despite how much I actually enjoy my role.
I report to someone less experienced and less qualified than me - and see less experienced, capable and qualified people given opportunities - my 1:1 discussions are good but my manager has never been able to articulate exactly what gaps I’m missing that others don’t have. Very frustrating.

summary: Be Prepared to Ride the Wave
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: When the organization commits to something, they commit. If your projects become priorities, there will be support and desire for results.  You will be surrounded by talented coworkers and the means to achieve your goals. When times are good the company will commit to developing the skills of the team.
cons_description: There will be initiatives that are driven by people you have not met, and have not engaged with you honestly. They will be filtered down the management chain in a game of telephone where messages can be mixed. Many of these initiatives are harmless, well-intended and a few are useful. Some are layevoffs/reorgs with an uncomfortable amount of positive spin. Patience and serenity are required.

cons_description: Company is always trying to save money which means taking it away from the people who make the sales. Sales incentives are virtually none. If you're a high performer and you want uncapped potential, do not work here.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time

Benefits are good as well... start with 3 weeks of vacation, great health insurance, 401k, etc.
cons_description: Con are really department dependent. I am lucky enough to work in a department where even the VPs want to get to know the employees on a personal basis and everyone is focused on good science, good medicines, and good career development.

author_title: Former Employee - Director and Senior Research Investigator
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Interesting and meaningful work, good salary and benefits, great colleagues at the NC R&D site.
cons_description: As would be expected at a large R&D company, bureaucracy adds significant overhead to doing science but GSK seemed to have more problems with this than similar companies.  GSK R&D leadership did a poor job of setting strategic direction and staying the course.  Made significant changes to strategy every couple of years which is problematic for a research driven company.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Great workplace atmosphere with colleagues keen on helping you integrate. A lot of resources for training related to non-research activities, helping you grow professionally.
cons_description: Same set of high expectations between research locations, but resources and equipment are not the same everywhere. However inter-site collaboration is possible.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Benefits are great.  Flexible work options in most departments.  Growth in Vaccines portfolio.  Most departments work as a team.  Very lean organization internally.  CEO is making some changes to return back to being a competitive company.
cons_description: Many departments micromanage.  Looking for next big product (cash flow can be an issue for bold new ideas as a result).  Limited upward  promotional opportunities.   Some departments are understaffed making workloads heavy.  (internal).  Significant transformational changes in R&D organization, good in the long run but chaos for now.  Limited money spent on employee entertainment.

summary: Excellent values and global mission, but constant strategic changes
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description:
- Strong focus on values that guide decision-making.  They don't just talk about values, they live them.
- Positive global citizen
- Passionate, brilliant employees who want to make a difference
- Solid product pipeline
- Global footprint creates international career path opportunities
- A company you can be proud to say you work for
- Strong, inspirational leaders at the global level
cons_description:
- Frequent changes in global corporate strategy.  Creates a challenge in remaining focused, and disruption in trying to interpret what new strategies mean for individual-level execution
- Insufficient focus on holding local country management accountable for strong leadership
- Some markets have experienced a significant number of resignations in recent years (e.g. Canada)
- Pendulum has swung radically towards risk management, SOPs, and strict enforcement of policies without employing common sense (e.g. sales managers feeling pressured to 'report' reps for having a bottle of water in the vehicle...against fleet policy)
- While not necessarily a 'bad thing', the company is struggling to find the right balance of good governance, employee empowerment, and common sense.  Wildly varying interpretations at the balance have created significant tension and friction in parts of the company.
- The intense focus on governance can sometimes manifest as an attitude that can be perceived as 'holier than thou', both within teams and with external parties.

summary: One of the  most inovative employers ever
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 10 years
pros_description: Work with the brightest minds and the most compassionate people in combination with the amazing people that serve in the medical field.  There were always new opportunities to educate and help providers give the best care and medications possible. We really saved lives everyday!
cons_description: Unfortuntely the increased demand for lower cost health care and the push to use  more and more generics has limted the access to providers that were once open to the latest information.  It is now filtered through various medical formularies that take from the physician the 'art of practicing medicine'.  These are among the greatest minds ever on the earth and they have to limit their gift to fit in an ever shrinking box of managed care rules and regulations.  Society as a whole suffers this great loss!

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description:
Strong and palpable focus on patients
GSK Biologics (vaccines) is special in that it is helping with a very inspirational public health agenda
Global footprint can create lots of opportunities
cons_description:
GSK Biologics continues to be Belgium centric and not truly a global culture
Sometimes it feels like tenure is more important than talent, and speaking French is most important of all
I felt the culture was not friendly to female employees (felt a bit like stepping back into the 50s with a male dominated culture) and definitely not friendly to Indian employees (I don't understand why, but saw several examples of it)
Performance driven culture has been lacking

summary: Anyone lower than a Director is just a Minion.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for less than a year
pros_description: Beautiful office building and modern office equipment; Inspiring senior level leaders (C-Levels) bringing in new vision, focus, and hopefully a culture of change.
cons_description: Consumer mid level leaders (directors) are too busy focusing on self interest to actually manage or coach their own teams; More than a couple dont have mastery and don't even work to deserve their titles and pay; When faced w issues, it takes these mid level leaders ages to acknowledge the matter, and thereupon another few months to action upon a fix or course correction; Tons of directors; Anyone lower than director is easily disposable.

pays very well
great brands

summary: Great place to work, values matter

summary: Good company but expect restructuring every two years.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Good work environment, nice people, flexible working, good benefits.  Bonuses can make a nice positive impact on the salary. Opportunity for lateral moves are sometimes possible.
cons_description: Constant organizational change leading to lack of instability, corporate bureaucracy can feel overwhelming.  Annual bonuses is tied to a normal distribution curve; even if you have worked well and performed you can still technically have underperformed.  This can be very demotivating and seems to run against the 'team' ethos most companies try to create.

summary: Was a good company but not anymore!
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Used to be one of the best pharma companies in the US.  They have great products and strong pipeline.
cons_description: Consistently having restructuring and layoffs.  Advair is going generic and this is really going to impact all employees.  The bonus structure is subjective and reps have no control over their bonus.  Management does not care about employees and try to find a way to push out seasoned reps.  Limited opportunities for growth within the field.  They do not respect work life balance.  Senior management is horrible and don't care about the field.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Great and talented people at the peer level and first line management.  Industry leaders in many aspects.
cons_description: Upper management would make decisions based on their need to be recognised for being innovative rather than strategic. There was a huge disconnect  between those doing the work and those dictating how it should be done.

summary: Used to be great, but culture has soured and morale is low
author_title: Former Employee - Senior Pharmaceutical Sales Representative
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Most of my co-workers were top-notch
cons_description: Tout an environment of transparency, but are rarely transparent. Benefits were starting to slide the last few years and new policies have been implemented to penny and dime employees on expense reports (For example: We were not allowed to expense a coffee at the airport when traveling to a company meeting. Also not allowed to expense lunch on a day we travelled to a meeting bc one was served at the hotel even though our flight was such that we didn't arrive until AFTER the lunch buffet closed. We are expected to have wifi at home, but company decided it would no longer contribute.) Little to no opportunity to advance as last two Primary Care reorganizations have involved manager layoffs.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time

I enjoyed volunteering with Science in Schools program as a GSK Ambassador to our local community which exhibited integrity.  GSK had respect for people and I loved receiving awards to celebrate my team and individual talents.  I enjoyed working with global counterparts whom were open to new ways of working and  displayed leadership to inspire others.  As a driven employee,  I shared knowledge and information freely to work together to achieve common goals to build on the portfolio of GSK success.

cons_description: Based in Singapore, collaboration with UK and US means working during their working hours which is often out of hours in SG. Basically no consideration given to the times of meetings in SG by the other parties, and the local expectation is that they are attended. Can impact work life balance.

summary: A very good place to work that used to be great
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: GSK Consumer Healthcare is a very good place to work but that had historically been a truly great place to work.  The people you work with are exceptional and the culture has been historically supportive, encouraging, positive, and focused on development.  The company has a true sense of mission and a strong teamwork approach.  Compensation and benefits are without question exceptional as is the work life balance.  During recent savings initiatives the travel budget was cut substantially year on year for the past 5 years.  While this might seem like a negative it was in fact a very large positive having shown that most business travel can be cut without negative impacts on performance.  Judicious investments in video teleconferencing and collaboration tools more than made up for the travel reductions and sharply improved work life balance for all corporate travelers especially where US/Europe and US/Asia travel was concerned.
cons_description: Recent changes to the corporate strategy, integration of the Novartis business/joint venture, and a strong move to downsize has undercut the culture and resources that made it a truly great place to work.  Many highly experienced individuals elected to leave the company due to these changes.  This, along with a very challenging computer system upgrade has made life more difficult for employees.  Hopefully these just turn out to be growing pains.  The real negative has become the strong growth of corporate politics between the former GSK and Novartis factions.  Politicization and siloing has pushed decision making on even the most mundane of subjects to much too high of a level.  This coupled with business performance objectives that are divorced from what is actually feasible have contributed to distress at manager level and below.

summary: Visionary company, but behavior based selling model has room for improvement.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Great people, great products, industry leading, innovative, great pipeline, values-driven, customer centric, respectful workplace, great culture, fairly strong empowerment to run our business strategically within appropriate guard rails.
cons_description: Behavior based selling model impedes potential for significant growth & sales professional accountability, and misaligns incentives around demonstrating behaviors vs. making sales. To some degree, the company is also focused on metrics (reach, frequency, # of calls, etc.) and wanting leaders to hold teams accountable to those things because we aren't allowed to incentivize sales performance below a regional level due to the Corporate Integrity Agreement GSK is in with the OIG.

summary: Great company, great values, poor senior management team.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for less than a year
pros_description:
- Great company to work for to obtain sufficient consumer insights and experiences to the commercial market.

- Great company that upholds its company values (Transparency, Respect, Integrity, Patient Focus) to a high standard which is align to what every employee would want and expect out of its employers.

- Work life balance is achievable as well as top management globally has made effective the flexible option of working from home (provided with managers approval and your current job scope).
cons_description:
- Senior management team locally does not share the same vision as the global company values.

- Senior leaders does not practice coaching and mentoring. They will only give a beautiful speech about 'Your career is in your own hands. Come to us for advice and we will help you grow'. However, that does not translate into reality when subordinates actually ask for guidance and are often brushed off (All talk but no walk).

- Senior management (most) has the mentality to 'throw you to the deep end of the ocean'. If you manage to swim back ashore, you are a talent. If you drown, you are incompetent and will be looked down upon'.

- The political game is high on red alert where top level management brings the political game down to lower subordinate levels to stir up dissatisfaction and unhealthy competition.

- Slow/no career progression even though you are a strong candidate (unless you are able to speak the same language as certain senior managers then you will progress at the speed of light).

- Promotion of talent is often not in the books. It is often hired externally to fill up the ranks causing the company to lose its originality.

- Senior management does not practice transparency; which does not come as a surprise as most company does not disclose PnC information. However, shouldn't the company adhere to the company value of Transparency and Respect to disclose certain information where internal staffs are suppose to be made aware of than finding out the very last minute? (food for thought).

- Overwhelming amount of administrative work and refusal to hire additional headcount to enable dedicate employees to focus on their job scope.

- Turnover rate of employees is extremely high.

- Some senior managers look too high upon themselves and are plain ignorant.

-HR does not act in the best interest of its employees.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description:
Higher base pay to compensate for capped bonus. Company car. 
Excellent health insurance. 
Strong vaccines portfolio and growing.
Competitive contract offers for physicians clinics and health systems. 
Global impact of GSK Vaccines is huge. Here is where you see GSK's values shine.
cons_description:
Bureaucratic. 
GSK takes a now obsolete top down approach to leadership. Field reps are told their opinions matter and plenty of meetings focus on listening to field reps but things do not come to fruition in leadership's actions.
Way too many conference calls and desk work. Because I want to do well in whatever setting I am in, this lead to working evenings/weekends regularly. 
Priority after priority... there are too many and they're ever changing. 
Bonuses are based on quality (subjective) rather than quantity. This can be good if you drink the GSK Kool-aid, but most find it frustrating. 
Logging calls is extremely cumbersome because of an outdated system. 
GSK has a way of overcomplicating things.

author_title: Current Employee - Process Improvement, Performance & Risk Management
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for less than a year
pros_description:
an excellent place to work with an excellent mission - to provide the best new vaccines to as many people as possible at the most reasonable prices possible. GSK is the polar opposite of Martin Shkreli-type pharma in every conceivable way. 
I came to GSK as my first for-profit job after a career in non-profit humanitarian work, drawn by the potential for helping their new vaccine pipeline save far more lives than my career in humanitarian work was able to achieve. I was very suspicious of what working for GSK would be like, but have been pleasantly surprised in every way. In some ways, it is even more of a positive, nurturing, 'do-gooder' environment with people even more committed to making the world better than most of the NGOs for which i had previously worked.

Leadership on site is open and accessible and committed to doing good work in the world and maintaining a really positive work environment.

the new R&D center is in an innovative and newly renovated complex in Rockville, and they make open space working an excellent experience from the very top to the very bottom. No one has an office and people are incredibly friendly and make the open space a real pleasure. I used to have a really nice corner office suite downtown and I like this new situation far more than that.
cons_description: It is still part of a big multinational company, and while even the CEO is fully committed to the good work and to transparency, integrity, respect, and patient-focus, it still comes with a slow and somewhat dysfunctional corporate bureaucracy. It can take days to get a computer, weeks to get access to critical systems, and months to become fully productive because of this, but at least upper management is aware of these problems and trying to fix it (but turning a ship this size takes a long time, even for the captain).

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Great company, benefits, tuition reimbursement, great upper management. The company is amazing and has wonderful values and gives their employees incredible perks.
cons_description: Micromanaged, lack of communication and respect, pushback from direct management when trying to apply for internal roles. The management of Inside Sales is awful. You are treated as if you are a child and while the rest of the departments enjoy work from home days, you are stuck at the office because direct management wants to monitor your every move. (Even though they record every single call) it is required that you record every call in 3 different systems and treat employees as if they are incompetent. The accounts the inside reps are given are absolutely terrible and most of the time you are just wishing you had something to do that way you are not reprimanded. The company is great but do not go into this department, if you are looking for a way to get your foot in the door, I suggest the cafeteria. Anything is better than this I have wasted 2 years of my life and now I'm looking to go to another company after too much pushback.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Employer that tries to do the right thing as a whole. A lot of guidelines and documentation as in place to guide the ways of workings. Can be fun and energetic at times.
cons_description:
Depending on which department you could have very different work life balance. Bureaucratic and mostly led by UK leads.

In theory, GSK is supposed to be an inclusive culture. But in Malaysia, it's not practised. Hiring managers still hire based on gender, marriage status etc. 
Not walking the talk - local HR need to bridge GSK values closer to change local practices. Otherwise it's really just hypocrisy.

Observed a rather unjust treatment of a recent Finance outsourcing in which the employees were not offered any choice of retrenchment package but rather 'forced' to accept placements at outsourcing company. Legal loopholes perhaps?

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Strong products with exciting R&D potential
cons_description: Leadership which has failed to respond effectively to market challenges.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Pharma will always be lucrative as long as they keep the development pipeline full of assets that can go onto successful trials, and there lies the Achilles heel of the industry. That and CEO issues and law suits.
cons_description: GSK slaughtered its R&D presence in NC over a decade. Once a predominate tenant in the Research Park area, GSK left its employees with pro-rated severances and the area with shells of empty buildings for off-shored and contracted work. One excuse actually given in 2014, 'real-estate was cheaper in Philly.'

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years

cons_description: None, it a really great company to work for if you are selling to work and good at what you do. Company relocated to another state.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Intent to seek new opportunities for growing the business.  Promotion options seem to be available.
cons_description: No concerted way of making well informed decisions.  Mistrust of analytic solutions.  Very near term focused; very risk averse.  Promotions based on relationships vs skills or merit.  Very UK centric.  Most of the progressive thinkers in R&D have left due to frustration.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Great benefits and potential for growth is there if you play the 'go-for' role. Sr. Leadership is all over the open environment setting, thus enhancing visibility for those that are proactive, ambitious and loud. Management is very hands off, but results-target oriented.
cons_description: Company is undergoing organizational right-sizing and re-structuring itself for a potential spin off from mother group. Too much hierarchy and central-shared functions makes it feel a bit stagnant and sloppy in checking priority to support critical process. Mentoring and coaching is almost null, you trace your own way.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for less than a year
pros_description: I enjoyed my team/colleagues, office building, WFH policy
cons_description:
Poor management, no transparency, lack of respect for employees, lack of communication.

Management creates barriers to success rather than lead us to success.  When hired, employees are promised work-life balance, high potential for mobility, managerial support and motivation.  As a telesales rep, I've heard horror stories from colleagues about management, the company itself.  Management has a large say in whether or not you can apply for a specific job creating a sense of feeling trapped, no freedom.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: I believe the organization has potential to continue to be an industry leader. I am proud that GSK has been recognized as an organization making a significant impact on global health.
cons_description: Disappointed with management's resistance to accept change. Management appears to perpetuate a culture that does not motivate its employees. New ideas are often dismissed with the old-fashioned rationale that, 'this is the way we have always done it,' quip. Very little growth/development potential. After a year of trying to make a contribution to improve processes, I have realized that I do not fit into the GSK culture. A real shame since I had previously worked at GSK for ten years, and only returned last year with great hopes for opportunities with the Novartis integration. Looking to move on now.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description:
Generally good benefits, 401K, Pension, paid time off, competitive pay.  Most people are fun to work with.  People who care about patients' health and finding cures.

Depending on your manager, one may exercise flexible work hours (i.e. work from home).
cons_description:
Financially driven company.  They claim 'patients first', but it's clearly Shareholders first, patients second, employees last.  All the core services, especially IT, is always targeted for reductions.  Then they take the work load and spread it across those who remain.

Very little work-life balance.  Told 'not to work so hard', but then criticized for not delivering on time.  If you put in the hours to deliver successfully and on time, told you have done a good job, but then criticized that you put too many hours/have time management issues.  Damned if you do, damned if you don't.

IT leadership is thankless.  It's not about what what accomplishments you had, it about what you can do for me now.

There is no development path.  They continue to come up with new schemes to make you think you have a chance like develop yourself and 'getting out of your comfort zone', but the reality is no one will spend the time to give you a role that is out of your zone because it's more work for them.

They continue to move jobs in the US and some UK to lower cost countries (Poland, Costa Rica, Malaysia).  They are downgrading positions from Director to Manager.  They are posting new 'Manager level' positions at a lower band so they don't have to provide higher bonus % and shares of stock, yet it's the same responsibility as the Manager band that does receive those incentives.  Very shady practices.  All about the bottomline and not quality of work.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description:
Flexible schedule 
Job has recognition for being a tough industry to break into.
Help people with meds.
Has Internet, phone, and iPad paid for.
Pay is great.
cons_description:
Field sales is awful, you are graded on a bell curve for the most part some are targeted to be lower than others.
You aren't paid on sales, you are paid on ride alongs that aren't consistent with grading metrics across the board.
Super toxic culture.
District managers check boxes for ride alongs.
They base things on sales while maintaining they don't.
It's so fake here.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Excellent benefits and salary.  Pleasant work environment at the corporate offices.  Flexibility and work/life balance.  Generous time off  and plenty of fringe benefits available to employees that were not company related: i.e. - movie discounts, vacation travel assistance, many products offered at a discount.
cons_description: The only real con at the time of my employment was that there was a lot of transition.  Top leadership had changed and departments were tasked to make drastic cuts immediately.  Downstream effects were not considered.  This may be one of the reasons why top leadership is changing again.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Three weeks vacation to start, ok health benefits, decent 401k matching program.  Very few buildings are connected so you get to spend some time outdoors.
cons_description: All of the political job shuffling and promoting of a small family-owned company, along with all of the corporate garbage from a large company.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Stiefel was a great place to work until GSK came along.  Paid well.  Good bonuses and options.  Benefits were top notch
cons_description: The GSK philosophy is one that keeps its employees on edge about the future.  Every year there were additional layoffs.  Major losses of key personnel without consideration to their individual value to the business.

summary: Better than some, not as good as others
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: One of the biggest pros is flexibility, dependent upon your business unit.  Also most of the people you work with are friendly and helpful.  Pay is good - as long as you aren't comparing it to other Pharma's.  As GSK is a UK company, we do get the week between Christmas and New Year's as shutdown.  The appointment of internal candidate, Emma Walmsley as CEO, appears to be a positive step for GSK's future.
cons_description: Once an admin - always an admin.  There is very little room for growth, and although the company has a lot of development options, it does not trickle down to the support staff.  Promises are made that managers will help you find more challenging roles, however they move on before anything happens.  The company line is Work/Life Balance, however in the R&D environment many people cannot use their vacation days because of work requirements or external requirements (ex. FDA meetings).  Many people lose their vacation days due to this, and no rollover or payout is allowed.  As much as we are told we are valued, with the sale of the Oncology Business Unit, everyone has realized that we are only numbers with a dollar amount associated with our head.  That is not how you value an employee.

The clients whom I supported were also top-notch scientists who were glad to have our help. Great benefits, pay was very good, local management/team leads were very good and always had team personnel's best interests at heart.
cons_description: Upper (corporate) management seemed to change direction too often. It seemed as if the moment we were comfortable performing work with certain tools, processes and infrastructure in place, senior management would change things up. Also, numerous reorganizations cost a lot of people their jobs.

Promotion may tend to be based on networking rather than performance, potential and true career planning. Training programs are mostly internal, with little external benchmarking.

summary: Good global company with lots of lateral growth opportunities
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than a year
pros_description: World class environment within the Pharmaceutical industry.  Lots of growth opportunities for lateral movement.  Work life balance good.  Working from home a bonus depending on manager.  Great benefits and bonus program.  Shutdown over the holidays a plus.  Competitive salary based on role title.  Solid work environment, mostly up on current technology, and good technical infrastructure.  Lots of opportunities to take on new work and projects.
cons_description: Simplification of roles and movement to low cost resources in other countries (i.e. Poland, India) has become the norm.  Lack of opportunity for advancement.  Unrealistic yearly objectives based on continually changing priorities, and lack of resources, limit ability to attain better than average annual reviews for better pay and advancement.  Short life span for employees that have been with the company over 10 years even though they have deep subject matter expertise.

summary: Not what it used to be

pros_description: Vacation time is good.  You will start with about five weeks total between vacation time and personal days at the lowest level.
cons_description: High turnover.  New hires are in and out.  Long time employees are counting the days to retirement.  The company used to be a great place to work and valued it's employees.  Now it's all about the bottom line.  Vacation time has been reduced, health benefits are not as good, many former benefits and policies that employees loved are no longer offered: extended vacation days, summer hours, working from home flexibility, on-site banking.
