-No onsite HR and IT support. New hires sometimes don't get their computers or phones until after a few months. 
-Unrealistic manufacturing timeline set by people who never have to work the weekends
-Aging facilities and infrastructure that are always being talked about but never addressed.
-Lots of useless initiatives and mandatory trainings that add little value to people to work
-Exhausted and demoralized workforce.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for less than a year
pros_description: Good people that are motivated. Interesting work. Good benefits and compensation. A lot of experienced professionals to learn from as well.
cons_description: Depending on role, travel can be a bit much. Other than that, there are no real other cons to the place.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Very involved with the community, produces both every day over the counter drugs and products as well as vaccines. Great employee benefits.
cons_description: Only wished I could have gotten hired on full time. They have a tendency to hire contact or temporary workers at a much cheaper cost to them and work is sometimes only guaranteed on a day to day basis

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: The people I worked with care about the patient more than what I would consider normal. There was an emphasis on simplicity and efficiency that created standardization that helped keep people focused on their tasks. Emphasis on knowledge improved confidence in sales force.
cons_description: Deliver more in less time was always being asked of every employee. The Patient First Compensation platform solely looked on areas of improvement and was not empowering to employees. Adopted a psychometric employee performance measurement that demotivated employees. Employees were only told their faults. Psychometrics being designed toward survival of the fittest. Learning was a challenge because employees could not review there assessments to improve in specific knowledge they didn't do as well. This left my representatives feeling like the company was not being transparent when transparency was one of the four value pillars.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: THE BEST: facilities, technology, environment, colleagues, industry, and mission
cons_description: Occasionally get a less progressive/motivated by fear manager, but overall mgmt is great!

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Some good people, decent pay, has potential if leadership improves.  Nice building with onsite dining.  Ample parking.  Good location.  Good benefits in some areas.
cons_description: Poor leadership, from the top down.  Continual restructure that disrupted continuity and employee morale.  Unethical business practices.  Very bureaucratic, way too many layers just to get simple things done.

author_title: Current Employee - Executive Pharmaceuticals Sales Representative
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: In this day and age, thankful to have a job with decent benefits. Decent medicines to sell and love the freedom the job offers.
cons_description: Unfortunately, upper management has given the district managers 100% of the power to rate the representatives. Managers control our ratings, pay raises and potential for bonuses.  When you have a tyrannical, control freak manager, the job is unbearable.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Compensation package is good. Product pipeline is robust. Patient-focused culture is above industry standard. Talented sales people in specialty divisions
cons_description: Management takes a reactive versus proactive approach to problem solving. Breadth of experience is valued more than depth of experience. Many mid-level leaders though successful in previous roles are unsuited or unprepared for their current roles.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: Friendly work environment, Health and safety.
cons_description: More work tension, Keep pushing

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Come with a good balance on work/life and set valuable standards for that. There may be great opportunities for some areas, and less for others
cons_description: The senior management is quite chaotic, and company strategy is not clearer

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Excellent overall culture of looking for opportunities to learn.
cons_description: Middle management is mostly clueless.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great benefits and working conditions
cons_description: Really rigid structure, is kind of dificult to grow inside.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great company with a strong history in Pharma. Offers great development options for those who actively seek them out.
cons_description: Despite the strong development focus for employees there is a logjam of high performers who are waiting for higher level roles to be available. The lack of these higher level roles inadvertently leads to some people having to leave to pursue career ambitions.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great benefits and salary. Great place for learning as too many opportunities to work across boundaries (legal, finance, procurement, commercial)
cons_description: Morale is very low due to continuous re organization processes. Due to this, employees are getting more responsibility in all areas (Tactical / Operational / Strategic) and people get over burnt

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: It was a good company. Had a good structure. Excellent leadership team.
cons_description:
My workplace senior was harassing me. Despite repeated speak ups of the various forms of harassment, he was promoted. On the other hand, my annual review was spoiled by that person - my annual increment and bonus and dreams of a good future within the organisation were thus destroyed. 

The person who was harassing me now holds a director level role. He was great with his work, for sure. But the company doesn't care if a good worker is terrible with his team. Or whether he engages in lobbying by hiring people from within his community.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Values are focused on Patient; there is high respect for people and people work with integrity and transparency
cons_description: Medical benefit to dependents doesnt cover out-patient

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Very stable company. 
Work environment is fine, though in the latest years and due to fail in generating expected finantial results the pressure as increased a little.
cons_description: Difficult to make a career at a local level in overseas branches. As the company is not growing there is a lack of opportunities for promotion in a LOC as there is no much turn over and no new positions are generated

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Good work environment and excellent benefit package
cons_description: Bad life / work balance

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Good people to work with.
cons_description: High turnover rate, market research is not accurate in terms of compensation.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: 	Provide project management support on behalf of the Business for process improvement, reporting and MDM initiatives from implementation through testing efforts
cons_description: Growth MIn for Contract People

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: 	Provide project management support on behalf of the Business for process improvement, reporting and MDM initiatives from implementation through testing efforts
cons_description: Growth MIn for Contract People

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Work from home.  Great benefits and culture.
cons_description: Can be a bit of disconnect between home office and field employees.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 5 years
pros_description: Great portfolio of category leading brands
cons_description: Large matrix organization with Global oversight

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Great benefits, great pay, many opportunities
cons_description: Merger with Novartis shut down Pittsburgh site.  Not sure why in this day and age you have to have everyone in the same location.  Co short sighted on knowledge loss due to site closure.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Emphasizing focusing on patients and meaningful goals for employees' every day efforts; developing employees and talents' career advancement through various programs.
cons_description: Too complex system in processing some decision making or logistics, especially when it's at the cross function or cross division levels, which reduces work efficiency.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Excellent consumer focus and Job Satisfaction
cons_description: Lots of Documentation and Silo Administration

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great people great value system
cons_description: Inertia conservative too lean in markets

summary: Toxic Culture. Good place to start. But get out quickly.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good industry. Decent Training.
cons_description: It is Glaxo. The CIA has crippled this company.

summary: looking actively for a job change
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: it gives a good working environment
cons_description: working in general division and want to change to a speciality segment

summary: Business Service Centre (Malaysia - Petaling Jaya) 'Walks The Talk'
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description:
- People oriented
- Great, energetic working environment, office has a 'buzz' of energy which is infectious
- Absolute focus on cultivating a culture of safety, openness, honesty and integrity
- Leadership ethos that a working environment can equally be fun as well as professional, productive/effective.
- Key Drivers -  'Leadership Capability', 'Talent Management', 'Service Performance' & 'Customer Service'.
- On the whole 'walks the talk'
cons_description:
- Its' not all rosy, there are without doubt challenges, inconsistency in leadership capabilities throughout the teams & of course room for improvement
 - Long working hours
 - Compensation doesn't appear to move with the market
 - Too much change - change fatigue is very evident throughout the centre although this is improving
 - Consistently changing strategy driven by head office, which seems to be at odds with the centre's values & original ambitions. The only constant is change!
 - US/UK Senior Leadership Perception (not data driven) of limited talent & capabilities.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: History of industry leader
cons_description: Downsizing yearly ; poor outlook

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Salary, atmosphere, stable job
cons_description: lack of trainings and certificates, crowded office

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 10 years
pros_description: Some good people still work there, despite brutal cutbacks every year.  Compensation is still competitive, but career growth potential is non-existent.
cons_description: Company is slow to respond to changing market.  Once in the top 2-3 pharmas worldwide, it is no longer a leader after a string of bad leaders and embarrassing scandals.  More concerned about protecting itself from litigation than actual growth and innovation.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Benefits and salary are still somewhat good.  Newly refreshed facility at 5 Moore Drive.  Parking was pretty good most days.
cons_description: Environment in RTP was a bit rough with the ongoing layoffs and people moving up to Pennsylvania.  Navigating infrastructure and support services was very complicated.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description:
Excellent work environment
Great work benefits
Opportunity for growth
cons_description:
Working Continental shift
Not great raises company wide

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: work life balance is fantastic.
cons_description: some lifers who really need to be let go.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description:
-Glaxo production syatem
- Lead projects
- Drive perfoermance of VS
cons_description:
- Sometimes No team work
-High Ego

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Friendly environment. Working  in the IT department, you get some challenging projects to work on. Also get an opportunity to learn new software and technologies. Overall good experience
cons_description: Like any big corporate, everything takes time. Lot of processes defined so even simple things like getting access to a file share could take weeks.

author_title: Current Employee - Senior Pharmaceuticals Sales Representative
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: Great reputation with good products and pipeline. Great scientific and sales training. Good managers with best intentions on mind. Great benefits .
cons_description: Changes happen all the time. Hard to get promoted because they constantly change the target. Not paid on performance so there's no incentive to sell. Bonus capped.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Friendly and knowledgeable staff.  Pay is pretty good.
cons_description: Rarely convert contractors to permanent employees

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Best in class products for reps to carry
cons_description: Sometimes stifling environment. heavy competition from generics.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: I enjoyed working at GSK mostly because of the positive atmosphere, good organisation and the great manager who was leading my team. CEO was also great.
cons_description: Bad work-life balance. Receiving emails after ending working time. Too many reports which couldn't be accomplished during the week and then having them done during the weekend.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description:
Great people.
Central purpose to develop medicines that help people live longer, better, healthier lives.
Good benefits.
cons_description: Downsizing and moving R&D diverting from important core business function.

summary: Local senior leadership here in Puerto Rico lacks focus, employees feel unappreciated and unheard.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: GSK has a very successful, experienced, hardworking sales force and in office support staff. The all the new products are on track as expected. Great local Inventive collaboration.
cons_description:
Senior leadership does not listen to concerns and likes only to hear that all is well while the house is burning. Some senior leaders are protected at all cost after serious issues and concerns have been brought up against them. 
Very respected, lower level Managers have left our company for these reasons in the last 6 months.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 10 years
pros_description:
very well established and professional company with a wide range of opportunities and benefits.
GSK is known abroad in the U.K. as well as the U.S.
cons_description: Management can be a little aloof at times. They seem to try but getting to know your employees a little better would go along way.

author_title: Current Employee - CARICAM Finance Business Partner Head and Controller
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Social Responsibility and genuine willing to support others
cons_description: Lack of processes and operational discipline

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Great culture, employee and consumer focused! Pays well combined with very practical perks! Provides a conducive environment that supports work life balance - runs a number of CSR events too.
cons_description: Matrix org and therefore can get bureaucratic at times, like any other big boy in the industry. Large set up can sometimes slow things down!

pros_description:
Environment

Professional growth and development

Uncertainty with leadership

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for less than a year
pros_description: Friendly environement, excellent product and pipeline. Very scientific engagement with physicians. Good employee benefits
cons_description: new ways of work are very good but the employee incentive is missing which may lead to demotivation for some.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Worklife balance good, onsite gym.
cons_description: Transition from Novartis has been challenging.  Very different culture, not sure if the local CEO is that interested in the transitioned products.

management reactive to needs of sales professionals
generous package especially healthcare

no sales goals
low salaries
management not standardized

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Values based decision making... Trying to promote diversity... Good benefits but poor base pay...
cons_description: Old timers occupy senior management positions. Therefore no room for growth for middle managers. Also, too many white women at the top in the name of diversity...

summary: Great opportunities, massive amount of change
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Experiences available, company mission, salary and benefits, peers and teams at company, 'doing good' by supplying leading edge medicines, good bonus scheme and share scheme once at the right level. There are great people throughout the company and they make it fun and interesting to come to work everyday
cons_description: Amount of change, constant change, targets always moving, poor performing people and business units allowed to continue on for too long, big company arrogance

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 3 years
pros_description: Great comapny with long heritage . Selection of products are outsatnding . Worklife balace is good .Self  learning opputunity is high . Collegues are friendly and very cordinative in nature .
cons_description: Limited trainings . Flat organogram . Little slow in todays fast pace consumer goods marketing world . sometime procrastiration kills good ideas . Limited numberof brand and solutions for the consumer .

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: GSK Consume Healthcare is a company that pays well in comparison with other consumer companies and well even within the Pharma Industry.
cons_description: Not supportive of learning so I would advice junior or just graduated to search another option. This is a company to capitalize learnings.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Excellent work life balance, amazing individuals in all the departments.
cons_description: I joined at a time when they let go of almost half of the staff at the Parsippany office.

summary: A company striving to be a great place to work!
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: The joint venture with Novartis OTC has made it the fastest growing consumer healthcare company. The culture is changing for the better and it is a good time to join the business.
cons_description: Many long-timers working in the company still think and work in the traditional way and try to pull the pace back. Decision making is slow and hierarchical.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good benefits, career advancement opportunities
cons_description: too much restructuring over the last few years which disrupts customer relationships.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good benefits, career advancement opportunities
cons_description: too much restructuring over the last few years which disrupts customer relationships.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Love working with the values at heart.
Working with people of different cultures but so dynamique.
cons_description: Rigorous recruitment process. But still good.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: great place to work and development.
cons_description: did not make too much profit these years.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than a year
pros_description: Good work life balance. Work culture  not very hectic.  Good company to work in if you are looking for a stable job.
cons_description: Salary increment low.Not much progress in terms of career. More like a government organization in terms of hierarchy

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Has a stable  pipeline with over half dozen new pharmaceuticals launched in past couple years. Great people to work for.
cons_description: Since 2012, GSK entered into a corporate integrity agreement with Office of Inspector General. This agreement made it mandatory that GSK would no longer provide incentive compensation. Sales reps are not recognized and compensated for growing revenue.

summary: Excellent systems and processes, slightly conservative
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than a year
pros_description: Professionally, this organization follows some of the best practices both in terms of working and employee care. It is one of the companies one may think of retiring from.
cons_description: Changes take a bit of time, and things may be frustratingly slow. It has a bit of catch up to do in terms of technology adoption. But the conservative methods have worked for the company so far, hence cannot really complain.

summary: Going through a lot of change
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: friendly team members, flexible schedule, good pay
cons_description: confusion with upper management, redundant meetings, little value of work

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 5 years
pros_description: Great benefits and value personal life
cons_description: Not too many cons that other company's have.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Pay, bonus and benefits really good. 3 weeks vacation to start, takes 10 years to get 4 weeks.
cons_description: Lots of hoops to jump through to get things done. Lots of 'silos'

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Pay is reasonable and life style is good
cons_description: Instability and poor management skills

summary: GSK best company to work for
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Family oriented.  Good Management.
cons_description: There is nothing bad about this company.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: GSK is a company with a motivating mission to help people do more, feel better, and live longer.  They pay quite well and provide outstanding benefits.  Flexible hours to help work life balance.  For the last 15 years I had nine, yes, nine weeks of paid vacation!  Plus LTI shares of stock for excellent performance.  Benifit of working for a British firm.
cons_description: Extremely demanding workload, with staff getting less and less.  Strategy shifts depending on the leader which makes for a very difficult to achieve objectives.    Lots of staff turnover recently.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description:
The people are committed / very loyal 
The culture is heading in the right direction  = Great  collaboration with Senior staff
Excellent First line leaders
Benefits are great 
Good work/ life balance
cons_description:
Downsizing - major consolidation 
Not much to add for this category 
Hoping for a  robust pipeline

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Brilliant organization which provides Employees with opportunity to grow and develop career.  Outstanding products and R&D program.  Excellent compensation, benefits, and incentive package.  Highly ethical.
cons_description: GSK is undergoing structural change.

summary: Making the 'Do More, Feel Better, Live Longer' purpose actually work!
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Inspiring company vision and purpose, strong brands, and great heritage make GSK an attractive employer to look at. With an ageing global population, and governments off-loading healthcare responsibilities across the board, consumer healthcare is also a growth sector for the future. There is a lot of promise in the GSK portfolio and plans.
cons_description: It has been called a $6billion startup ...and it is just that in many respects. Despite a storied past, the company suffers from archaic systems and processes, and a silo-ed approach to solutions. Despite the best of intentions, several strategic initiatives have some to nought due to inadequate attention to detail and complexity in execution. Top driven culture still rules the roost, with the recent Novartis merger adding some further cultural complications.

summary: Not as great as it use to be...
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great pay and benefits. Operators are great to work with.
cons_description: Have recently changed to GSK Consumer Health so there are many changes happening. Unfortunately, there is a mass amount of politics happening. Many managers and supervisors are lying to the workers in which they oversee.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good pension plan, generous 401k match and stock ownership grant, generous RSU amount,
cons_description: low-to-average base salary, low annual increase

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Solid company, Good overall foundation
cons_description: Do more with less, need balance of talent.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 8 years
pros_description: Great training program. Family oriented. Good product.
cons_description: Stressful work. Constant reorganisation. Heavy workload. Unclear focus. Limited carrier advancement.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: great people, job flexibility, excellent benefits, good advancement opportunities for those willing to move/relocate or try new things
cons_description: culture is changing because of lack of growth, company is shrinking, major products are soon going off patent, lack of clear direction and inspiration in the US, slow decision making, highly political decision making

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: good comany to work for in generak
cons_description: a lot of work to do in general

summary: Poor Management, people pretend to do work but nothing is done
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Great company and has great values. Regional and overseas teams have significant level of expertise.
cons_description: GSK Sydney is a poor reflection of GSK; horrible management (senior) and very poor people managers. Employees who have been in the company for a long time have somehow made it to the top and now do nothing. Horrible culture and acceptance to change. Poor performers are shifted around the company rather than asked to leave.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: GSK is a world famous and multinational company. Strong consumer health brand in the world and the brand image is mostly good.
cons_description: Entire supply chain is not very efficient. Supply hub is not supportive to TW supply chain. Political issues are quite normal here.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good work life balance, good employees benefits
cons_description: Bad increment, less bonus, opportunities not good

author_title: Current Employee - National Rural Activation Manager
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for less than a year
pros_description:
Employee friendly environment.
Flexible work hours.
Compliance is at the core of all processes.
Opportunity to explore various roles and locations
cons_description: Slightly lagging in terms of technology

summary: Coworkers are great... management not so...
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description:
	Great staff
	Global Company, 
	good salary package but less than in the past and small negotiation possibilities,
	great opportunities and projects if you’re supported, 
	contribution to eradicate diseases (such as Tetanus, diphtheria, meningitis, measles, hepatitis, ….)
cons_description:
	High change management levels due to poor vision 
	Not enough patient focused (to inaccessible & GSK is too big)
	Top management has a poor charisma radiance and no crystal clear direction.
	Lack of transparency at some management levels who were quite secretive about future plans for the company
	Too many rules and it became to administrative ( work fictive 3 hours and have 4 hours of paperwork & negotiations)

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: great people, navy yard is a really nice environment to work and the new building brings a lot of excitement and energy.
cons_description: Large company cultures can be difficult to get things accomplished due to many layers of bureaucracy. Just a tradeoff between large and small organizations.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Perks, 401k, stocks etc are great benefits. 7 hr workday for US and vacation is great also.
cons_description: Benefits have been decreasing over the year but overall good company to work for.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
There is a lot to learn 
A lot of ingoing projects
cons_description: very bad management and unqualified mangers

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Management did not micromanage. Launched several new products in short period of time. Company did a great job of getting competitive insurance coverage
cons_description: Rx reporting system was extremely inaccurate.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Salary is better than some.
cons_description:
GSK is not currently competitive with other pharm companies concerning 401K match.  Although you would think it would be easy to move around, it's challenging.  The moral at this time (between downsizing and restructuring) things seem a bit unsettling; however, perhaps it will improve with the announcement of new CEO.
We are in open space which I do not think is ideal for productive work.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than a year
pros_description: Pays well, nice working facilities, feels good working for a company that produces quality medicines and products
cons_description: Canada is operated as a 'satellite' office, with little decision making happening here.  Strategy is handled globally, and adopted by local markets.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great pay, great benefits, and the team I worked with was the best.

summary: GSK Suffers from Big Pharma shrinking
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: The company has a great working environment.  They are very much on the cutting edge as far as sales, marketing and business development.  In addition they work with many of the  large nationally known vendors and agencies, which creates a great opportunity for networking.  The company is also very pro employee development.  They have an extensive training and educational library in addition to conducting several off site learning programs per year.
cons_description: The company is in a continued state of downsizing due to generic erosion of blockbuster products and very limited new assets in development.  Getting promoted within the company has become increasingly difficult, in large part because they normally implement a mid year hiring freeze if they are not on track to achieve year end budget objectives.  That creates a considerable backlog of key talent within the organization looking to identify their next career opportunity.  When growth opportunities do become available, they are very often politically charged because there is so much talent looking to move and so few opportunities available for consideration.  For that reason, GSK has seen a considerable erosion of key talent leaving the organization to pursue opportunities outside the company.

cons_description: Market conditions have not been good for pharma, so it's been 15+ years of tight budgets, doing more with (even) less, etc. Overall vision and direction of the company seem sound, but I wouldn't recommend taking a position at GSK unless you're confident of being able to move on to other things if your role is eliminated.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Close to home and I enjoy my peer co-workers.  Salary average.  Bonus disappointing.
cons_description: I knew GSK as a Pharmaceutical Sales company from my years in the field selling pharmaceutical products.  Never in a million years would I think that working for this organization would be so dysfunctional!  I admit that going from a field based position to working in a manufacturing environment would require an adjustment.  But three years later I can tell you that this organization does NOT live by its 'Values'.  It is a 'Boys-club' and the majority of Upper management 'leads' through bullying and intimidation.  Communication is conducted via a Top-down driven, command and control, hierarchical structure.  In today's business world never in a million years would I think that this type of organization would still exist. No room for advancement.  Not even a courtesy interview when applying for internal positions.  In fact I have proof that in one case the hiring manager never even received my resume / application.

Lots of talented, hard-working people, striving to continuously improve what is already a world-class operation.  The IT organization runs with high level of efficiency and very high-level of compliance.
cons_description: Lack of leadership, cronyism and weak management in key positions resulted in the loss of public trust, missed business opportunities and forced down-sizing.  The company has a much reduced R&D capacity as they now focus only on research with the highest profit potential.

cons_description: Long history of hiring from within so when external management candidates hired, internal employees could be resistant (at least in field). Low morale primarily due to the PATIENT FIRST sales compensation and performance measurement program - created a type of internal sabotage/resistance. Witnessed hostile and dysfunctional work environments (within field sales) as a result. Ongoing charges of executive bribery charges (I.e. China) make their touted values fairly meaningless statements.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: The benefits are good. Open office space. Good employees on the most part. Good location. Chance for global relocation (whether you want it or not).
cons_description: Company has lost its direction, and is no longer an innovator, except in cost cutting and reorganization.  Senior Management's job appears to be managing-up to the next level of management in order to position themselves for the next reorganization.  Recent leadership change in R&D more likely to lead to even more of the same.

summary: A great school but a Toxic Working Culture

summary: From halcyon days to hellish days
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Used to be a great company before patent expirations. Pay is still excellent and benefits are good but that's about all it has going for it any longer.
cons_description: Fear and despair define the corporate culture, even within upper management. Employees aren't truly valued and upward mobility is based solely on whom you know instead of what you can do.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Research and development pharmaceutical company. Abundant pipeline with a diversified portfolio across multiple therapeutic areas.  Top 5 pharmaceutical company in the world in terms of size.
cons_description: Significant restructuring is omnipresent.  There have been patent losses In recent years and this trend will continue for years to come.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: good work and life balance, short commute, nice office area, nice pay
cons_description: no cons to think of as I know, others may have different opinion

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description:
-There is a lot to learn, you are always busy.
- products are always changing so you get a lot of exposure and experience very quickly
-very good benefits, medical, dental, vision, 401k, pension plan
cons_description:
- management has skewed priorities, none of which are the employees
- compensation is roughly 20% less than competitors in the area
- attempts to improve existing systems creates more issues
- site has been purging talent so most operators are inexperienced, a lot of valuable time spent holding hands
- expectations for BMAs ever changing and vague
- openly regard employees as replaceable, disposable 
- growth and developement opportunities are often promised and rarely delivered

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Respectful culture, opportunity to move between departments, science focused R&D, good early to mid-stage pipeline, new products offsetting old product sale decline. Good work life balance (7 hour work days and Christmas to New Year's Day shutdown).
cons_description: Lots of internal and fragmented processes slow things down. IT systems generations behind competition. Compensation not competitive among rivals. Many old timers resist changes in processes.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Regular working hour
Open to ideas for improvement
cons_description:
Staff seem fearful in the presence of management and engineers.
Low job security.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: The company provides good benefits and a competitive salary.  There are significant in-house resources available for personal and technical development.
cons_description: Overburdened and top-heavy structure which led to 'oversight' that crippled the ability to get anything done.  The company promotes those that play politics, even if they are technically inept.  The company suffers from cumbersome internal review processes in a market that demands a more agile and adaptable approach.  This process results in a significant amount of work that does not help advance programs and projects, further increasing an already heavy workload that makes having a healthy work/life balance impossible.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Excellent benefits and compensation
cons_description: Glorified ups drivers, sample sig all day.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Strong values oriented culture. very collaborative open office working spaces
cons_description: Less that ideal level of transparency with employees

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Excellent Salary and Benefits; Excellent Work Environment; Excellent Fitness & Cafeteria facilities, above average vacation policy
cons_description: Questionable Culture, if one at all; Periodically unstable work environment; Poor work life balance; Very Political in Nature

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: New site in Rockville, MD will be in growth mode in 2016. If you live or are willing to move to the area, there may be a good number of opportunities.
cons_description: Vaccines unit is in flux due to the recent merger / integration with Novartis Vaccines. It may take a few years until the vaccine organization is fully operating as one.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Highly-educated, professional staff. Friendly and collaborative work environment. More than adequate training in both job and soft skills
cons_description: Recent JV with Novartis Consumer Healthcare leaves long-term success of company uncertain. New organizational structure even flatter than before, so room for advancement tight.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Great benefits, great people, meeting the challenges in the pharma industry head on, but this requires radical changes, which they're going through now. High integrity company in my estimation, invests a lot in its people for the most part. Work hard and you will be rewarded. I must say, having been let go after several years, they took VERY good care of me on the way out!
cons_description: Many cutbacks and/or reallocation of staff had been difficult, but the 'transformation' is necessary to stay competitive in today's environment. Tough to stay motivated. Politics and cultural differences abound, you do need to play the game and know who the power players are. Also, need stay on top of the trends, Six Sigma, Lean, ADP, whatever is being presented as skill to get you to the top, otherwise, you get left behind.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Many opportunities for advancement if you are mobile and want to do a stint in the Head Office. Excellent Benefit package.
cons_description: Large company, with many constraints, both internal and external, therefore slow to change.  Little job security because of the volatility in the marketplace.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good benefits: holidsys, medical insurance, bonus
cons_description: No downside I can think of for now.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: Great Benefits Great Company Values
cons_description: Soon to close @ PR

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great supervisors and opportunities for development
cons_description: Very unstable organization over the past few years as they prepare ADVAIR Generic.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline

cons_description: Decision making is very slow

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time

cons_description: Difficult to advance to another administrative position

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: I have worked at the company for 3 years and the best thing about the job is the people that I work with on a daily basis. I work with a lot of great people who are smart and talented.  There appears to be opportunity for development and movement into other roles. There is pretty good work/life balance.
cons_description: Boy's club atmosphere (at least in my department), and difficult to get promoted if you don't have a PhD or a chemical engineering degree. Upper management  is dysfunctional and some are completely out of touch with how the work actually gets done. Communication and teamwork between departments needs improvement. I feel that the company has gotten too big to be efficient.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great Healthcare and Benefits!!! Awesome job security
cons_description: Poor upper management. Issues aren't properly handled and job is somewhat looked down upon.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good pay, predictable work, friendly co-workers
cons_description: Slow to change, unimaginative, bureaucratic

summary: Quick organic growth led to confusion
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Great first job! Good graduates program that enables you to circulate the company during 2 years and then set on the preferred and available role.
cons_description: Everything occurs very slowly here. The company is like the public sector, full of networking and friendships. If you don't know the correct person, by name, nothing gets done and you don't understand why.

cons_description: Since changing from Novartis to GSK, only two top managers have been replaced by GSK leaders and one of them is interim and sill not stay. Due to this, nothing has changed here that needs to change and as hard as I try to implement change, it never sticks and I have a change management masters degree and have implemented many change initiatives in my experience. This place simply does not want to break out of the past and embrace new ways of thinking or doing things.

summary: It was fun while it lasted...
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Excellent benefits and pay, company car, retirement, maternity leave and stock options were lucrative
cons_description: Massive lack of direction with leadership.  Company is full of 'yes men' and good luck if you don't get along with your manager.  You either get along or they will make sure that you get out.  There is a massive talent drain at this company.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Nice people at some sites/locations
cons_description: The employee has to bare the costs of moving and manage the process on his own. He has no say in the type or roles he would get, and most likely will be placed where there is space. Once there, since the employee is only there for a rotation, he would be used to do the job that no one wants to do with the excuse that he gets so much already and it is unfair to give him interesting and developing projects. People have to manage a lot of politics rather than do their job, which only advances the wrong people

access to training and information which are updated within the industry

summary: Good career, limitations on advancement, laid off

pros_description: Smart colleagues, interesting projects, good working environment overall,  Nice culture.
cons_description: Layoffs, resctructuring, seem to be the norm.  Limitations on advanacement / promotion opportunities.  Tendency to bring outsiders into higher roles vs. entertain promotion of key talent from withtin. Many were Denied severence when laid off (and were instead given equivalent work at a struggling CRO).

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: GSK has always had an excellent name in the pharmaceutical area.  During the time that I was there, it was wonderful except for the last year.  Prior to that I became upward on my experience, After starting my job as a Group Leader in Clinical Pharmacology. Assistant Director and Section Head in Clinical Pharmacology Outsourcing and my International Medical Outsourcing.  The next steps were Senior Clinical Assistant Pharmacokineticist, Section Head and finally Director, Clinical Pharmacology.
cons_description: As another company took over, GlaxoSmithKline became a company that did not have the sense to understand the need for keeping a good experience.  After several years I decided to get out of the company and  I wasn't the only one.  After I left I came back to visit my colleagues.  The feeling was not getting support from the executives that used to visit with lower colleagues.

summary: Good pay but the company is going nowhere
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Good pay, good benifits and reasonable work life balance. If you don't want to go anywhere in your career and just get a pay check then this is the place for you.
cons_description: Layoffs, company is not growing,  internal politics and unnecessary internal processes prevents competitiveness. Working there is demoralizing. Middle management is the worst.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description:
In my experience, the level of comfort is good. I mean the package was pretty alright considering flexibility with office hours and good benefits. 

Stated values are good, and this still attracts smart well-meaning people. I can see how that appeals to recent grads. 

The company is also trying to institutionalise some good project management practices and a coherent manufacturing system.
cons_description:
The place is just inconsistent: if you're lucky with a good manager who genuinely subscribes to the values, it can be a wonderful gig. Unfortunately, there are too many skillful navigators at director/vp level and above, who are proper bullies and/or just poor leaders. And despite all the talk of values and despite the restructurings, they still poison the place. More specific observations:

1) Bloated org structure at regional offices. We usually cut headcount at middle management or below, with senior management layers only getting reshuffled. E.g. a senior marketer's job is cut, and the team is disbanded. However the sr manager will call a few buddies and get a random newly-created senior position. The new position will then sprout new positions around it because 'there is so much work to do'. And then the next restructuring comes, with new job titles and the cycle repeats, but operational efficiency remains poor, because there are too many chiefs with overlapping jobs in proportion to the people at execution level. 

2) Related to the first one: poor accountability, because the matrix structures are ridiculous. It's always a decision by committee, and then it's no one's fault if things go south. Decision speed suffers because of the matrix as well - I've seen senior leaders go and ask their bosses to approve mundane decisions which are clearly in their mandate.

3) A good chunk of the system infrastructure is disjointed / archaic. Upgrade projects are under way, but dates are regularly getting pushed back. Seriously, it's 2015, and here is a major mnc where we still collect data via custom spreadsheets for generic analyses. 

4) There is a lot of pressure from the top to reach targets which drives a lot of dubious behaviours with insecure leaders: massaging results, contentious marketing practices... Executive management cannot legitimately claim we are serious about values when we've had bad news from 6-8 different countries in the past 2 years. Hopefully the digital push will help... Consumer healthcare is also bad - the president is a very aggressive individual who says the right things in public but she sets the wrong examples in front of smaller audiences.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Great culture towards continuous improvement in certain areas of the company. The intent to spread that culture is company wide is certainly there. Work-life balance isn't too bad (can't say the same for all roles though). The benefits and vacation allowance (at least 3 weeks to start off with, including end of year shut down) are fair, and help employees balance out the stresses of the job (using all of the allotted vacation days is certainly encouraged by management for health/energy resilience of employees).
cons_description: As in all companies, there tends to be a bit of office politics when it comes to promotions. There are certainly people who get stuck at a certain level for years, even with good performance reviewed. The job grade level structure was 'simplified' a few years ago, which makes it tougher for upward mobility with seniority and performance. Salary negotiations within a band are often frowned upon, again even with good performance. All in all - the culture of continuous improvement,  high energy, and high morale gets stifled by the fact that good people don't feel like they have anywhere to go except laterally - and even lateral movements can be stifled by politics especially if salary adjustments are requested.

summary: GSK Discriminates and abusive to older workers.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than a year
pros_description: Pay is ok, as long as you are not a temporary worker. Company generally seems committed to safety.  Company tries to keep employees informed.
cons_description: If you are an older, non-management employee, lower level supervisors try to drive you down and out of the company.  If you file a complaint against a supervisor, they will find a way to drive you to quit.  Five (5) months after I resigned, GSK is demanding that they overpaid me, and threatening to take me to court if  I don't write them a check.  GSK makes it difficult to get your paystubs, which are very difficult to understand anyway.  They forced all workers to 'go paperless' yet won't give you time or access to download a paystub! They don't properly train low level supervisors, who in turn mentally abuse the older workers until they quit...forcing them to take orders from temporary employees.  One woman who broke her hip at work and eventually came back to work about 8 months later, was quickly fired for 'not being able to lift 50 lbs.  There is a huge gap between upper management and line workers.  Young laboratory workers and office personnel are treated like gold, while most regular workers are kept out of the corporate loop.  Training via computer is about the worst I've ever seen- forcing workers to take tests in areas that don't concern their actual jobs.  Temporary workers are told they will get hired soon...but almost never do get hired on by the company (I felt sorry for them).  The company puts up a huge false front about treating people with respect, yet ignores and retaliates against employees who actually have the courage to complain about being an environment like a teacher screaming at the kindergarden kids!  Confidentiality by supervisors is a joke. I have worked for people_abusive companies before, but never for one that made sensitivity and caring their motto.

summary: Heart is in right place, but..
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 10 years
pros_description: GSK is a good place to work overall. The company today is struggling and the work environment is much more reflective of the struggle and the stresses that accompany it. The company was much different in the past. That being said, it is still a good place to work if you reside in NC. Old leadership has been eliminated and new leadership is trying to find its way.
cons_description: The company spends far too much time on the little things. They live in constant fear of getting in trouble with the government and are afraid to take on any risk whatsoever. Virtually everything is questioned. They rank every employee by department and use a lot of subjectivity to arrive at those rankings. It creates competition between employees and, instead of trying to help one another as good teammates should, co-workers snicker knowing that at least one person will take the fall at bonus time. If I could change one thing, it would be the unfair treatment to employees.

cons_description: Unfortunately every company has to make challenging decisions at times to meet the bottom line and investor expectations. If there was any way they could have done that in 2015 without having to let so many people go it would have been a better situation for all involved.

cons_description: There is a Biopharm CMC group in US in King of Prussia. That entire group can be laid off without affecting the GSK bottomline. They create unnecessary projects just to keep people busy. Whenever scientists accomplish something, the management portrays it as their own success and get bonuses for themselves while writing bad reviews for scientists. The whole group is full of managers, directors, VPs, project managers with couple of workers. So if you do any work, be prepared to get criticism from multiple managers packaged as 'feedback'. I left that place and I have been happy ever since.

summary: Good company but some toxic directors
author_title: Former Employee - Vaccines Health Economics Senior Specialist
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description:
Company provides very good pay and benefits (additional holidays, very good travel policy, modern facilities on site like gym, cafe, small shop, laundry, etc.).
Employees from all parts of the world, most of them very friendly and helpful.
Networking opportunities.
cons_description:
An health economics senior specialist is not a senior manager (and it's very difficult -impossible- to be promoted to senior manager).
Very subjective appraisal, depending on the Director you report to.
In the middle of integration process of external products, a pretext to fire people and freeze promotions.
Some people are very toxic, don't realize they work for a company, for saving lives of people and not for themselves or not in a university.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline

standardized processes

systems used are too old

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: GSK used to be the best in the industry.  Now they are at the bottom.  I used to be so proud to work for them, but no more. They are using their ridiculous Patient First test scores to get force out long term successful sales reps to save money and then hire contract reps to replace them.  They are no longer putting money into their pipeline, but instead are just buying the molecule from another company.
cons_description: There is no respect for the field sales rep.  GSK blames the rep for all of their woes and even though the rep works intensely with long hours to get the job done, there is still no respect.  My manager lied constantly to make herself look good. She was late on anything administrative and was never there to help like managers in the past.  She just didn't do her job.  When the generic Advair comes in 2016 there will be severe layoffs. Their motto TRIP, Transparency, Respect, Integrity with a Patient Focus is a big joke and is no longer practiced here.  You can't even breathe due to the stress and lies implemented by management.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Salary,first-line leadership, development, products, working with sharp team, 401K, medical and dental coverage.
cons_description: Previous incentive compensation mode; and previous upper leadership listening or moving fast enough to address the issue, considerable process orientation, too hard to get promotions under previous model.

summary: Solid Company but be careful for what you wish for...
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Good benefits. Some good brands. Leader in their field. CEO who is willing to take risks and trying to build a culture of leadership.
cons_description: Slow Pharma type company. Highly regulated markets. Lack of talent management.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: The pay is decent for a call center.
cons_description: We are loosing our jobs because they are being outsourced and taken over by Novartis, a company we merged with. Awful management, extremely petty and unfair. Work you to death. Very micromanaged and it's almost like a preschool environment. Worst job I've ever had.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than a year

cons_description: do not see any con

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline part-time

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years

summary: Not the best place to work
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Lunches at meetings, relatively lax supervisors
cons_description: They hire mostly temps contractor who have work there for ever to just even be a full time. Pay isn't that great. Not much upward mobility. Long work hours for manufacturing people.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: 100% tuition reimbursement, and the retirement pension plan. Gsk has great things in place for workplace safety. Also the visual boards displayed throughout the halls are great because it gives all types of updates regarding production activities and other good to know information.
cons_description: Low pay, no rewards, tight with budget. There are more temps than permanent employees in some department because people keep leaving. It's takes a while to hire people. And oh,  did I mention, they don't pay well.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Nice campus, Nice work surroundings.  Can work at home 1 or so days per week.  Support for advancement and additional education if a high performer.
cons_description: Some business unit decisions seem to hurt business more than help. High performance work culture is not run properly as failures are heavily penalized...high performance is supposed to encourage risk for the sake of success.  Rumors of workforce more reductions.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Everyone is committed to the objectives of the company
cons_description: Things can be slow to take off

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than a year
pros_description: Company Culture, work life balance
cons_description: softwares are outdated and approvals are slow

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description:
They have a great working model of R&D structure globally, with proper support from various sites internationally. Scientist are empowered to make changes to what they wish to improve in term of science or working environment.
Management I worked with tried to improve processes so that redundant work process can be reduced if possible. 
There is also a huge emphasis on work life balance so employees can work efficiently.
cons_description:
Many form of 'model testing' like other pharmaceuticals. The multiple changes and mass closure of sites makes scientist feel undervalued by the company. This impedes research where time is required to establish working protocols/procedures, and constant changes reduces efficiency in research.
R&D department has constantly taken a big impact (layoff/headcount freeze/travel ban) to cut cost but is still expected to deliver candidates.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: the  atmosphere  is friendly in the workplace. Colleagues are pretty polite. You can also enjoy open atmosphere in the workplace. It's so good in my opinion.
cons_description: i think the company is good enough for me.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Benefits and salary are good. Ability to work and learn with some very talented staff. Global organization allows for great networking.
cons_description: Managers are hired because of their degree with little to no actual management experience. There is a definite good ol' boys club mentality and a low glass ceiling for scientists that are actually making the drugs that are making the managers more wealthy and move higher in the organization. The recent layoffs were another blow. 450 people laid off, many with 20 plus years experience and there was little to no HR support available. These people dedicated their careers to the company and there was not even a thank you note for their service. Have a look at the stock price, it's clear your investors aren't satisfied either.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Friendly work environment with a large number of company activities  to support an environment where people feel appreciated.
cons_description: lay offs tend to happen around the holidays but you usually know that is coming because the company is very transparent

summary: Good company unless you work in RTP
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Benefits package is really great
cons_description: Management seems to be more about how they can promote themselves then in providing opportunities/advancements for others.  An entire site is treated like a red-headed step-child because they were once 'the other company' even though the merger was almost 14 years ago.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: The sense community in the workplace is awesome. People really are keen to help each other - makes you feel comfortable and confident in the workplace.
cons_description:
The HR is horrible. They feel like owning the company and holding people hostage to their jobs. The salary review is a joke and participating in a round of internal recruitments I was treated much worse than for some of the external jobs I applied for.

Pound foolish, penny wise. Company wastes enormous amounts of money in some areas but refused to do anything about it because that's how it was done for the past 20 years (culture mostly driven by UK & US). Yet on the other hand the ongoing drive for cost reduction leads to absurd and unfriendly situations.

There is some prominent over-advertising of 'success stories'. Which would be good if they were not straight up flops. But hey - what stops HR from giving big shiny bonuses to themselves for a job well done?

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: good pay, nice benefits, good management
cons_description: annual lay offs, uncertainty about future

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline

cons_description: long working hours and high pace

Company is constantly fighting itself - many departments and initiatives at cross-purposes
Poor work / life balance. Tight budgets mean no additional headcount to spread the workload.

cons_description: Restructure. At times remote role is a little too removed. Cannot think of anything more in terms areas I did not like. I gave 3 stars for the restructure aspect.  All other aspects 5-star.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 10 years
pros_description: As far as I am concerned they have entered into a realm of protecting profits at all costs.
cons_description: They have zero loyalty to employees which includes those employees who have dedicated most of their lives to the company. Many have been downsized out without even so much as a note of thanks after giving 20+ or even 30+ years of their lives to the company. Many employees have commented on a mgmt style of high pressure and intimidation which greatly damages employee moral as well.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Well established structure, and organized functional groups.
cons_description: Too much politics~ hard to move things forward.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time

cons_description: the JV saw one of the ugly side of the company performing assessment and selection with who they want to keep in mind.  Novartis headcount are taken in regardless to show fair opportunity but denied the experience and skillsets of the current post holders.

summary: Solid company but their hands are tied.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Solid company with a solid portfolio. They seem look within for promotions first before going external which is a good thing.
cons_description: Their hands are tied when it comes to being a sales organization. In fact I would go as far as to say they are not a sales organization as they don't feel that quantity sold is a good measure of sales aptitude. On top of that they do not reward you for sales.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Strong pipeline. Strong people. Strong heritage.
cons_description: Weak management at all levels

author_title: Former Employee - Senior Executive Pharmaceuticals Sales Representative
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Have ideas for bringing good products to market , some for unmet needs of patients. Unfortunately their marketing department and contracting have no clue to current business environments. Ok benefits.
cons_description:
They are the biggest fraud in the Pharma industry. They purport their vision is all about being the most trusted pharma partner to health care professionals and patients. Bottom line they are strictly about profits, not patients. Deceptive marketing practices unchanged despite paying the Dept of Justice a 3 Billion dollar fine. Their recent downsizing of 2000 employees came after a 2 Billion dollar shortfall in revenue in lead brand Advair due to mistakes made by upper management, contracting and DC herself who was ' forced to retire'.  Cut many senior employees with outstanding top 10% performance rankings and prolonged loyal service. These factors mean nothing to management and HR who were forced to maximize cost cutting. 
Spending the majority of my 30+ year career there was the worst mistake I have ever made.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Great co-workers, loved the location, great products.
cons_description: Every 2 years they go through some form of re-org.  Gets frustrating!

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Competitive salary and good benefits.
cons_description: Due to present circumstances company is in flux.

summary: Reducing staff in the RTP area
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Good benefits, salary and bonuses. CEO is passionate about the mission of the company.
cons_description: Being run by finance. Not a lot of diversity in the upper positions.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Pleasant working environment and generally good compensation and benefits. Very good work/life balance. Access to high end instrumentation. Usually, budget available for conference or training.
cons_description: Sometimes slow  decision making process. Large company with systemic administrative burden.  Shortcoming of scientific strategies. Restrictive rules for article writing and presentation.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: great condition and great possibilities
cons_description: Need to be more innovative

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: My legacy organization was terrific. Good people, great products, and a focus on innovation. Management was supportive and there was solid communication and collaboration across functional areas. Benefits were great (e.g., vacation, shut down week, pre-maternity leave, summer hours...).
cons_description:
The 'New GSK Consumer Healthcare' feels a lot like Reckitt Lite.  

Transformational changes are taking a toll on employees - the 'journey' is never-ending. Lack of clarity around precisely who will be part of the new organization has lead to widespread disengagement, and the overly long selection process has destroyed employee morale. When presented with a challenge to the lack of clear direction it seemed to be regarded as bad attitude or not being aligned with the new vision.  

Summer hours and work-from-home arrangements have been rescinded; other benefits are being dismantled.  Work-life balance is being negatively impacted. New organization is extremely lean and extremely flat - questionable opportunities for growth and development. Mediocre compensation and benefits.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Benefits - 401k and pension, good insurance plans.
cons_description: Everything but the benefits. Basically only promotes minorities (the more UNqualified the better, it seems) bullying from some managers and HR does nothing. Not paid on performance. Extremely inconsistent and A LOT of busy work (depends on manager though)

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: It has a warm culture and respect for people is prime. Salaries are competitive. People help each other. Good international presence. Very values oriented.
cons_description: There could be a more robust career development program within the functions. The marketing organization is the key player in the company. More integration across functions could do the company better.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: commute (suburbs), equipment, benefits, coworkers
cons_description: not a lot of lateral discussion

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time

summary: Transformational Changes - For patients or to mitigate risk
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 3 years
pros_description: Excellent training and people to work with.  An excellent working environment for the most part.  When committed to the goals and aligned to the strategy- you work many hours and can take pride in the results the team can accomplish.  Products do provide value and are marketed responsibly.  A great place to start a career in pharma.
cons_description:
Transformational changes taking a toll on employees remaining.  The 'journey' is never-ending and when there is a challenge to the lack of clear direction- it is mostly viewed as bad attitude or not being aligned with the changes.  The Global operations take precedence over any decisions made for the local environment.
Reporting structure has changed frequently in the past few years- each time being announced as the best option.  Lack of continuity felt throughout organization.  Constant feeling of re-building.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 8 years

cons_description:
Upper management only listens to its favorites and not to reality.  Everyone mostly has blinders on and refuses to see some of the blatant violations of HR policies that are happening.  

Current job cuts are leaving remaining staff with triple the work load with the same pay.

summary: The Joint Venture with Novartis is a mess

The transition will be long and difficult.  Many things will fall trought the cracks and GSK will be less customer focused and even more focused on saving a buck.  The poor performance of Big Pharma has made life difficult for Consumer Healthcare as we need to help the broader company keep the dividends high.

summary: Great place to have a lasting career
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: I've been with GSK for many years and I've been able to enjoy a great career through a variety of different roles in various business areas.  Generally speaking, if you are a high performer you can take charge of your career progression.
cons_description: Given recent downsizing, the number of roles at the director level are limited due to org chart compression.  Having said that, I am not sure it is much different elsewhere in the pharma industry.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: GSK provides awesome benefits including low cost healthcare and pension.  Everyone in the company is eligible for a yearly bonus based on personal and company performance.  Flexible work environment that allows a work from home option when needed.  Salary is comparable to similar roles and responsibilities in the industry.
cons_description: GSK is currently undergoing major changes as the leadership team has made some bad decisions in the past that resulted in the company losing money and forcing layoffs and organizational changes.  GSK has too many systems and processes are more complex than they need to be. The concept is to do more with less, but most people are overworked.  The RTP office has an open floor plan setting, so no more offices or cubicles.
