cons_description: Layoffs, poor moral and malfeasance.  Never have I worked at a place where the motto ' The beatings will continue until moral improves' was more accurate.  During several meeting we were told as a department,' yes things are getting worse, if you don't like it here leave'.  Unfortunately pay was too good to leave until I like everyone eventually was laid off.  In 8 years there I know of 2 people who retired when they were not laid off. Granted I did not know everyone, but retirements were real news.

author_title: Former Employee - Senior Sales Representative and Hospital Representative
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Wonderful people to work with.  Incredible products. Great training. Great support.  Marketing team was 'right on' in their messages, presentations and media selections.  Greatly respected by physicians-great reputation and past products. Amazing product launches, training materials, one on one detailing critiques(video taped for you to watch and improve upon).  The support from the sales team was unbelievable..they were available 24/7 to help.
cons_description:
They changed which products we were detailing and the % of importance/commissions every trimester.
The only car in the fleet that was available to me to drive upon my hiring was a Pepto Bismol pink car.  Not kidding and they made me drive it until the mileage reached it's limit for upgrade.  About 2 1/2 years.  I had the Houston Medical Center as a large portion of my territory and the stares and laughs I got were humiliating. Ha

cons_description:
Recently it's a rough time to work at GSK, with restructuring pretty much everywhere, which really hurts morale.
Being a large company, sometimes it's tough to weed out the bad apples, so people are able to coast by for a long time.

summary: Good people and committed to helping patients
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great people who really care about making their work meaningful and helping patients. Good benefits, flexibility, decent pay (other pharmas pay a lot more). Great strategic focus at the brand level - a machine that delivers.
cons_description: While the brand level strategy is a machine, the upper level strategy is lacking. Moral is low. Lilly influence in the US has killed the culture.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great atmosphere. Take care of employees
cons_description: Slow advancement for career progression

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Benefits are good.  Money is decent.
cons_description: Company values are laudable. They want to be the most trusted pharmaceutical company in the industry. However they have created a toxic culture. Sales people are paid on how well they score on tests and other metics, such as the number of doctors they call on, the percentage of samples they give out and the number of targeted providers they get to programs/meetings. The whole field is cheating because they are scared. They routinely pass around tests; lying (inflating) the number calls made; getting doctors to sign for samples and throwing them away and running telecons that no one listens to.  Reps are also subjectively rated by managers. They say the rating scale is not subjective, but it most certainly is. Integrity, honesty & respect, three of the GSK's pillars have never been so compromised. Cheating is happening. Senior management knows it. The just 'turn a blind eye' to it.

summary: It's like working in an ocean and you are a tiny fish

pros_description: Great health and other benefits. The employee store is useful and has everything from clothes to toothpaste. The Philadelphia facility is very nice.
cons_description: No unity, giant cubicles and no one knows each other. It literally feels like a giant ocean of strangers, save for the small (relatively) group that you work with.

cons_description: zero tolerance for documentation errors can be stressful at times.  On the job training is limited.  Safety stand down meetings are excessive.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: When things are going well, an OK company.  Salaries, bonuses within range of industry averages.
cons_description: Things are rarely 'going well' at GSK.  They have elevated re-organizations, downsizings, layoffs and RIFs to an art form.  People literally go from month to month wondering when their group will be the next one 'hit'.  The political BS is stifling - people are promoted and advanced, not on skill set or capabilities, but on who they know and how they are connected.  Worked with someone who was completely clueless and had only 1 from a list of 15 job requirements who was promoted to VP - insane...

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: There are a lot of great people who work at GSK.  They are smart, fun and energetic people. The company has a good ethos and tries to do the right thing for its patients and its shareholders.  The work environment is pretty good and people want to help others.  The pay is outstanding and the work/life balance is good.
cons_description: There is a reason GSK has been hit with a lot of scandals.  The company is incongruent with itself.  The company empowers people only to say no and rarely yes.  In some cases, even very low level employees can say no and derail a project wanted by senior leadership.  Therefore, even when it is the correct action, employees are sometimes forced to  go around standard protocol to achieve success.  When this is the norm, scandals are inevitable.

Too many silos and not enough team work with focus and understanding of other groups.

summary: GSK Product Development: was good, but GSK-RTP being shut down:
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description:
+Excellent pay and benefits
+Flexible work hours (though varies based on job and boss)
+Stimulating projects (nothing is ever routine)
+Good budgets for great equipment (up until 10 years ago)
cons_description:
-RTP site being shutdown
-For 25+ years before shutdown, had endless counterproductive reorganizations that crushed productivity and caused confusion
-For 25+ years before shutdown, had endless management 'initiatives' that never achieved anything and were usually abandoned before getting to the implementation phase
-For 10+ years before shutdown, had layoffs about every 1.5 years with most experienced/best scientists getting cut
-For 10+ years before shutdown had minimal chances for meaningful promotions
-Complete disconnect between 'talking about quality' and actual timelines & resources allocated for developing projects
-Most equipment not upgraded or replaced in over 10 years
-Now outsourcing EVERYTHING with resulting increased management burden and decreased quality
-Moving R&D to China has been major fiasco

summary: GSK was a great place to work in IT.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: Excellent work life balance and very good pay.  The majority of management is open to ideas and offers advice when needed.
cons_description: GSK is moving a majority of their IT staff out of US.  More layoffs starting soon.  New employee stack ranking system designed to give smaller bonuses and force competition between employees. This is the exact rating system that Microsoft just abolished, the so-called, Rank-and-Yank.  I would say it was to weed out the bottom 10% of employees, if they hadn't already laid so many people off.  I believe it is to help relieve the company of more US/UK employees so GSK does not have to give them a severance package as they continue to eliminate jobs in US/UK and hire in other countries.

summary: Interesting science great benefits but beaurocratic and repeated layoffs
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good pay, plenty of vacation time with company shutdown over Christmas, good people generally, interesting science and projects
cons_description: Over 15 years my department has undergone repeated painful layoffs as the company tries to grow profits by decreasing costs. much more work is now done on contract and R&D done by acquisitions rather than internal research. Even after a record year of new approvals (6) in 2014 we are undergoing another huge layoff (RTP site is stopping all R&D). Unclear when this will stop.

summary: GSK is struggling, but a good place to work
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Even as large as the company is, I felt I was always treated fairly.  The people are fantastic.  Benefits are good.  Hours are flexible.
cons_description: The company is struggling and a significant restructuring recently occurred.  That's always a danger in pharma.

summary: Senior Scientific Investigator, perspective of a scientist.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: Good pay.  Excellent benefits. Great to work in lab if you get the chance. Many good coworkers to collaborate with. EXCELLENT associates-very talented and independent. Working with them is more of a collaboration than a supervisor-supervisee relationship. In fact, they are more fun and worthwhile to interact with than most peers.
cons_description:
Management is completely untrained, both with respect to running a research program and with respect to working with others. People are promoted into management positions based on ambition rather than ability. The more of a steamroller you are the better. 
There is no training available to scientists with respect to managing and interacting with people (and we are scientists-'nuf said), and to rely on management that also has no people skills is a mistake. I was having trouble with a report once and my 'pep talk' meeting with her was absolutely disastrous. I handled it very poorly, and could have used a little coaching.  Additionally, managers  are completely unable to run meetings, allowing some people to turn a 5 minute update into a 30 minute dissertation. That turns a 1 hour meeting into a 2 1/2 hour waste of an afternoon. 
I also wonder if there isn't a little seniority discrimination or 'problem dumping' going on.  During one of our department downsizings, I was chosen to be one of people who needed to find another position within the company. I was having some serious personal problems at the time, and was also one of the highest paid non-managers. In the nine years I had spent in that department, I had received mostly excellent reviews and several awards (including a very rarely given gold award).  Admittedly I was struggling at the time I was selected to go elsewhere, but rather than try to help me and guide me through my troubles, the director chose to dump me instead. So honestly I can only suspect that the dumping came from wanting to make me someone else's problem or to get rid of one of the highest paid scientists.

cons_description: It is a huge company so sometimes it is difficult to interact with a lot of employees. No too many cons

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Flexible work environment, great development opportunities, good compensation
cons_description: constant change every 12-18 months

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Its a school for professionalism and leadership. You can enter to this company  and become a successful person at work and in personal life.
cons_description: Decision takes time to be executed on the right time.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: GSK brings together the critical mass of smart, dedicated people needed to discover drugs.
cons_description: The industry is contracting, and there is always a threat of layoffs in research.

summary: Great place to work with highly motivated people who care about doing things right with high ethical standards
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great benefits and people to work with
cons_description: Top management needs to understand how to motivate a top sales force,, limit the minutiae

summary: Good company if you're in the Philly area
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good benefits and good pay if you can make it through cuts
cons_description: RTP site will be nonexistent within 2 to 3 years.  All functions will move to Philly area.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good benefits and care for the employee
cons_description: Organizational politics more importamt than meritocracy, sometimes

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: culture and value. systematic sops
cons_description: changing is slow. engagement is low

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: Extremely talented and dedicated employees. While leadership may struggle or change, the people working every day do so with strength and commitment.
cons_description: Underneath the immediate challenges, it remains difficult to get ahead. The organization is flattening, limiting opportunities for promotion. Lateral moves are encouraged to gain experience but your salary is not adjusted as you do.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Top notch employees and management.  I enjoyed my time there in QA.  They have excellent benefits and the pay is good,
cons_description: Reorganization occurred while I was there; however most big companies go through these changes as well.  I don't have too many cons as I enjoyed my time there.

summary: I worked at GSK for over 30 years, and it was a wonderful company to work for.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Always room for growth within the company.
cons_description: Nothing negative to say about this company.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Good company, plenty of opportunities for training and diversifying
cons_description: GSK a great company to work for.  Had to leave as we moved abroad.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: Good base pay, travel opportunities and company car
cons_description: Horrible culture, difficult development processess, awful management and leadership

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: The salary and benefits at GSK are very good.  The people that work there have long tenures and it would be difficult to find someone who has been there less than 5 years.
cons_description: Big pharma is shrinking due to patent cliffs for products and lack of investment in organic growth.  There is also major outsourcing activities which all combined lead to constant layoffs.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Work environment is flexible and good compensation/benefits.  Very talented and dedicated employees.  I've seen the employees working every day with strength and commitment.
cons_description: Tough to establish work-life balance; no job stability feeling, but does this exist anywhere?

summary: Twenty years of good and bad at GSK.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Above average salary for long term reps.  Good benefits, vacation, and time off policies.  Quality people in the field.
cons_description: Leadership lacks courage and vision.  No incentives or even acknowledgement for performance.

summary: Great name to work for, but there are some concerns.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description:
-Most employees are assigned to work at one of GSK's gorgeous campuses in King of Prussia, PA
-Professional mentality.
-Staff is friendly.
-Overtime is not really encouraged; 40 hour work week.
-Great Industry.
cons_description:
-The Vice President of EFF (who is also the manager that data analysts report to daily) lives off of micromanaging and is paranoid most of the time.
-Don't be deceived by the friendly environment because EFF can be political.
-External parties complain about the VP in public, which makes the employee second guess the manager.
-No Benefits.

summary: Professional, self motivated individuals striving for a single goal.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Decent salary, good package, with opportunity to grow
cons_description: slow growth, but opportunity is there, low salary increases and bonuses are non factors.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: good work atmosphere, good people
cons_description: very little availability for growth and promotion

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: pay, worrk life balance and benifits
cons_description: politics and lack of gender equality

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: This company was a great company to work for!!!  Management was very willing to help, and very flexible to accommodate with work restrictions.  Employment atmosphere was very pleasant, and our group felt like a work family.  They also had a great vacation plan, holidays, and excellent benefits!!!  One of the few companies that still offer a pension plan as well.
cons_description: The only con I can think of is the potential for layoffs, but that seems to be a growing trend in the pharmaceutical industry, unfortunately.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: This company was a great company to work for!!!  Management was very willing to help, and very flexible to accommodate with work restrictions.  Employment atmosphere was very pleasant, and our group felt like a work family.  They also had a great vacation plan, holidays, and excellent benefits!!!  One of the few companies that still offer a pension plan as well.
cons_description: The only con I can think of is the potential for layoffs, but that seems to be a growing trend in the pharmaceutical industry, unfortunately.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline part-time for less than a year
pros_description: pretty relaxed, very flexible, above minimum wage pay. it was an overall good company to work with. people notice when you work hard.
cons_description: spending a lot of time sitting down, can get pretty boring at times, people always looked out to see what you were doing.

summary: GSK going through a lot of change
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great company and people to work for, opportunities to expand skills and wealth of experience.
cons_description: GSK going through a lot of change, need to reduce complexity in simple processes, senior management can be viewed as making rash decisions based on little information and then a chain reaction from there.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description:
Good pay and benefits.  
Used to be a great place to work where you were recognized and rewarded for your performance. 
Perfect job if you are not driven or motivated and you don't mind sitting home and collecting a good paycheck.
cons_description:
Not paid on performance. 
Majority of people are not engaged and sit at home all day complaining about paperwork and upcoming tests.
Bonus is based on tests and assessment where everyone is graded on a curve and nobody gets any feedback on how they did or what they did wrong. If you are not willing to cheat on your tests then you will be a bottom performer no matter how much you sell or how good you are.
Pipeline is not good and the few new products are not growing because the sales division is not paid on sales and doesn't care about sales performance.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: quality of people, professional development
cons_description: new sales incentive compensation model

summary: rémunérations et autres avantages plus que corrects. La vision d'entreprise est actuellement un peu obscure
author_title: Current Employee - Technician De Production Bulk

pros_description:
-conditions salariales
- possibilité d'évolution de carrieres
- facilité pour concilier vie privée et pro
cons_description:
une communicaiton verticale un peu obscure.
conjoncture actuelle difficile pour l'avenir de l'entreprise et pour les salariés du coup

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline

cons_description: very bureaucratic with moderate pay

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline

cons_description: have not find any cons yet

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 8 years
pros_description: Supportive environment between district and territory partners. Highly skilled representatives who you can learn a lot from.
cons_description: Bad middle and upper management beating dead horses with the belief that scripted messages and tons of administrative work actually drive sales.

summary: Great principle driven and patient focus!
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for less than a year
pros_description: Middle and Top management is very knowledgeable and cooperative. Sales representatives are very competent and focus on therapeutic education to patients. Excellent benefits.
cons_description: Stategic and supporting groups are slow and in some cases very inefficient due to poor resource planning. Some of these groups are taking important decisions with very limited or erroneous information.

pros_description: Protecting patients from deadly disease
cons_description: there is many. check advice to management

cons_description: I do not have any negatives

cons_description: none, none, none, none, none

pros_description: good benefits, pay and retirement
cons_description: The Philadelphia wage tax is a killer

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: benefit, team members, training in time
cons_description: overtime often occurs due to compounds deliverables

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: good salary puts the golden handcuffs on you
cons_description: typical high level mgmt. way out of touch

summary: Solid conservative company with increasingly less focus on the pharma business
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: Collaborative environment.  People-focused.  Bright and dedicated colleagues.
cons_description: conservative, risk averse.  Company is trying to diversify the risks of developing pharmaceutical products that require high drug price to recoup the investment.   After all, all major countries will eventually follow UK model.

summary: Great experience but too much politics
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: A lot of experience and good people. Great marketing. Global footprint put to good use. Sincere interest in developing promising talent
cons_description: Personal fiefdoms abound and starts at the top. Merger mania can be good and fresh but infusion of new corporate cultures can be distracting when heads focus on known n  lieutenants

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Good at supporting career development
cons_description: Changes in headcount and structure

summary: Underhanded dealings. Does not honor employment agreements or policies if they are not legally required to.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: If you can stay the pay and benefits are very good. Some opportunity to move around sites and business units.
cons_description: Layoffs, outsourcing, and getting rid of people for as cheaply as possible. Not much company loyalty. Difficult to advance past the old guard, as they are almost always given preference for new roles or advancement.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Career advancement and sales training opportunities
cons_description: Patient First Assessments and Simulations

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline part-time for more than a year
pros_description: Benefits given were on given the position
cons_description: Long working hours to hit sales targets

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: GSK is a great company to work for overall. It is commonplace to work with individuals from across the world, which is a very enlightening experience. GSK does care about patients and performs a lot of work dedicated to charitable notions.
cons_description: It takes forever to get anything done with the bureaucracy and political climate. This causes frustration as a lot of hard work goes to waste when it takes so long for decisions to be made. Everything is about savings money right now, and the focus is on tactical decisions, not strategic ones.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: People believe on u.u have freedom to do works by ur own way.
cons_description: Currently very focused on Value, Not very system oriented in terms of sale.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good benefits and good perks with the company
cons_description: management in England not in tune with US

summary: GSK is a good company to work for.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Flexible work hours, good benefits, average compensation, on-site fitness center, easy access to benefit management site and performance review site, good resources for on-job training.
cons_description: Work environment is getting intense and less friendly recent years. Too many people work on administration jobs. The performance review process is getting weird. Frequent reorganization.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: The benefits are extraordinary and the people I worked with were generally competent and nice but in such a big company, you do find people who seem to stick around because they are better at politics than performance.
cons_description: The complexity of the organization - you have to go through a lot of hoops to get things done

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: KNow industry knowledge. involve Pharama and FMCG
cons_description: NO development plan/ has reputation issue

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Great exposure and leadership skills
cons_description: No Cons for this company

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: A fair amount of developmental programs, strong pipeline
cons_description: Patient First, Incentive compensation, questionable leadership

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Great training opportunity, Flexible schedule, good compensation
cons_description: Tenure based instead of performance based.

summary: Many positive aspects of working at GSK
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: Cutting edge science, infinite opportunities, great office culture, training and career development support
cons_description: Large organization that can seem hierarchical

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good work life balance for the most part but does depend on local management.  Benefits and pay are good.   Office culture in the new Philadelphia office is fantastic.  Open work environment and good worknig vibe
cons_description: Job opportunities in the Philadelphia office lag behind the UK.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: Great opportunity to work in a global organization with direct exposure to unique needs of developing markets.  Despite excellent learning opportunities and comp, moving up is unlikely unless you are British.
cons_description: This is the right place to work for professional development or are strictly interested in maximizing your comp. However, it is worth noting that few employees resign or retire.  Rather, most are let go as a result of a downsizing initiative which occur every 18 months like clockwork.  The addition of Emma Wamsley as president in 2010 has had little positive effect on the organization's business model or performance, adding fuel to the already underperforming division.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Lots of smart people.   Genuine corporate desire to create great medicines.
cons_description: Persistent cultural issues.   Shrinking in innovative R&D, making it hard to find new roles or develop.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Salaries and benefits. Global presence. Leading products.
cons_description: NON respect for a 25 years long committed employee. Terminated as a robber or even worst. So NOT the company I though I worked for. I was so proud. But the 'Respect for People' they mentioned everyday is just in manuals. Its NON existant watsoever.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: GSK biologicals is considered to be one of the top employers in belgium, there is an on site gym and great coffee corner. If your just starting out in the pharma industry work is cruisey
cons_description: Management doesn't empower you to do anything. IT technology is so outdated its like working in the 80's everything is managed on excel spreadsheets. It doesn't matter how competent you are to do your job if you want to advance you have to do what management says even if its corrupt and against the company values.

summary: Rewarding experience, lately work environment is chaotic, managing to many initiatives and not focusing on fundamentals
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: Good career opportunities and good benefits. Fflexible working environment. Employs good people who are dedicated and who endeavor to do the right thing for the patient
cons_description: chaotic work environment. Management putting high pressure to deliver results without providing adequate resources to deliver.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: Work life balance, work from home, opportunities available
cons_description: Heavy workload, but that is job security

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: Decent pay for our area
cons_description: Management couldn't plan anything.  During the summer there wasn't enough work, many weeks we didn't get 40 hrs and had to take vacation.  In the fall and winter we worked 6 and 7 days a week, 12hr shifts.  Pay raises were almost nothing and were not based on performance, just a flat rate.

summary: Great company; develops people; high expectations; work/life balance challenging; take the job if offered
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: Enormous company with many eco-systems so employee experience can vary greatly depending on management and business challenges. I've worked there 8 years, rose from Admin to Manager and have been offered valuable professional development opptys most points along the way. In an HR delivery function I can attest to it being a very ethical company that tries to do right by employees. Employees must own their development but the tools are there and easily accessible. Movement is encouraged to build breadth of knowledge. Pay is good/fair and benefits are excellent.
cons_description: Constant market fluctuations can drive waves of RIFs that cycle through the various businesses functions. Certain functions, like IT, have seen more than their fair share. That said, there are many who have been with GSK IT over 20 years. Not unique to GSK, but they continue to try to do more with less to protect stock pricing. Employees are feeling the strain. Too many simultaneous objects. Very project focused and too many meetings.

summary: A visionary company that is great to work for.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: Company values were solid, and the company responded to feedback from the field, which can be a very important quality in a company. I really had top notch managers who cared about their reps and treated them like the professionals they were. This then inspired myself  and others to rise to put forth their very best. I learned a lot about leadership with my managers.
cons_description: There were a lot of changes that occurred very quickly, and the impact to the representatives was that the changes were occurring at too fast a pace.  Remarkably the company responded to feedback and worked to make the situation better.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 5 years
pros_description: Good salary and benefits. Good work-life balance. Good opportunities to learn with employees with a high level of competency.  Great installation.
cons_description: Very complex company.  Laval site not considered enough by upper management based in Belgium.  A lot of employees are very susceptible.  Difficult to get support within the company.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: Many opportunities to move around the company
cons_description: Constant changes with lack of clarity. Good intentions with bad execution

summary: GSK is a highly professional organization that seeks employee empowerment and engagement through education & career path
author_title: Former Employee - Audit Manager, R&D Internal Audit
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: Reasonable expectations of staff, great working hours and fellow staff are great to work with.
cons_description: With the company tightening its belt over the past few years, many of the opportunities for upward career mobility have been eliminated.  This makes competition for the available positions extremely difficult and forces staff to remain static in their positions for many years, make lateral moves or leave the company for better opportunities commensurate with their skill sets and talents.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: There are none that I can any longer find.
cons_description: Long hours no meaningfull pay increases and the constant cuts in full time employees to contract workers.

summary: Overall a good place to work but headed in the wrong direction.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: I worked with a lot of good dedicated people.  Everyone cared and was willing to pitch in to produce a safe quality product.
cons_description: Management, they expect people to do the work of 2 people and do not want to hear it's not done. Site manager outright lied to employees on at least one occasion probably more.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 5 years
pros_description: Great Work Life balance. The people are the best part of the company.
cons_description: Hierarchy. Leaders who are not connected to what goes on at the bottom of the organization make all the decisons

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Fairly stable due to it's size. Excellent work-life balance.
cons_description: A lot of older management in the high ranks makes moving up a challenge. Quite behind the tech curve in terms of R&D and overall processes. Not the best pipeline.

author_title: Current Employee - Procurement Leadership Development Program Associate
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Globally focused, nurturing culture, strong and diverse product portfolio, strong emphasis on maintaining healthy work-life balances. The company allows you to do so and encourages it. Great benefits: 401K with up to 6% match, Pension Plan and generous vacation time according to US standards.
cons_description: Bureaucracy as I'd expect from any large company. Top heavy company with too few workers. Long term employees overpaid and unambitious. The company does offer great benefits and as such creates an atmosphere of 'golden handcuffs'

author_title: Current Employee - Procurement Leadership Development Program Associate
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Globally focused, nurturing culture, strong and diverse product portfolio, strong emphasis on maintaining healthy work-life balances. The company allows you to do so and encourages it. Great benefits: 401K with up to 6% match, Pension Plan and generous vacation time according to US standards.
cons_description: Bureaucracy as I'd expect from any large company. Top heavy company with too few workers. Long term employees overpaid and unambitious. The company does offer great benefits and as such creates an atmosphere of 'golden handcuffs'

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Nice building with complete facilities and infrastructure, Globally renowned Pharmaceutical Company
cons_description: Mediocre Leadership and Management with good talk but mediocre actions, changing environment with lots of uncertainties, attractive entry remuneration package but with low increment and bonus. Multinational company that do not promote fun environment and with restricted freedom in work.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Excellent support system from management, good benefits, fun job when you work hard,
cons_description: Very big. Need to live near corporate to advance within company,

summary: My work experience with GSK was great until the last 5 years.
author_title: Former Employee - Executive Pharmaceuticals Sales Representative
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: GSK gives you exceptional training and the industry standard benefits. The company stresses patients are first in everything that they do.
cons_description: GSK does not have good work- life balance. The compensation is not good. Compensation and performance are not based on how well you sell your products. Compensation and performance are based on mangers ratings, timed test that require you type in all of your answers and simulations that are done over the phone. GSK has made a VERY STRESSFULL environment for its field employees to work in. I know several employees in the field and not one is happy working for GSK.

summary: Horrible of Horrible companies to work for.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: benefits, company car, pension, nothing else
cons_description: Group incentive packages, and out right age discrimination, that you can't prove.   They will write you up and force you out, if you are over 40 years old, even if you always performed in the past.  I got a new manager, I had moved my territory 60 ranking points above my peers in two quarters, with a brand new territory, and brand new drugs. The same day those numbers came out and I was at 140% of goal,  they allowed my manager, who used to fall down drunk at sales meetings, who was having an affair with someone in our region,( to the point that everyone could hear them at national sales meetings in hotels) to write me up and say that I didn't know how to sell.  He would smell like alcohol in the AM when I picked him up at his hotel for a ride along, and then he would have me drop him off at Starbucks for a couple hours at lunch, and he would get back in my car to go on two more calls before he quit everyday at 3, smelling like cigarette's.  Very nice to have to bring in your offices when the doctors can smell alcohol and cigarette's on him.  He had even been written up for his behavior before, but I was the one who got pushed out.

summary: Engaging clinical trial work but company overworks permanent employers due to tight resources and finances.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Satisfying work in clinical trials, ability to do some telecommuting allowing work-life intergration and decent benefits for medical/dental and timeoff.
cons_description:
Disconnected senior management, disconnect between company philosophy and culture and behavior of senior mangement, especially with regard to ethics and oncology staff was instrumential in the success of several treatments only to have senior executives decide they could capitialize on their employees' sweat equity to swap assets with Novaritis for approx $16 billion dollars. The senior management and some middle managers at GSK are quite cut-throat, don't look out at all for their employees, can't understand why telecommuting would make the company more competitive and cut-costs without severe adverse effects on staff and micro-manage.

Lack of meaningful career advancement due to changes in job grades and the old girl and old boy networks. If you are not part of the Queen Bee hive, you are likely to languish in your current position.

With the current turbulence at GSK, I suggest folks take a pass until the dust settles sometime in 2015. If you care about ethics at a company, I'd take a pass on GSK for the time being.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: Overall people at GSK are good!  Enjoyed everyone I worked with.  Not a lot of career options currently and R&D product pipeline does not appear to doing what was expected.
cons_description: Big company, lots of office politics.  If you don't get moved up early, you probably have missed the boat.Your job satisfaction is as good as your manager.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for less than a year
pros_description:
Good work life balance
Challenging work
independence to manage your own projects
great people to work with, great benefits
cons_description:
Slow to promote
often have to put up with mundane tasks
Internal politics
At times bureaucratic

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: A company which take care of the well being of the employees, provide good culture and conducive to working harder and smarter.
cons_description: There is plenty of double standard treatment from management to staffs and they are often not sincere and upfront in their communication. They also tolerated many incompetent and overbearing managers for incomprehensible reasons. Pay is not able to meet the yearly high inflation rate.

summary: Good place to work and to learn.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Respectable company with the good portfolio and stable diverse business.
cons_description: Compensation policy seems slightly below the market. Slight reputational problem (globally - compliance, and also locally - vaccines trials, Volgograd).

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for less than a year
pros_description: Benefits are superb! The medical insurance is one of the best in the industry.
cons_description: Too many  consistent database changes, utilized sales force as focus group to utilize new software, micro management, non creative with HCP/Customer database, overly regulated, too much time required at Desk, although we were outside sales professionals, time management was unrealistic to get electronic responsibilities completed and spend adequate time in the field calling on HCP's.

summary: Great company to start with if you are new to the industry.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Senior management is great, work/life balance good
cons_description: Patient first, simulations, lack of detailed feed back about test results

summary: Working in GSK is like going to a jungle
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great benefits; I can think of anything else.
cons_description: Too much pressure , no work life balance. Too much expectations from the management. Too much office politics. Management practice is non leadership by example. Some doesn't care about the people they will cross just to be on the upper ladder

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Friendly atmosphere, best pay, good values
cons_description: Too much paperwork, fair work-life balance

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: good pay , good benefits, good pension,good 401k, the vacation time was great you start out with 3 weeks
cons_description: they want you to keep adding reponsibilities to your job with out paying you any more money

summary: The best company I have worked for
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: This company is great when it comes to work life balance.
cons_description: I cant think of any really

summary: Lots of poltics, contract employee's treated like second class citizens
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Industry *was* secure and stable
cons_description: not up to date with technology, slow to change, lots of politics.

summary: Great team culture and excellent product portfolio!!
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: As a small team (of about 20 nationally) with a shallow management structure things were always transparent which made for a fantastic team culture. Pre entry psychometric testing seemed to place a lot of emphasis on 'fit', not surprisingly those that made it into the team generally felt like they were surrounded by like thinking co workers. Might sound a little creepy to some, but that was the best cultural fit I've ever found. All the critical mass of a multi national (powerhouse brands and a great product portfolio) combined with a relatively small headcount locally. Many international career opportunities available, and numerous of my colleagues took them up.
cons_description: When one of the key leaders was transferred internationally we seemed to lose momentum as his replacement was not of the same standard (and may have duped his was through the pre entry testing)

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great team, good employment benefits
cons_description: Long, long hours..lots of meetings and activities, sometimes unnecessary and takes up lots of time..staff have to work late to compensate for time wasted.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Patient focus in every area
cons_description: Delay updating from vusual aid to ipad

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good training ground, good reputation in market, brand name
cons_description: Too slow, not much growth

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Great Benefits and competitive salary
cons_description: Management is not in tune with employees. It is sometimes difficult to accomplish tasks with the information and tools provided. They are only concerned with trying to accomplish quite unreasonable corporate goals. The move to the open work environment is counterproductive for some. Not everyone excels in that environment. Too much outsourcing! It makes the job of most employees more difficult because they have to deal with a language barrier and lack of corporate understanding when dealing with the outsourcing company.

summary: Overall rewarding, but not in favor of recent changes as a result of the corporate integrity agreement.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: The company has a good training program and the entry level reresentative is well prepared tp educate HCP's about medications.
cons_description: Patient First and the incentive compensation plan has created an unhealthy environment that promotes misrust, lack of transparency and subjective ratings.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Work life balance, good benefits
cons_description: poor management skills; decision changes very fast

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Good work environment, dedicated people, good benefits. Sometimes long hours were required, but overall work life balance was fair.
cons_description: Slow downsizing was almost constant due to late stage failures. No clear strategy. Seemingly lots of problems in overseas units.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good benefit, lots of nice people to work with, flexible work hours
cons_description: don't feel pay by performance, lacking budget to replace equipment, management is not that great.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great culture and campus and work
cons_description: Hard working globally because of time zones

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Wonderful colleagues, lots of job flexibility
cons_description: Constant infrastructure change. I was laid off but managed to get a position elsewhere in the company. I then left the company to pursue academic goals but haven't succeeded in getting my foot back in the door. They seem to be going through more lay-offs

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: True to the corporate values
cons_description: Continue to focus on patients

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Best value company I worked
cons_description: no idea of how to develop long term career

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: good working environment. Excellent prospects for people who are prepared to put the effort
cons_description: constant change in last 10 years

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description:
Environment - great place to work before densification. Plenty of space for privacy

Salary - met industry standards but did not take into account specialized fields and any award accumulated

Benefits - better than average
cons_description:
Always looking over your shoulder
Too many reorgs
Always had to justify your job or be outsourced.  Last time was lied to about losing my job.
Too many good people gone
No incentive to stay
Densification equals demoralization
Pay for performance lacking
Advancement almost impossible unless you knew somebody. Was promised promotion but never happened even after attaining proper credentials

summary: A positive place to work with opportunities to try different career paths
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Great benefits and lots of resources beyond products for customers
cons_description: Challenging business environment means being able to focus in a company with more manpower than it needs.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description:
Work-life balance, office culture, leadership, lots of possibilities to learn and expand your knowledge, remote working,
great company to start working in complex matrix environment
cons_description: at some point there is limited opportunity to advance, despite going to cross team working it seems very team closed,

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: This company gives opportunity to develop skills. In this company every employs can be creative and improve each process - this is very important in career path.
cons_description: I can use in this company in my work only English language. If will be better when I could be use my second language which is Italian :)

summary: Good place to work with little problems
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Good compensation and benefits  and good growth
cons_description: poor management and strategy by upper management

author_title: Current Employee - Senior Pharmaceuticals Sales Representative
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: The pay and the flexibility of the job is great, and it is nice knowing that the medicines you promote actually do help people live better lives.
cons_description: 'Patient First' is the name the company uses to describe the compensation system. Since entering into a Corporate Integrity Agreement with the federal government several years ago, the company can no longer evaluate representatives on the basis of sales or prescriptions. What it has done instead is implement this new system which essentially boils down to taking tests and checking boxes. This new system has little to do with actually helping patients, and is an incredible waste of time and resources.

summary: Good Company with good career opportunities
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: value, culture, cooperative, knowledge, appreciation
cons_description: salary, reporting dcr on mobile, increament,

summary: Good place to work if not in oncology
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Nice work environment, nice people
cons_description: Difficult to advance - some departments have a hierarchal view of employees and makes it impossible to move up - others depts. are great

summary: Very thorough training with extremely high expectations, especially demanding of your family life.

pros_description:
Compensation seems fair for those with tenure.
Benefits are fair but getting more streamlined.

Work -life balance constantly compromised.
Too much study time required

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: good working nature,monthly training,good pay from others in initial stage
cons_description: no incentives present,difficult to manage work

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Work life balance is fair
cons_description: Patient First Model implemented for US Sales Division has been an abysmal failure.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for less than a year
pros_description: Great work environment, friendly co-workers, safe woking conditions.
cons_description: Most of the staff (myself included) are contingent workers. GSK 'contracts' us for 18 mon then lays off for 6  mon. to avoid paying benefits to 'temp' workers.

summary: Opportunities to learn new skills; but work stifled by red-tape and restrictions ;too frequent changes in policies

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: comfort working environment, nice people
cons_description: canteen a little bit small

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Good Work-life balance. Good salary and benefits, including bonus opportunity. People are nice and supportive for the most part.
cons_description: Weak culture. Morale is low driven by too many restructures and layoffs.  Opportunities to grow are limited as there are very few higher level jobs. The structure has become very flat after restructuring. It sometimes feels like a cold company without a soul.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Good and sensible British culture
cons_description: Too many distraction - Lawsuits, bad PR happening

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: GSK is a one of the benchmark companies in the pharmaceutical career, a lot of challenge and knowledge is being gained while practicing a work their, the establishment of system with principles of adherence to quality and safety   is main effective side.
cons_description: Engineering career is limited as the main businesses is related to pharma which mainly depends on pharmacists and analysts

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description:
A lot to learn 
Nice People and Good Training Sessions
cons_description:
Slow Growth , 
Pay not enough

summary: Excellent place to work at, positive environment, great family-work balance.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Managers ķept a positive attitude towards employees. Company uses several tools to keep personnel motivated. Training was an important part of their policies. Loved working there.
cons_description: It was haRd to get promoted since people stayed for long periods of time. I really don't have anything bad to say about this company.

summary: Overall favorable but beware of the politics and the politicians
author_title: Former Employee - Commercial Side of the Business
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Good products line with some of the products truly world-class. The benefit package is pretty good and the work/life balance is pretty reasonable for pharma. GSK did a nice job keeping employees up-to-date with what was going on in the company and not just in the country you worked but overall. Felt well connected.
cons_description: Sometimes a bit afraid of their own shadow. The Corporate Integrity Agreement signed in June 2012 took its toll on innovation and willingness to swing and miss. There always seemed to be something changing so knowing the most current operating policies meant searching the intranet for the recipe far too often.

author_title: Current Employee - Senior Pharmaceuticals Sales Representative

Car
shirt and tie
glasses
fast to find

low income
no hope to progress

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: number 1 company in egypt , ethical policies , team work , stability , the est training course , promotions
cons_description: stressful condition to be always in the lead make u always more tough .

author_title: Current Employee - Senior Executive Clinical Specialist
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: High science , intelligent discussions are the norm in the Specialty Arena
cons_description: 'Cultural Diversity' has all but eliminated high performing employees from the advancment pool. Careers can quickly stall

summary: Great for freshman, not for the experienced
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Ideal environment if you want to learn things. Robust training.
cons_description:
Has good products in pipeline, however seems like they have lost their direction somehow with all the unnecessary red tapes and bureaucracy.

People are very political and some form of favoritism can be seen at play.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Chance to work with teams across globe. Good place to work.
cons_description: not a master payer, highly system oriented causing lot of quality issues.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: First line management is engaged with employee needs to get the job done. Flexible hours. Friendly staff and team atmosphere.
cons_description: Upper management is out of touch with needs of employees. Promotion go to who they know. Retention of employees seems to be a problem.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: There is a lot of effort on the part of senior leaders to create an environment at GSK conducive to innovation, productivity, and a good work experience. There is a large value placed on professionalism and teamwork.
cons_description: A minority of senior leaders focus their energy on politics and get in the way of GSK being all that it can be. Initiatives rarely are ended; they just fade away, wasting time an effort on the part of employees to continue to engage until they realize nothing is happening.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Great team to work with, no competition between each other.
cons_description: Lots of change and uncertainty.

summary: Too much paperwork, too much liabilities
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: Great fellow employees, a well-meaning company.
cons_description: The system is too archaic. More time is spent managing the system than in doing real work.

summary: Great company to work for if you are interested in a large global company.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Unlimited number of opportunities to advance career starting with university intern and graduate placement programs.  Company provides avenues for learning through various learning mechanisms.  Global presence also gives opportunity to learn about different cultures, working in a global environment and understanding complexity of a global business. Mergers, acquisitions and divestitures also result in many opportunities within the company.
cons_description: Many of the core shared services, Finance, HR, IT have been pressured to reduce costs/complexity, etc resulting in many layoffs and moving services outside of GSK.  With continued change, there is always opportunity!

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good flexibility in terms of working from home, exciting work and great people who work collaboratively. Good opportunities to move into other functions and learn oyhet parts of the business
cons_description: Work life balance is not ideal, very high workload and a very flat organization means little room for growth. Being a large corp means that flexibility in how things are or can be done isnt easily achieved.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Good salary, team working environment, good place to learn but no longer a career maker.
cons_description: Open 'kitchen table' work station that company adopted in 2011 is a nightmare to work in.  Very difficult to concentrate and you spend your evenings doing the quality work.  Management is disengaged and only goes through the motions.  Laid off (retired) after 30+ yrs and didn't get so much as a good-bye handshake.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than 10 years
pros_description: Salary, benefits, good brands, working from home
cons_description: Senior leaders are serious micro managers. Not interested in building relationships, more interested in their flawed culture. All about building phoney numbers. Sales calls are a joke. All they care about how many false numbers they can get from the doctor. Not real world, everything is drop down boxes.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Salary 
Great in first 10 years
cons_description: Merger with Glaxo, company run by lawyers

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description:
Good salaries and benefits also peers work with you to achieve goals
Competition within the company sometimes is fierce
Benefits above market
cons_description:
Uncertainty of future constant changes company seems that they don't know where should be going
Relationship-based not real merit promotions

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: The company has many opportunities, enough to keep hundreds of contracted employees busy for years to come. The work is challenging but very rewarding.
cons_description: As a contracted employee in general work life balance is hard to achieve; more so with a company like gsk, where there is a lot of work in the pipeline and at least where I am nut enough company employees (not contractors) to oversee, approve abd advance projects.

summary: Typical for a large global pharmaceutical company.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: The advantage of working for a large pharmaceutical are the broad opportunities available to employees for advancing your career.  The benefits are good for employees.  The salary and bonus is competitive with the best incentives for the lower salary grades.  GSK is trying to create an image of a good corporate citizen in the aftermath of several well known regulatory compliance issues.  And if you love open office concepts, then there's a place for you at GSK.
cons_description: As with any large pharma, creating a strong corporate culture is talked about, but not organically cultivated.  Having worked at smaller biotech companies, it is apparent that although they want to create a culture it is difficult for a large globally disconnected corporation to truly have a common culture.  Innovation and thinking outside the box are trumped by bureaucracy and following the herd.   My personal experience with HR is that they toe the company line and are not truly ambassadors for employees.  Open office concept is not as productive as management would have you believe.

summary: Good experience, the top management is very friendly to management hires.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for less than a year
pros_description: Good organisation, People will value your work ex at GSK more than other pharma players
cons_description: Salary too low. For campus interview they do not leave any room for negotiation. Also salary hikes on basic salary and not on CTC

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: Wonderful smart people to work with, good benefits and bonus opportunities. Lots of development opportunities, project work and empowerment. Dynamic and personable CEO, Andrew Witty.
cons_description: constant reorganizations and restructures, promotional opportunites have become fewer

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: used to be good not anymore
cons_description: outsourcin very confusing and frustrating

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Culture is great!  Values of company are ones that you can really feel good about!
cons_description: Takes way too long to get promoted and jobs are competitive.

summary: Hard to leave a company that offers more than most!!
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: EXCELLENT benefits and perks, very flexible, female and male leaders who seem to 'get it,' feel close to leadership, complaints and roadblocks to doing job get escalated and you feel heard.
cons_description: Tough business in general, MANY changes that happen VERY frequently, if you do not like change, you will not survive nor would you like working here.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description:
Empowerment and accountability, Culture & Values
Trainings
cons_description:
Lack of leaders.
Performance development plan was not well organized in the whole company in Egypt

summary: A great company in the Life Sciences arena, especially amongst the larger companies

pros_description: Truly global; some great businesses such as Vaccines and Consumer Products; some real innovations in such areas as Malaria and Vaccines
cons_description: Conservative; maybe not moving as fast as could be or truly changing the culture

summary: Going down year after year since 2007
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Reasonably stable environment, good pay, and descent (used to be excellent) benefits
cons_description: Poor leadership, disconnect between senior and middle-range management, poor treatment of employees

author_title: Former Employee - Executive Pharmaceuticals Sales Representative
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: The company knows how to reward an overachieving employee
cons_description: Too much company politics in the organisation

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Benefits, training, opportunities for self improvement, bonus.
cons_description: Workload was particularly heavy at times. Sometimes bureaucracy and hierarchical structure hampered good initiatives.

summary: PRAY IF YOUR A SENIOR, 10 years of dedicated service equals being laid off to save money on a younger less experienced..
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Money...As long as you forget your own personal ethics you'll be OK.
cons_description:
Understand that this company pay and values sales first and only.  Research for safety is a low priority.
Unethical company with no morals other than making money!   
No work life balance NONE.  Be prepared to lose the very people you value the most--your family!
ADVISE:  Value your laptop, because it becomes a limb on your body.  Value your company car because you'll spend more time in it than with your family.   Quit at 5 years if your smart, unless of course, you work in sales, and your willing to bet your looks last.  If you are a woman get some plastic surgery, and find the tight shirt, and the very shortest skirts...oh, don't forget the 3' heels.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: High values which are carried through all aspects of the job. Great compensation and work/life balance.
cons_description: Slow to adopt change. Understandable given the size and scope of the business units.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline  for more than a year
pros_description:
4 day work week with 12 hour shifts
Family oriented atmosphere - Company picnics, Holiday Christmas party for the kids
Bonus
cons_description:
Rotating schedules
The political game - knowing the right people

summary: My experience at GSK was wonderful!
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Excellent training, great team members, company culture (focused on the patient) and a fun challenge !
cons_description: My contract was only for three years. I was sorry to go.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Excellent perks, training and development.
cons_description: Extroverted 'speak up' employees and leadership are being managed out of the organization.  New culture prioritizes appearance to the general public, even if it means sacrificing their integrity.

summary: Work is rewarding, hours are long, pay is OK
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: Benefits, vacation time, the work is rewarding
cons_description: No work life balance, leadership is so-so, no sense of community among teams or departments.  Constant undercurrent of do more with less.

summary: Great Mission, Good Salaries, Extremely Bureaucratic.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Good business strategy and on-going communication with employees.
cons_description: Very Political, UK centric and slow at making decisions.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Nothing really. They flaunt their pension plan but it really only equates to a couple thousand a year. I am so glad I found a new job.
cons_description: They have no ethics. They are every bit the dirt balls you think big pharma would be. Oh and they're cheap

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Great healthcare plan, fun team-building outings, great pay, good amount of paid vacation days, and a wonderful bonus every year.
cons_description: Sometimes coworkers gossip, spread rumors, etc. but that is expected in every workplace.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Opportunities for young scientist to develop their ideas, nice salaries, care for employee, focus on creativity and innovation, as well as on patient needs. Multidisciplinary teams.
cons_description: Sometimes management should be more decisive to focus to complete good projects and to discard less promising ones. Sometimes too confusing corporate policies.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: Opportunities for young scientist to develop their ideas, nice salaries, care for employee, focus on creativity and innovation, as well as on patient needs. Multidisciplinary teams.
cons_description: Sometimes management should be more decisive to focus to complete good projects and to discard less promising ones. Sometimes too confusing corporate policies.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Social networking is good given that employee numbers are always increasing every month. Processes and workflows are in good order and set up, time can be flexible depending on job nature.
cons_description: Focus on employee staff: Subjective (no PDP for contract staff and often times, neglected for many things. Perm staff get all the attention even though there are quite a handful of contract staff who has been with the company for a no of years despite headcount freeze)

author_title: Current Employee - Senior Executive Pharmaceuticals Sales Representative
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: was great sales culture but has changed
cons_description: all the testing for sales reps now & sales reps don't get sales numbers

summary: Top 50 or Top 25 company for almost a decade...
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Work/Life balance, salary+bonus, people, culture
cons_description: Transparency is one of our key 4 values, and it's gone by the wayside - at least transparency is only evident when convenient.  Communications is often late in the process. Director level & above very cautious of protecting themselves and making themselves look good & often taking advantage of others while abusing the companies generous work flexibility.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: Excellent salary, work environment, benefits.  Strong emphasis on accountability and practicing corporate behaviours.  Top notch training programs and a genuine concern for resilience and employee health.  Hugh diverse employee base of highly qualified and intelligent people. Work life balance is important and some managers allow you to work from home on a regular basis with an agreement set up ahead of time.
cons_description: So big that it's hard to move up or acquire another job in house.  You can apply but don't expect to be interviewed or notified why you are not interviewed or qualified.  Hard to find needed information for tasks at hand due to constant changing of systems and processes.  Highly regulated with regard to keeping 'between the lines' which, when systems or processes change, group transistion hiccups often occur.  Polictics within upper management occurs and the bulk of your department is at another site, there are no opportunities for growth.  Promotions are rare for everyone but do occur for the selected few that are high achievers and given more opportunities.

cons_description: Poor lab facilities in many areas with aging equipment. Flexible work at home options and vacation policy.

author_title: Former Employee - Manufacturing and Building Maint Mechanic

summary: Great cohesion with management and sales team.
