main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: I was there for 9 months on a consulting gig and I'm very proud of the work I did. The people were hard working and mostly dedicated to the wellness of their customers, helping others and creating great products.
cons_description: GSK is a competitive company in a competitive industry. As such, while they do attract incredibly smart and telented people, some of them were overly ambitious and focused entirely on advancing their careers at the expense of their subordinates. It was only a few people, but they were definitely not team players.

summary: Pathetic joke masquerading as a real company
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: It's a paycheck -  nothing more. Once the economy begins to revive, expect significant departures.  Some groups (very few), are reasonably good - good luck finding them, though.
cons_description: 'Ethics' are a pathetic joke, as is the leadership, but they are experts at spin-doctoring.  Promotions - when rarely given - are dispensed to pets and favorites, with no correlation as to talent or capability.  Very political and a who-knows-who environment - if you don't enjoy a-kissing or sucking up, STAY AWAY. Morale is non-existent - people are seriously overworked, overstressed and always looking over their shoulders for the next layoff festival to begin. If they developed and launched therapeutics with the frequency and enthusiasm that they downsized jobs, they would be a world class organization.

summary: I worked seven territories under five different managers in five years at GSK - change is constant.
author_title: Former Employee - Senior Executive Therapeutic Sales Representative
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: The people - coworkers and managers - were great almost across the board.  They tend to be hard-working and professional but still fun.
cons_description: The constant change is frustrating at best, and it's difficult to gain traction in one territory, selling one product or working for one manager.  Also, for the last three years the company has not compensated reps based on sales performance, but rather on how they've performed on written and verbal tests, etc.  This is disappointing for sales professionals that are results-oriented.  Finally, we all know big pharma is under a lot of scrutiny and is highly regulated, but GSK takes this to the next level.  They are the most conservative pharma company out there, and I believe this hinders the business.

cons_description:
Commercial:  Lots more processes compared to other companies, but this may change as GSK to stop sponsoring doctors. 

Medical: Possibly more compliance-oriented work compared to pure medical/scientific work. Check to see if this is still the case. Good place to start off in.

summary: Too many Chiefs, not enough Indians
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Better than working at a Fast Food Establishment!
cons_description: Management is stepping on each other to climb to the top. Good old Boys club.

summary: All things are difficult before they are easy!
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description:
Wages and benefit packages are suitable
There is promotions to move up the ladder 
Canteen
The general attitude to when someone leaves or its there b'day there is a celebration.  
Charity Work is outstanding
cons_description:
Where do I begin:
The minute I arrived I was treated extremely inappropriately for a large organisation.  
•	There was no training at all and was thrown in the deep end literally.   
•	I was told by a team member (on the first day) that I must never speak to higher management.
•	The systems are so outdated.  They use a system called JDE from the 1970s.  For anyone unfamiliar with JDE it’s MSDOS based which means training on all the F functions is required if you want to access any menus. This is not like an intuitive windows based or WYSIWYG system which anyone with good I.T. skills will figure out. The people with the knowledge on this system will not help you.  It’s as though they want to keep you in the dark so you look incompetent by having to constantly ask for help. Be prepared to teach yourself everything. What should be a simple task takes a long time to complete. This further highlights the deplorable lack of training.
•	All processes are extremely dragged out and not efficient for a Pharmaceutical company. Completing your own work and others work can be very upsetting and frustrating at times.    
•	In the interview the job I was told I would be doing was a customer based, administration role but in reality I did work I consider it was more the function of a finance controller.
•	You want to have a good knowledge of mathematics and be an excel whiz. The outdated system meant every department just created their own excel sheets for everything.  The shared network was a nightmare to navigate and you could spend a week searching for a folder. Instead of instinctively knowing where to search as is the case in a well organised company, you would email stakeholders with a hyperlink to every file path for this reason.
•	There are too many chiefs not enough Indians.  Everyone is a manager and many of them are not held to task as their managers are U.K based.
•	 They are not open to new ideas. Most of the staff are lifers and are resistant to change. They are happy doing things inefficiently because that’s just the way it is and done in this large company. If you thrive on progress this company with kill your enthusiasm and hope.
•	Frequent sick days by a number of permanent staff who were consistently and noticeably out sick. No flexibility with certain members of management. 
•	While a good social life is important in any work environment, I found the level of fraternising inappropriate on one team. This lead to an unpleasant working environment for anyone outside of this inner circle. Bullying was rampant.   
•	A number of people left within a very short space of commencing a new job because they couldn't work in such an unprofessional and unreasonably demanding environment. 
•	Even though I was only there a short time a number of new starts were required due to restructure and I would have conducted more training of new starts than the permanent staff, many of whom had been promoted. Their cosiness with management created an air of entitlement and laziness. While I could admire ability and talent in one or two of these staff members, the culture at GSK meant bad habits were learned and passed on to the next generation of ‘leaders’.  
•	Certain members of management didn't get to know you. They would listen to tales being told out of context rather than opening their eyes to what was actually going on around them. 
•	GSK do not give out references. On leaving I was not thanked for the work I had done and a management comments parting comment to me was “I hope you learnt something” and walked away.   I would class myself open and friendly and felt this behavior was not necessary.  
There is an air of bragging about working outside normal hours and weekends and is praised by certain management and then work is lacking during the week as these people are overtired/drained.
•	Communication between teams e.g. marketing and sales is appalling and key departments should be united on their objectives for the selling cycles.
I am a consummate professional and I take pride in my work. The culture at this company does not value this and any hint of ability or progress is seen as a threat. I never had a problem getting on with colleagues previous to joining this company. If you’re a shut up and put up kind of person who likes to collect a pay cheque regardless of how unfulfilling the work is, then this place would be a great place to work. You get a global brand on your CV which will help getting your next job no doubt. If, like me, you like working and enjoy a pleasant work environment, steer well clear.
•	On a positive note I did take away something from the experience, hold your guard up and always make sure you get a second interview where you can meet the other staff and ensure it is the environment for you.

cons_description: The local company has very little context or knowledge of the pharma industry and market. This situation is made worse when the management team are mainly foreigners and the local team are not capable to provide that valuable external insights to manage that knowledge gap. When the leaders are weak, and the subordinates are mere followers, there isn't much to look forward to.

The information systems and infrastructure is really, really obsolete. There are different systems for everything which makes the processes more and more complicated. There's no CI culture for integrating and simplifying.
No leadership at all.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: Really great work-life balance.  Most salaried employees within R&D are only required to work 35 hours per week.  Also, flexible work schedules are a nice bonus.
cons_description: Compensation is low compared to the industry.  There is no room for career advancement.  Many of the internal programs within R&D to promote top talent are advertised at a management level which is too high above those that are early on in their career (5-10 yrs in). Trying to move around within the organization is tough too.  Management doesn't value their internal employees as much as they do external job applicants.  The fact that middle managers within GSK have no confidence in their own workforce and would rather hire external pretty much sums up how they treat their employees once you get a job there.

author_title: Former Employee - M&A PM of Acquired Company
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description: Large company with great resources and some very sharp people and teams.  Reasonably logical organization that eventually gets the job done.

Constant down sizing and insensitive means to communicate this with the teams destroys any morale and sense of dedication.

summary: A very open and transparent culture
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than a year
pros_description:
An executive committee that is willing to listen with a real focus on developing leadership
Great opportunities for learning both interpersonal and functional skills
Wide window of opportunity for career advancement
Consistent focus on promoting an open, transparent and fun culture
Amazing CEO in Andrew Witty who is very inspiring and clearly an industry visionary
cons_description:
Mid-level management can be very autocratic and don't have the skills they need to deliver
A massive number of leadership teams with a confusing structure. It can take ages to get things done
Lots of bad press which is sometimes rather difficult to stomach (bribery, corruption etc.) on a personal level
If you are not part of the 'cool kids' club you tend to be left out pretty easily

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for less than a year
pros_description: I cannot think of any.
cons_description: Deceptive management, made my position redundant in order to employ the clinical director's wife whose position was being eliminated by the creation of a new company. I have since found out that the company's redundancy method was *illegal*, offering me no opportunities for redeployment. GSK is a company bereft of ethics, and I would not hesitate to recommend a friend or colleague to avoid them like the plague.

Everything was done by the books. 
You were given every tool you needed for success.

The job security also wasn't what you would imagine. Huge layoffs were a normal thing.

summary: USED to be a great place to work...
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 10 years
pros_description: Ability to apply for jobs in other departments. Good health insurance and retirement benefits.
cons_description: The senior-level and mid-level managers who once made this company great are all gone. GSK today is a company run by fear and suboptimal managers. The previous focus on sales and marketing is gone. What drives most decisions now is fear of legal action. The lawyers essentially run the company because they so significantly impact key decisions. Marketing and Sales have little say in key decisions anymore, and R&D has turned into a joke, with very little marketing/commercial input . R&D is wrought with number fudging and reluctance to terminate assets despite poor trial results. There is a systematic effort to make it appear there is a robust pipeline, when in fact, half the assets are seriously troubled. Short-term shareholders and legal fears are what drives the decision making at GSK. In addition, the company is pennywise and pound foolish, and many operations decisions are vehemently opposed by staff, which has destroyed morale.  Outsourcing is rampant and many managers in the US now have their admin assistants located in India. Yes, seriously. The fear of layoffs is pervasive and the stress levels are high. With so many layoffs and good people jumping ship, the morale has declined over the past 5-7 years. No one smiles, no one jokes around or has fun working. Unlike years past, it is now a miserable, depressing place to work. Stock options are worthless, promotions rarely occur, and the continuing a career at GSK has lost its appeal. The most highly regarded managers have been plucked away by other companies and only the bottom of the barrel remain. So much intellectual capital has been lost. It is a shame to have witnessed a once-great company slide so far downhill.

author_title: Current Employee - Senior Executive Pharmaceuticals Sales Representative
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 8 years
pros_description: Great big pharma experience at the local level due to tenured colleagues and managers. Excellent salary and benefits. Superb initial and ongoing training.
cons_description: Numerous recent changes in policies have seriously impaired sales reps ability to serve customers. Not incentivized based on sales but a convoluted system of test taking and manager reviews. Rumor mill is rampant and managers lead from behind rather than providing a clear vision based on reality. Big disconnect between corporate management and sales reps and not all local field managers do a very good job of supporting their teams.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description: It is an employee friendly organization. GSK gives you the freedom to implement. They believe in rotating employees through functions as opportunities arise.

summary: Getting tougher to enjoy your job...
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time
pros_description: great health benefits, 3 weeks vacation plus a week off at christmas and 2 additional personal days on top of paid holidays for employees during their first 10 years, car, unlimited gas (GSK deducts $75 per paycheck), most employees are great people, supportive on advancing career within GSK,
cons_description: very micro managed, most people are no longer motivated to sell because we aren't paid on sales, morale is very low, very difficult to build relationships with doctors and staff because lunches/in-services are so challenging to conduct under the new GSK Corporate Integrity Agreement which requires any health care provider to have an established customer identification number CID in order for you to give any item of value. very limited clinical resources for us to use in the field.  most people find the new incentive compensation system very demotivating and the manager grading system for rep reviews can be naturally very subjective.

summary: Good place to work, but now undergoing lots of changes that impact job satisfaction
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 5 years
pros_description:
Strong position in the global vaccines market
Expansion in Asia through joint ventures
Substantial pipeline of new prophylactic and therapeutic vaccines
Leading position in adjuvant technology
cons_description:
Currently implementing a 'smart working' (open office, no assigned spaces) office environment in many parts of the business, which is a terrible work environment compared to what was the norm until 2012
Cost cutting is reducing opportinities for profesional development
Moving more toward use of 'in contractors' rather than employees in many functions
Not enough interaction with other parts of GSK in areas of mutual interst, such as nonclincial safety, and too much of a 'stove pipe' mentality in Belgian operations
Too much bureaucracy in many functions, especially for contracts and publications

cons_description: This site has yet to make a block buster drug so the drug product being manufactured constantly changes, causing unfortunate changes in shifts, schedules and titles.  Opportunities to move within are limited during these periods.

By and large a good review and appraisal system.

summary: Horrible company that won't survive long
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline full-time for more than 3 years
pros_description: The people below the VP level - that is about it. The older executives that have been 'real' GSK folks generally care about people and have interest in others developing and the greater good of the patient.
cons_description:
The new executives (VP+) moving in (mostly from Lilly) are motivated by power and carnage without any concern for employees, selling drugs or helping patients. 
Too many people for the number of products. 
Focus is on checking boxes rather than innovation
Legal oversight has paralyzed the employee
Have to get everyone's approval before you go to the bathroom - too much micro-management. Sucks the life out of innovation!
Negative culture with everyone unhappy

cons_description: They changed how they compensate sales people, now it's pretty subjective, not based on numbers. I'm no longer there, but here that most reps are unhappy about the new plan.

work culture is nice

unnecessary training and seminars

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great benefits and employer contributions to 401K. Three weeks vacation your first year, plus company shut down last week of December.
cons_description: Company has gone through too many changes over the past few years. The quotas set for reps were seriously unattainable and created a lot of dissatisfaction, which forced many employees to leave the company.

summary: Great flexibility, ability to work from home at least a few days per weeks, bad communication, overall not bad at all.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Flexibility, work from home (or remotely), most managers are not constantly over your shoulders, pretty good pay and benefits.
cons_description: Due to flexibility very difficult to meet people face2face.  Lot of CYA type activities due to matrix type organization.  Sometimes I do not see my manager for weeks, this could be good and bad.  Things that used to take 4 weeks at a smaller company, take about 2 to 3 months here because it's tough to get people together.  Expect to work long hours and odd hours as parts of you team may be based all over the world and thus, late evenings for Australia meetings and Early AM for UK meetings.  Management impliments processes without input from the folks who actually have to live with it.  A lot of Knee Jerk Reactions.  People are over worked.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Large company, with good employee working conditions, respect for employees and opportunities to grow. Managers typically find healthy balance between work and life for their teams.
cons_description: Its size can sometimes mean it moves very slowly.  Over the long term job progression comes for those who put in the effort and get results, but the onus is mostly on the employee to drive their own careers. Moving around the business can be difficult,  but is possible for the persistent.  Long term employees means there can be a mix of abilities.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Open culture about interacting with superiors and top management. Strong commitment to one area of interest epecially future is determined not just by one function supervision but how other departments feel about the candidate
cons_description: Focus on single brand that might lead to market detoriaration. Need to quickly understand the key developments and build another Horlicks brand.

summary: Great learning experience and supportive environment, rigid project environment
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
-Great athletic / recreational facilities. Good company-wide intramural sport support
-Great work-life balance. 35 hr work weeks and half day Fridays, can leave after lunch
cons_description:
-Resistance to change due to lack of budgeting allocated to projects and strict quality/safety controls
-Difficult to measure and predict impact of work and projects due to the nature of highly documented and regulated manufacturing, lack of accomplishment at the end of the day

summary: Work can be quite repetitive at times.

cons_description: Very boring. Work is very repetitive.

summary: Once a great place to work.

cons_description: Several, significant rounds of downsizing continue to make the office a tough place to work.  Headquarters outside of the U.S.

summary: Good place to work - great pay and benefits

pros_description: Great pay and benefits - by far the best I've come across, compared to other industries. Friendly people. Collaborative work environment.
cons_description: Not much talent. Was surprised to see people with such limited knowledge and skills. So, was not able to learn much from my colleagues. A lot of 'dead' weight and lazy employees who do as little as possible and are able to get away with it. Not much opportunity in Philadelphia vs RTP or London.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Product set is fantastic, and the challenges are great. Some of the people working there are super smart and want to take on the challenges. These are the people that are getting dissapointed and dissillusioned by the rest.

The IT team there is fantastic, although they do not have enough engagement with the business, and this is a key area for improvement across departments.
cons_description:
Management culture is one of fear and stagnation. One would hope that the new Operations CEO Christophe Weber will put some rocket fuel in and also loose some of the dead-wood. They look like a potential Nokia with many of their current management staff.

Managing by looking upwards to what they consider management expectations rather than downwards to what is actually happening on the ground is a critical issue.

Real growth will come form emerging markets, and profitability from moving production from Belgium to overseas. Also remove the 'scientific' approach in management, to a more business based approach will be key.

summary: A good stable place to work
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Competent Leaders who know what they are doing. Good stable place to work . Strong  expertise in their chosen category and industry
cons_description: Can get to be a bit slow. The industry is quite stable so limited new growth opportunities. Not the most innovative company

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Globally recognized organization. Excellent Phramceutical products.
cons_description: The opportunities that existed have slowly faded away. Budget cuts are restricting education, travel. Upgrades to IT hardware and software are minimized. Morale is low as the constant restructing/outsourcing/downsizing takes place. So called smart office space (table and chair) instead of a cube/office or personal space makes for a challenging work environment. No clear career path or room for advancement.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Glaxo Smith Kline provides competitive salaries and great benefits to employees. At Glaxo Smith Kline your coworkers become some of your best friends
cons_description: They tend to focus on getting rid of older workers and bringing in new, younger ones. This is true for most plces though

summary: Great place to work and have a good life balance
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
GSK has a great Work Life Balance
The Salary at GSK is competitive
Benefits are great
Gym is nice
The  drug pipeline is full of new and great things
cons_description:
Stability, working with alot of contractors
Review process could be better
Lay offs are frequent in some departments
Large groups, you can feel lost at times
Less departmental awards and more individuals

summary: There was no career growth within the global organization.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great work and life.  Flexible hours and good immediate managers.
cons_description: No career growth if you aren't in one of the headquarter locations.

summary: Learned a lot but people are afraid to offer constructive criticism or to be risk takers.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Excellent products.  Good pay and benefits.  Well respected in the industry.
cons_description: People are expected to keep their heads down and get their work done.  Not an environment that fosters collaboration or innovation.

summary: Learned a lot but people are afraid to offer constructive criticism or to be risk takers.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Excellent products.  Good pay and benefits.  Well respected in the industry.
cons_description: People are expected to keep their heads down and get their work done.  Not an environment that fosters collaboration or innovation.

summary: good. If you show interests you can have some opportunities to grow in.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: great place to work. Growing up in this Company. You have some possibilities to prove your competence and your interest.
cons_description: It's a big company so it's very hard to move some things. When you work on production. It's difficult to have flexibility to organize your schedule.

summary: Financially beneficial. Limited advancement within the Department.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great pay and benefits.  Generally good physical working conditions.  Good bonuses.
cons_description: Very limited promotion opportunity within department without taking a role in another department or location.  Toxic working conditions from corporate restructuring.  Constant fear of RIF.

summary: A waste of 10 years of my life.  No career opportunities unless you enter the company on a high grade i.e. as a student
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Salary but you pay a price.
cons_description: No opportunities of promotion despite having a 'Performance Development Plan' and constantly achieving and exceeding targets.  You can train and develop to your hearts content and strive to do well but at the end of the day it's up to the line managers who they employ.  I know many people high up in the company who have been forced out of their department due to changes and bad management.  Went from having a great job to having no proper job description and being kept on because of my headcount.

summary: It's OK - but hope you get a good manager and department leader/VP
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
They do really good things for people who need their medicines.
They have some innovative management ideas.
Advancement is available.
cons_description:
Don't get stuck in a bad department.
As with any job, networking and getting your personal brand known is key to moving up.
Increased litigation and legislation unfavorable to US pharmaceuticals has led to most leadership positions moving to London, UK.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Research seems well funded.  Seems very patient focused.
cons_description: Not sue what the downsizing, reorganizing and eliminating offices will do to the culture.  May be necessary but outside consultants may  be thinking simply 'bricks & mortar'.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great pay with awesome environment. Very good products
cons_description: Your job enjoyment depends on your district manager.  Always afraid you're going to be laid off.

summary: My experience at GlaxoSmithKline has been challenging and rewarding.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: The benefits at GlaxoSmithKline are among the best, if not the best. This company rewards you with attractive wages, bonus opportunities, and company sponsored family events.
cons_description: The downsides of working at GlaxoSmithKline Memphis are the opportunities for higher level jobs and positions are very few and limited, and limited sustainable products.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: I was part of a team of very intelligent individuals.  Each from their own background, I was able to learn a lot.
cons_description: Management always seemed off in their 'own little world.'  The problems the team faced were brought to attention but never really addressed.

summary: Overall, GSK is has been an excellent company to work for these past many years.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: The opportunities for training and promotion over the years have been broad. For the most part, the product portfolio has been rich and plentiful. Having a well resourced company to back your sales efforts in the field is very important. GSK has many valuable resources that it shares with the employees. The compensation plan is second to none. The benefit package is first class and will support you and your family throughout your career and beyond.
cons_description: Because of the sheer size, the individual territory can become lost and misrepresented. When change is implemented it is top down with little input from those that will be most affected. The patent cliff and the putting up with the reluctance of the FDA to make new product approvals has stymied growth. That has led to fewer promotional opportunities and advancement. Representatives not challenged to sell, but to increase perceived customer value and do well on corporate exams, while managers are challenged to meet the corporate sales objectives and to not harass sales performance from representatives.

summary: Very interesting work but they are not fair in rewarding achievements
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Interesting work on global projects
cons_description: Not much career development or advancement fairness for promotions

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Benefits are pretty good, though bonuses are capped now and no longer based on sales.  Great products.
cons_description: The course and strategy is constantly changing.  It is hard to get behind the latest strategy when you know it will change in 6 months to a year anyway.  The word of the decade is transparency, but there is little transparency.  Every manager goes on and on about work/life balance, but it is all talk.

summary: Not the best place to work
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Benefits such as health insurance, dental, pension, etc
Most of the employees are good hardworking people that want to do the right thing.
cons_description:
Inflexible
Inconsistent
Not family friendly
I'm not sure who keeps voting for GSK as one of the Best Places to Work...it must be HR, because it most certainly is not. 
Does not understand work-life balance.
Limited promotion and advancement opportunities
Toxic environment due to continuous layoffs....the morale is very bad in the company.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good salary , good working environment, development opportunities
cons_description: Poor promotion prospects, minimal development opprotunies

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good health care benefits,  pension plan and 401k plan
cons_description: Weak ethics from GSK Managers who compromise ethics to sell pills, e.g., Avandia

author_title: Business Planning and Analysis Project Manager
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: It's a global company that contributes to world pharmceutical  development and improved consumer healthcare. opportunities abound and depending on your location career development is encouraging.
cons_description: Company culture is not consistent across all markets as it should be, so mobility can be difficult, which can be dissapointing for the ambitious.

summary: Great company, needs to streamline more
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Fantastic benefits, needs to follow through on process improvement
cons_description: The pipeline seem to be shrinking

summary: once a wonderful company....now the joke of the industry
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: the benefits - that's about it
cons_description:
No work life balance
Micromanagement
constant turmoil and change 
reinventing the wheel

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good benefits and higher wages than other companies at many positions
cons_description: Management from the top levels is often inconsistent in word and action, providing ample motivation for good employees to leave

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Management cares about employees' work/life balance
Opportunities to advance
Excellent Benefits - pension, 401k, shutdown, paid time off, vacation, etc.
cons_description: Company does not embrace employees working remotely - hence I had to leave after 5 years.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
1. Good environment and work culture
2. Great place for starters
3. Work-life balance is better
4. Excellent training opportunities
cons_description:
1. Poor salary structure
2. Lack of fairness and transparency
3. Dearth or employee benefits
4. Bureaucracy in decision making
5. Inefficient local leadership

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
work life balance is good for most people
salary is good
manager is awesome person
cons_description: the leadership stinks, no idea where they want to go

summary: confusing due to too many people in processes
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: the company offers many job opportunities as the site is very large and opportunities can be taken from very different departments
cons_description: the company is structured in a such way that it's too hierarchical and any decision needs a lot a time to be validated

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Great management team
Very close friendships are made
People usually stay with this company for years
cons_description: It's hard to meet new people, sometimes it's 'clique-ish'

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: They hire good People at GSK
cons_description: Industry Changes have hurt every pharmaceutical company

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: GSK is positioning its self for the future and there are a lot of changes taking place.  This allows employees to be instumental in shaping the changes and make a significant impact over how business will be conducted over the next few years
cons_description: Changes are occuring quickly and at times this leads to gaps in information, capabilites, and history to allow business to function effectively currently

summary: Frustrating, great products, lots of potential, lack of senior mgt leadership
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great products, great people.  Customers want to use vaccines, but business/contracting keep them from using GSK products.
cons_description: Senior management can't decide how to market vaccines.  Contracting is KEY and GSK is WAY behind the competition.  Piloting different markets to see what might be more successful.

summary: My experience was ok, that's about it
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: I don't have any!  I enjoyed the people but in general too much management overseeing...very little independence.  I found that when we worked as teams people were able to do little work and rest on the laurels of others.
cons_description: I would say the downside to working at GlakySmithKline was the inability to progress upward in terms of job opportunities.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: benefits package, helpful coworkers, beautiful campus, motivating atmosphere, state of the art equipment, amazing management, networking, versatility to cross train in various areas
cons_description: politics, some nepotism, difficult to get interview, commute, no 'park and ride', well-qualified workers easily replaced by new graduates, many positions start as contract positions

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Large company

Fair compensation and great benefits

More resources

Regular hours

Work/life balance
cons_description:
Large company politics

Multiple years of staff reductions draining the talent pool in many areas

Losing institutional knowledge in favor of lowering costs

summary: Management does not appreciate employees experience or knowledge
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great benefits and for the most part pay scale.  Have made alot of life-long friends
cons_description: Alot of favoritism and many opportunities for advancement, especially if you do not have a Master's degree.  They value degrees over knowledge and experience except for their executive team who half only had Master degrees or above.  Work environment is dismal due to so many cutbacks and work overload.

summary: Great pay, benefits and work life balance.  Opportunities for promotion and development are lacking.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: The benefits, pay, retirement plan and perks (company car, computer, phone, internet etc.) are second to none.  If you want to be a territory level sales representative for the rest of your career this is a great place to work.
cons_description:
Even after earning multiple tier awards, consistent rankings in the top 20% nationally, regional development programs, training experience and data analyst roles no opportunities for promotion outside of the territory level were available.  I was denied multiple opportunities for rotations outside of the territory with no explanation or face to face interaction.  Specialty sales positions are filled behind closed doors with no interview process or transparency.  My perception as a territory level
sales representative was that I would never be able to move into another position no matter what my national ranking or performance reviews showed.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Interesting projects with many intelligent people. There are opportunities to work in areas of particular interest to you. Some great managers. Opportunities for training.
cons_description: Decent work-life balance, but could be better. Pay can be at lower end for similar work at other pharma companies.

summary: Better than most big pharma companies.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Competitive pay, good benefits, generally good management.  Like all companies, there are a few managers that everyone hates that seem to be retained for reasons unknown; most managers are decent people.  The products are good and recognized brands the world over.  Good job to go to if you are in 20's to 30's.
cons_description: Recent layoffs seemed to focus on the over  forty age groups.  Being a sales rep in certain regions will be harder due to poor access to customers.  Products are good but are aging and facing plenty of generic and me-too product competition, which  means more micro-management as profits taper off.  This it typical of many big pharma Co's.  They have a good future pipeline, but introduction time lines are a guessing game.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Above-average compensation and benefits pkg. Depending upon the area of business, telecommuting is encouraged.
cons_description: Communication is poor. Sr. mgmt ignores workers in the trenches. Many of the fringe benefits--e.g. childcare subsidy; quality cafeteria/fitness centers--have been taken away completely or are of exceptionally poor quality. Work/life balance is constantly talked about, but not actually encouraged (i.e. ongoing layoffs have resulted in fewer people doing more work and, thus, working long hours, including many weekends).

summary: Rewarding work with competant, respectful and intelligent colleagues.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: GSK allows conduct of research that can prove extremely beneficial to patients all over the work. Although there are many unnecessary tasks assigned it is still a great company to work for.
cons_description: There are a great deal of unnecessary tasks assigned by  the Senior Executive Team, which they feel will improved efficiency of the organization.

summary: Great place to work, supportive culture
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Excellent training, no hierarchy, supportive culture, excellent products, coaching and sales support, competitive remuneration, great place for working mothers, opportunity for growth and learning, honest and supportive management, excellent diversity
cons_description: Opportunities for advancement are limited, and often the choice for promotions appear irrational when viewed in light of candidates' respective backgrounds and achievements

summary: Great people, Great learning, but stress and workload creates a toxic environment
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great group of professional people all committed to success. Lots of opportunities to learn new things and processes to to ensure disciplined work ethic.
cons_description: Management (globally and locally) always changing strategies and over-reacting rather than staying on course.  Expectations are high for productivity and work-life balance is impacted.  Empowerment is preached but rarely practiced.

summary: A rewarding and challenging place to work with great career opportunities if you are willing to work for it!
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Great compensation
Great corporate culture
Great colleagues to work with
cons_description: Limited product pipeline and unclear bonus structure

summary: It was mixed, some good , some bad
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Solid company, and good products
cons_description: They damaged  their  reputation and credibility.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great training. Years for low sales of company they still provided compensation through bonus
cons_description: No feedback from managers. Never given anything to improve upon. Benefits ok

summary: Not that good, micromanaging managers, failing products, lawsuits
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Car, benefits, a salary, small territory, some of the people okay, not doing much for your sAlalry, free gas and
cons_description: Micromanaging, low pay, boring, poor upper mngmt, small minded business policies, products that are me too drugs, drugs have many lawsuits pending

summary: Stimulating customer base and information allowiing me  opportunities to improve peoples lives with the medicine I sold.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Working with wonderful peers and doctors. Continuing education and updates on products. Fabulous salary and benefits!
cons_description: The ongoing restructuring and insecurity about job status, folling with severe downsizing. No loyalty to employees on any level except at the top management levels.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Dynamic company with double digit of growht. Business orriented on positive value to improve the life of people. Quickly you can received strong responsability. Multicultural company.
cons_description: Low flexibility and strong resistance of change. Many many hierarchic level reducing pro-activity and empowerement. Decision are not taken by the good chanel.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great place to work, lots of projects to take part in. Management is respectful and professional to all employees, and the food is great (their own cafeteria)
cons_description: Not much room for growth in this corporate ladder. People are great overall if you get to know them enough.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: It offers a pension which a lot of companies do not do in this economy
cons_description: It was extremely stressful and overwhelming at times.

summary: Overall, outstanding company to work, especially if you start in sales.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Flexible work schedule and excellent benefits compared to most companies.
cons_description: Continual rightsizing and restructuring of company making it difficult to create a niche for yourself. Must be able to adapt quickly.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: good benefits, health care, produts.
cons_description: the environment at the company is always changing

summary: Great place to work but future not looking good.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Mid Level management is typically very good.  Products have been solid up til now.  Most 90% of employees are ethical.
cons_description: Not sure about competency of top level management. Not sure if pipeline will sustain adequate future growth.  Management moving away from selling and moving to customer service model.

summary: Very good until the last 5 years.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Well respected in the medical and scientific community. Excellent dedication to doing the right thing to help patients recieve the medications they need even if it meant providing it for free if possible.
Very Committed to World Wide Health Care.  especially in treatment and elimination of disease in the 3rd world communities....HIV AIDS, Hepatitis, Malaria, elephantisis etc. Agressive research and scientific commitment
cons_description: Legal & regulatory had too much control over operations.  Employee often found out company news or product concerns with the public.  Like many large companies employees became more of a number than a colleague ...stress levels placed on all employees is extreemely high 10 on a 1-10

summary: Proud to have worked for GSK and appreciated my team and support of regional leadership
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Excellent training and opportunities for career advancement.  Team environment and supportive local leadership.  Great benefits, company car, 401k, vacation and competitive salary.
cons_description: Senior corporate leadership team is not as transparent as they like to think.  No such thing as work/life balance.  Issues and inconsistency with how sales data is gathered and reported back to the local rep level, which is unfortunately used to rank performance and determine promotions, etc.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: great salary and benefits provided
cons_description: long hours are expected of most

summary: Organisation trying to evolve but burdened by legacy and conservatism

pros_description: Great colleagues, working environment and work life balance.
cons_description: Below the 50% percentile in terms of pay and bonuses.

pros_description:
Enter to pharma industry, less volatile industry
Core business unit within GSK
cons_description: financial system is out of date

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great location since close to lake Garda and the mountains
cons_description: Low staff turnover so difficult to progress

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: great benefits, great pension, 401 K, health insurance
cons_description: slower growth for promotion, long commute

summary: Nice people, laid-back atmosphere, hard to move around company.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Nice people to work with.
Lots of info available to employees on website.
Laid-back atmosphere. Not high pressure.
Company has a good name.
cons_description:
Salaries are not great but not bad.
Hard to move around within company.
Rarely got a response to applying directly to positions on website even as a contractor.

summary: My experience was fantastic until 2008, absolute terrible management of the sales force after that.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: My years with Smithkline Beecham 1998 to GSK 2007 were great.  I always knew what was expected of me in the sales capacity.  They were a very fair and wonderful to work for.  The change in 2008 was defintely for the worse.  I understand layoffs and downturn in business is part of a cycle and expected but upper management has absolutely no direction and has completely demotivated the entire sales force.  It is incredibly unbelieveable, a complete shame.
cons_description: Not a sales organization anymore.  Going for customer service.  Not happy about this because I am a shareholder.  Lost several co-promotions based on sales(non-sales structure).  Upper management keeps changing sales structure; this makes sales team realize they have no idea what they are doing.  Very demotivated sales team.

summary: Wonderful at the start, but caught up in reorganization strategies of company at the end.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Large Pharma with great possibilities if you are willing to move to emerging markets.
 Competitive salaries and benefit packages.
cons_description: Company currently reorganizing to focus on emerging markets. Focus on Western economies and investing in western expansion being reduced dramatically.

summary: GSK has been personally rewarding to me.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: You'll find good people at Franklin Plaza in Philadelphia.  Employees are ethical and strive to be fully compliant to FDA regulations.  A strategic focus dominates business operations.
cons_description: Strategically strong, culturally weak.  Morale has been battered by external issues such as Avandia and by never-ending corporate restructuring.   Building is an absolute dump.

summary: A company with no direction lost in the ever-changing healthcare environment.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great products and very customer focused
cons_description:
Extremely political organization. Many promotions and employee evalutions made on perception.
Those in head office spoke of a very negative working environment where others would do anything to get ahead of you.

summary: Helpful colleagues, very good manager, very flexible work schedule.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline

Very flexible work schedule.
Work personal life balanced.
cons_description: Sadly, its not a software company.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: GSK is a great place to work at. People are respectful and work is very challenging. I love working there.
cons_description: There's some stress sometimes, but it's not just at GSK. Maybe a little too far from my place, but that's ok now.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Relaxed atmosphere that promotes camaraderie

No clear path for career advancement.
No introductory training in company operations specific to the laboratory.
Frequently changed course and reshuffled staff and managers which stunted bench scientists growth and development.

summary: Low pay but very supportive of the individual.

pros_description: My managers cared about the people with whom they worked.
cons_description: Too much disparity in pay.

summary: It was a good overall experience.

pros_description: Great people and work environment.
cons_description: Too many changes occuring at the time I was there.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Respect for people, good package, great spirit among employees
cons_description: not enough initiatives at local level.  Think globaly, act locally should be more applied

summary: Great place to work, great people and attitude
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good working environment, great attitude and people.
cons_description: Industry generally restructiring and has been for years. Limits job security.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Working at gsk is satisfying as if allows you to know there is job security and the company itself is out to help the community
cons_description: The bad side to side at gsk is the hours can be long and people can be obnoxious. Some people get away with murder

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Average work - average pay
free food
good work life balance especially for married woman'
flexible timings
medical insurance
very good vacation
support for higher education
cons_description:
no transport
no cafe
less infra structure facilities
less pay for laterals
too much of policies or restrictins some times

summary: A great place to work and be a leader
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: GSK has great values which I truly believe in and can stand behind. I'm proud to work for a company that continues to give back (be patient focused, Commit to transparency, Always demonstrate the highest integrity in our conduct, show respect to people)
cons_description: As like all Pharmaceutical companies within the industry, this work can be stressful and very competitive. One could get lost, demotivated and frustrated if not grounded in knowing why they are there (patient first).

summary: Love working here, but company is getting too strict with guidelines, making it a more difficult place to do your job
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great people, great benefits.  Car, free gas.  Flexibility, good pay
cons_description: not as stable as it used to be.  Lots of reorganization/changes/layoffs in recent years.  Lack of consistency with senior leadership team-changing the rules in the middle of the game.  GSK is so scared of doing anything out of compliance that sales reps are finding it harder and harder to be able to sell.  As of 2011, there will no longer be individual goals or sales achievements

summary: Good company, but different departments vary from working culture, selected for promotion, etc.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: good compensation package at certain level
cons_description: Try to cut cost, but they may not know they waste tons of money on the projects because of the leadership.

summary: Good company, but different departments vary from working culture, selected for promotion, etc.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: good compensation package at certain level
cons_description: Try to cut cost, but they may not know they waste tons of money on the projects because of the leadership.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: great benefits, ability to work remotely
cons_description: tough to get into senior management.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Career progression is achievable if follow the correct processes
cons_description: Benefits is par below the industry standard

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Salary, good benefits, challenging job
cons_description: Marketing messaging was not very good

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Coworkers are good people to work with.
Overall benefits are good.
Proactive in promoting wellness and healthy lifestyle choices.
Products typically strong clinically.
cons_description:
Direction of company via Senior Management.
Lack of input allowed from employees on decisions by Senior Management.
Every decision is made from a legal sense and how the company should minimize it's potential exposure to litigation.
Consultant driven management.

summary: Andrew is diversifying and building new markets  but US is a mess
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great health and retirement benefits w pension plan,  strong leadership at local level. pay for performance uncapped bonus, reasonable goals
cons_description: National leadership is lost and fumbling.  New Natinal Sales Manager doesn't believe in importance of relationships to sales and shifts territories and reps with alarming regularity,  changing sales force to rep for hire w/ 3 yr contracts and less benefits no chance for longterm employment.  New bonus program not based on performance rather on customer feedback sort of...  NO place for a real performer.

summary: Primary Care Pharma is a dying industry
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: GSK has some really good growth opporunities working for such a large company and even better is the location for other Pharma jobs.
cons_description: If you aren't Johnson and Johnson or Pfizer it is hard to compete with the larger Pharma companies in terms of size.

summary: Great place to work but be prepared to work overseas.  Mobility is essential to advancement.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Global company in a very profitable industry.  The company has consistently raised its game in the kind of marketing it does.  Very focussed on bringing new products to market that deliver incremental sales.
cons_description: Being a Brit or European can be an advantage even in the U.S.  Americans have not fared well in the upper reaches of management.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: People here are nice. And GSK is a big Company. I have a really good manager here. Salary is OK for me.
cons_description: They do not hire many young professionals. They may have some reform next year and may fired some employers.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: There are great benefits to working for GSK. Its modern and fast paced environment. Facilties and technology is all new.
cons_description: Over the last couple of years and the current economic climate, alot of redundancies have made the atmosphere amongst staff a bit 'off'

summary: Great company in a troubled industry
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Some of the things I appreciate about GSK, accountability, respect for employees, good benefits package, fair pay.  Traditional opportunities and advancement are hard to come by, but that doesn't mean there aren't development opportunities out there.  You need to take the reigns, no one will do it for you (I state the obvious because many people here seem to expect someone else to be managing their careers for them).  The current leadership team is very aggressive, but they respect a work/life balance.
cons_description: The industry is going through some big changes, changes that may take 10-20 years to work themselves out.  Be prepared for that when choosing a career in Pharma.  If you're not directly related to drug development and sales, this may not be the best place to focus your career.  But that being said, people will always need medicine, so if your style is compatible with the leadership of the company, go for it.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Incredible flexability and freedom within the company. Can work from home any time.
cons_description: Mostly contract work, and not too many full time positions.

summary: I enjoyed my years with GSK Consumer Health Care
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great culture, good products, great work-life balance.  Strong tenure of employment with high level of intellectual capital.  Extremely low turnover.
cons_description: Moved to a US model which eliminated the retail and account management in favor of a broker.  Limited opportunity to move in sales due to low turnover.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: great people, benefits, mission and vision/objectives
cons_description: tough time in biopharma, generics, healthcare reform challenging biopharmas to hand over millions.  think R&D arena will strengthen over time.  Commercial support will probably be outsourced.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Flexible,great benefits and conpensation, excellent training
cons_description: not as respected as pharma counterpart

summary: Was a good place to work, but not any more.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Overall a good working environment and friendly competent people to work with, but with cost cutting in IT they are constantly laying off staff every year since 2000.  IT is no longer a place to be at GSK.
cons_description: Everyone is worried about their jobs in IT.  Morale is low, productivity is adversely impacted.

summary: GlaxoSmithKline is a great place for Senior Managers.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: 1.  Great place to work for Senior Managers.
cons_description: 1.  Talent development is not a priority for junior employees.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
def not rocket science
great perks
flexible
cons_description:
No one makes any $$$ any more (relative)
seems like there are layoffs every year...wait.....there are layoffs every year..lol

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: People are great, work is challenging
cons_description: Since I was contracted by a temp agency, I recieved no benefits and was not able to apply for a permanent position.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Teamwork atmosphere within territory.
Supportive First line management.
cons_description: Missed opportunity for overall success when a 'one size fits all' approach is expected without room for flexibilty.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Teamwork atmosphere within territory.
Supportive First line management.
cons_description: Missed opportunity for overall success when a 'one size fits all' approach is expected without room for flexibilty.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: You are given ownership of a territory to build sales.  What you do and how you perform directly affects your success.  You are recognized for this success on a district and regional level.
cons_description: Some of the initiatives were not relevant to certain areas.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: International company with many areas to work
cons_description: Hostile work environment little regard for sales

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good benefit package compared with other industries.  People are nice.
cons_description: Working at GSK CHC can be very nice if you are able to look beyond the internal politcs.  Promotions are given to friends of managers and not to people who have the ability to do the job.  There is low turnover due to benefits and associates without education, who would be hard pressed to obtain the same salary and benefits package elsewhere.  With the many layoffs and uncertainty, GSK is a very stressful and an uncertian environment to work in.  GSK used to be about the people, now it is a company with bottom line concens as the main focus. People are an after thought if thought of at all.

summary: An interesting place during this time of transition
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
- great co-workers
- Committed to work together
- Flexible work environment
- Better than average benefit package
- vacation and holidays
cons_description:
- weak management regarding transition
- Senior Management below C-level - weak at best.  Seems as if they are just waiting to retire.
- Communication lacking

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: I enjoyed the opportunities for career advancement and the time and money they invested for training.  There were plenty of resources made available for self improvement and often a job well done was recogonized.
cons_description: Unfortunately I was affected by the first round of lay offs the company had back in 2008. I must say the company completely lacked transparency during this stressful time for the employees. They did not share any information about the company reorganization until 2 months prior to lay offs.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Great Place to work at Parsippany, NJ
Great Benefits, Good Work Environment.
cons_description: Low Pay, Frequesnt layoffs from the last 4 years. Flat Org Structure and management does not believe in changing the flat structure.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good enviroment to work, opportunity to growth.
cons_description: Management always said that the company wasn't for sale and they sold it.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Pros

Great pay
Great Benefits
Good 401K
Treated people well when they are let go
cons_description:
Constant downsizing.
Manages through threats and intimidation.
Company is struggling in the US, so top management constantly makes changes and never gives changes enough time to work.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good training, salary, benefits, chance to work set your own work schedule, routing, little supervision for field personnel if you prove yourself competent and trustworthy.
cons_description: Old products, only look at numbers and not individual employees in sales, layoffs for last three years, no job security.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: GSK has competitive wages and compensation.  They Strive to be professional in their dealings with personnel and the public.  Their products are usually of high quality and offer unique advantages to patients.
cons_description:
GSK has become so large that they now place legal liability as their driving concern.  Sales plans are now so restricted and ultra conservative that they seem written directly by the legal department.  If you have to ask whether you can do something the answer in inevitably, 'no, let's just be safe'.

Sales goals and compensation plans are also so one-size-fits-all that they can not adequately compensate for huge differences in marketplace demographics and trends.  Better hope you work in a growing city in the south, especially Florida, if you want consistent bonus opportunities.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Global company. Interesting international culture environment. Entrepreneurial atmosphere.
cons_description: Hard to get a promotion that you really deserve. Lower salary range than other companies.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: very good benefits, fair compensation, local management more in tune with the realities of the marketplace
cons_description: A great deal of regulation and little support from upper management; a more chaotic and reactionary atmosphere currently

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Great pay
Great Benefits
Good 401K
Treated people well when they are let go. I was there only a few yrs and they gave me a good package.
cons_description:
Too many Chiefs, not enough worker bees.  Overall, not a bad place. Vacation time is just ok.
Always reorganizing which causes people to fearing from losing there job and not focused on doing there job.

summary: Comfortable place for a job; not a place for a career
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Strong work life balance ethic...though the overall equations seems to be changing in favour of work under the leadership of the new CEO.
cons_description: Movement within the organization is almost impossible.  Company has be in a constant reorg mode for the last 3 years...likely to continue.  If you do not function well in uncertainty this is not the place for you.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Benefits are quite good compared to other companies.
cons_description: Expectation is that you will work all the time.

summary: I hope it's just my department
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Convenient location, flexible work options, corporate shutdown at the end of the year
cons_description: Management favoritism, lack of development, lack of communication by upper management, career advancement opportunities are few and far between, no cost of living raises offered,

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
GlaxoSmithKline is one of the biggest Pharma companies world-wide, so the name recognition stands out on a resume.
Because of the large amount of money in big pharma, the technology here is superior to what you might find at a smaller company.
cons_description:
NO job security.
No feedback, advice, encouragement, or even any communication with supervisors and upper management. 
No sense of direction or work importance.
No hope for being hired full-time after completion of co-op.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Large pharma experience and multiple business units to choose from.
cons_description: Fragmented decision making and poor advancement potential.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: company full of very bright people with the passion to help others do more, feel better and live longer.     Vibrant place to work with great benefits
cons_description: company is hurting financially.  many patent expirations and no products near FDA approval.  touch times lie ahead

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: company full of very bright people with the passion to help others do more, feel better and live longer.     Vibrant place to work with great benefits
cons_description: company is hurting financially.  many patent expirations and no products near FDA approval.  touch times lie ahead

summary: GSK is a good company to work for.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Excellent products and research pipeline; excellent salary & benefits; very good middle management; excellent reputation with customers, high quality sales representatives to work with; flexible when one needs time off.
cons_description: Downsides are common to the industry: increasing level of micromanagement by marketing, decreased access to physician customers; pressure of deadlines and reporting responsibilities. Nothing that would be significantly different at another pharma company, and better than many.

summary: Great Company. But you are just a NUMBER
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great place. Good compensationa nd benefits. Best training I ever had for sales.
cons_description: You are just a number. Bad economic time you will be cut. You do two ride alongs with your boss a month; which is fine. But if your numbers for the week are bad then he will be on your butt aboout it. Micromanaging. Business doesnt always have to be threw the roof.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
- almost impossible to get fired
- interesting pool of expertise
- international work environment
- only large company in the area
cons_description:
- very hierarchical
- personal contacts count more than they should in terms of who gets promoted
- poor work-life balance

summary: GSK is a good place to work
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great company mission, lots of passion for the work. Good work environment in most businesses.Company serious about ensuring its future success, which is why there is so much change at the moment.
cons_description: Lots of change and uncertainty. People under pressure to move fast and be agile, which impacts quality and quantity of communication and thoughtfulness in doing the work. More work piled onto managers. Less respect for people than there used to be (although could be on par with other companies).

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: The benefits that Glaxo Smith Kline offers are comparable if not a bit better that other companies I have worked for.
cons_description: Upper management talks a lot about the need to be transparent with both its employees and its customers but I do not see that happening.  Retroactive performance improvement plans, being told that layoffs would not be happening (then they do), are two examples of lack of transparency and respect for its employees.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good salary and benefits, very nice people to work with in general, emphasis on health and well-being of employees, I happen to have a great manager.
cons_description: Senior management seems out of touch with what goes on 'in the trenches', inequality in workloads, promotions don't match performance, work overload.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good products lots of industry firsts
cons_description: management is grasping at straws to keep their paychecks high while sacraficing employees, freezing salaries, and demotivating their sales force

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Glaxo Smith Kline offers a Great Salary and Benefits package. They are looked at as a leader in the pharmaceutical market.
cons_description: Glaxo Smith Kline says that they are a transparent company. However, in the past that has not been the case, be carefull while working for this company.

summary: Great company to work for, but industry is going through change - how will GSK respond.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Been a long time employee and been a great company to work for. They are fair to their employees, good salary, benefits, and promotional opportunities.
cons_description: Recent downsizing of the industry and GSK will leave concerns for anyone entering the industry from a sales and marketing side.  It's not the industry it used to be, and that is not a bad thing.

summary: Use to be a good place to work,
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good pay, great benefit package, use to be family oriented and great place to work . Management use to be thoughtful and caring of their employees.
cons_description: Grew too fast and people were promoted into management positions that were not capable and deserving of those positions. Becoming the largest pharmaceutical company destroyed the family oriented caring for their employees philosophy as well as being dedicated to the employees that had been so dedicated during their career. If you got close to retirement ,that was the time they choose to lay you off.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Doing an internship at Glaxo Smith Kline was one o fhte best experinces I've had as an intern. I was working at the HR department and everyone was willing to teach and guide me through a career in the human requirement sector.
cons_description: There were four people working at the department for many years so I could not see a potential to move up on the ladder.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great Benefits other than salary
cons_description: Senior Management, Pipeline, Managed Care, Doc Access

summary: Industry is having issues with drugs going off  patent. Generics are better and better, very difficult to compete with .
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: You promote medice that can very positively impact peoples lives.
cons_description: It is a high stress position due to business climate. Job security is weak.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Excellent Learning Experience and generous benefits
cons_description: ambiguity and lack of transparency

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Once upon a time..... great products.  Sales people have great integrity.
cons_description: Used to be a company with a known vision.  Upper management/ top leaders are now most interested in themselves than the people that work for them.Continuously are using 'buzz' words like 'empowerment' and 'transparency'.  If you are living a trustworthy  and honest life, you do not have to continue to promote it.

summary: GSK not what it once was
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Excellent perks and benefits. For example, car, 3 weeks vacation, 401k, xmas week shut-down.
Sales reps are top notch.
Overall good training.
