cons_description:
Constant downsizing.
Manages through threats and intimidation.
Company is struggling in the US, so top management constantly makes changes and never gives changes enough time to work.

summary: GSK as a Bulldozer (for good and evil)
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
No ending new projects / products (incredible pipeline)
Very strong financial bases
Hiring rate (+10-20% a year)
Ability to focus all resources on 1 major project
cons_description:
Out of 1 big project, GSK is unable to manage smaller projects (no prioritization, yes culture)
highly adminitrative
systems led by Global more than field.
No ending reorganizations (departement : each 2 yrs / site each 4 yrs)

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Solid products - good reputation - used to be a very thoughtful company
cons_description: Avoid Wisconsin and Minnesota for access reasons

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good salary and benefits.  Intelligent friendly people at all levels of the organization in my area.  Many conveniences (such as a bank right on the premises with no fees if you open your account at that location).  Flex time and good management (at least in my area)
cons_description: A lot of people in temp. positions have trouble getting in permanently.

summary: GSK is awesome for pay and benefits, but poor for job security.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: excellent benefits and pay.  extremely flexible with time off and ability to work from home when needed.  pension plan and 401k are great.
cons_description: depending on work area, opportunities for advancement are limited.  there have been a lot of changes under the new ceo and no one seems to ever be in a really secure position for too long.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good place to work with commensurate salary. Professional development opportunities with self directed career path. Resource allocations in line with industry.
cons_description: Pharmaceutical industry, sales in parituclar, trending in a very negative direction due to external industry pressures. Industry continues to be a political scape goat for too many of the failures of healthcare.

summary: Great place to work laid back
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Wide exposure to many different intersting reaserch areas
cons_description: Alot of volatility specialy lately no job security

summary: Overall good big pharma company but tolerates bad DSM's.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Very professional company with good benefits and plenty of resources to support your success.  Access to information about your performance is generally good.  Pay seems appropriate for this industry.
cons_description: There is plenty of double-speak on part of management and they are often not sincere and upfront in their communication.  They have also tolerated many incompetent and overbearing sales managers for incomprehensible reasons.

summary: Good benefits/salary - low moral and counter productive culture
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Pretty good benefits and salary.
cons_description: They view people and their talents as commodities.  Upper management is more concerned with the bottom line than with quality.  They continue to attempt to outsource as much as possible with no regard to the quality of the IT product.  They are easily sold on flashy powerpoint presentations from outsourcing vendors and don't take into account the difficulties in implementation and the impact on the end users.

summary: It used to be a great company but this has changed. I wouldn't want to work for them ever again!
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Great employees to help you achieve success for the newbies and veterans
Health plan and extras are equivalent to other places
Uncapped commission 
Learn a lot about interviewing and you really become an expert in this process (I am never nervous on interview anymore)
If you have a great boss, they keep you updated on what is going on in the market and let you know you're progress
cons_description:
Quality of managers have gone down and aren't clear on their expectations of the team
Upper management are not really the expert in their fields anymore
Too much pressure in the vaccine division to bring the US part of the company out of the hole
Salary and compensation is much lower than other pharmaceutical companies and they require more work for less pay
Pressure on sending letters to Senators and different government officials on healthcare plans which I believe should not be in allowed in your job
Restructuring has lead to a lot of problems and a lot of animosity
If your boss is lazy, dishonest and discouraging, then your whole team will suffer and you will not make any money
They do not always value their employees and they are quick to get rid of you once your numbers are down.

summary: Overall, very good company to work at.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Good salaries
High professional environment
Great benefits and incentives
Good internal communications
Opportunity to growth
Open door policy among employees
Opportunity/ Optional of having access to medicines
cons_description:
Long and extended work hours
No very flexible for vacation time
Merge between GSK and SmithKline was still very evident between employees from both sides. 
New philosophy was still difficult to manage among employees from SK.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: work life balance, flexibility, casual environment
cons_description: slightly lower salary compared to other big pharma companies

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: great benefits, freedom to work your schedule, car, gas, product knowledge training.  The ability to get rotations is great too.  If your numbers are up, you get left alone
cons_description: huge downsizing in the industry right now.  GSK is laying off 50% of the work force in June.  Sales reps are doing more program scheduling and sample droping

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Comfortable place to work. Nice people
cons_description: very large company, can get lost.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Portfolio of pharmacotherapy, great budget, excellent sales training, paper sample recall
cons_description: Micromanagement, conservative CPP guidelines, need more data anyalysis of competitor's

summary: No Growth, too much politics, senior management not empowering
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great benefits, flexible work options, good time-off policy. Can find challenging opportunities if you excel at work.
cons_description:
Forget about career growth if you are sincere and hard-working but want to stay away from politics and back-stabbing games.
VPs and Directors from Old School of thought are still sticking to their bossy and arrogant culture while the CEO is trying to be more open, flexible and trying to create an empowering culture.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: GSK provides some of the best benefits of any job I know. Great exposure and cross-functional team working environment.  Great educational opportunities.
cons_description: Could use a little more transparency in the promotion process.  Very frequent reorganizations.  A lot of changes in the last few years as trying to remake business model to fit challenging times ahead.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Lot of great science happening at this company if you can get onto the right team.  There are a lot of opportunities.
cons_description: This is a very large company and works as a bureaucracy.  Salary ranges and bonuses are set and not very negotiable.

summary: Talented people to work with, but opportunities for career advancement are very slim.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Talented people, both leaders and colleagues. Empowerment culture is settling
cons_description: Very little opportunites for career advancement - huge bottleneck as you climb up the ladder. Besides, it's unclear what are the rules to advance, and talent management is pretty much a mistery.

summary: Good benefits, no opportunity for growth
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good benefits and work life balance
cons_description: You only get promoted if you are friends with the boss.  Most political environment I have ever seen.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Training regimen is second to none.  Once you have graduated from GSK 'bootcamp,' you have a common bond with your co-workers that will result in a common level of clinincal knowledge.  This translates into confidence in sharing clinical information with common customers.
cons_description: Local influences on sales performance in relation to competitive  regional co-workers who do not enjoy the exact same obstacles.  This circumstance results in unfair regional sales rankings.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Good work life balance
Standard pharmaceutical rep package - car, 401k plus matching, good medical 
Received 3 weeks vacation to start plus off between Christmas and New Years
cons_description:
It was very hard to get promoted out of the field
Had a very big good old boys club
Compensation could fluctuate greatly, depending on management structured the comp plan for the quarter

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Good benefits, particularly share option
Flexitime
cons_description: Overuse of redundancies to restructure business

summary: A very good place to work.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Opportunities for professional growth within a given department, great benefits package/pension plan,  in general corporate culture promotes a team-based environment.
cons_description: All of the Pros above exists in most departments but not all.  So sorry.  If you are interviewing for a position at this company ask clever questions to get an idea of the culture and management style of the department.  Changing of upper management can grossly affect the culture of a department.  The opportunities to move about internally will come around with the constant reorganization but only then.  Change is the only constant (which is necessary for survival in this industry) so you will have to learn to accept the change.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: The pay is good. As are the benefits. Plus in general the work is helpful to the world.
cons_description: They'll axe your whole department in a heart beat

summary: Great for some, horrible for others
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good health benefits and work at home option is nice.
cons_description: Where to start? I work in the Philadelphia office and in my division, the leadership is just flat out incompetent, and political to the point of lunacy. The people who do the work are kept down, and their accomplishments stolen by management and repackaged as their own. And promotions? Ha! If you haven't 'carried the bag' -- management speak for having spent time in the field detailing doctors -- they don't want anything to do with you as a manager, no matter how smart or insightful you are. The leader of US Pharma herself blogs on our internal blog that she is committed to sales and marketing as the future of the company. The problem is that, as a company continues to rely on current and former salespeople to run the company, it cultivates a culture of persuasion at all costs, and the importance of individual goals above company goals, even as it speaks about the importance of teamwork to employees overall. Also, the sales folks who they deem so precious don't have the analytical skills to really understand the business, and they are given free reign to run roughshod over the smart people who really DO know the business and should be put onto management tracks. The current and former sales folks are the only ones who have any job security and senior management protects them. The rules for civil treatment don't apply to them, and they are allowed to say anything, do anything, try anything, and treat anyone who isn't a former salesperson like crap and talk down to them constantly. These are the same folks who spend years in the field forging their call records, lying to the company about how they spend their time, and stab everyone in the back once they get in-building. And THIS is the future of our company? The lunatics are running the asylum and until that changes this company is doomed.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Big company & excellent products
cons_description: Bad management, especially in middle east region

summary: Laid back culture that demands performance
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: GSK has a laid back culture that demands results. The high performers are compensated well and the work life balance is excellent.
cons_description: There has been recent cutbacks and management expects higher results from less people. The culture has become stressful and some hot talent has left the company. I worry that we may not have the right people on the bus.

summary: A good job that somehow does not inspire much company loyalty
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Good compensation
Interesting problems
Many learning experiences
cons_description: Organizational strategy sometimes seems at odds with tactical concerns

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good benefit, stable company. second largest pharma
cons_description: Not growth opportunities, depends which group yopu belong to

summary: If you can work elsewhere, do it.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Despite terrible managment and career development, there are many quality people who work there. They provide the only sanity, day to day.
cons_description: Constant Change. Since 2006, my group has been through 3 major reorgs& over 50% reduction in staff. If we are good at anything, it is managing reorgs. If a drug is actually discoverd by GSK, its pure luck!

summary: A good company going through interesting times
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: As someone who was not a 'lifer' I found ample opportunities to 'make your mark', get rewarded and climb the career ladder.
cons_description:
The company was originally a SmithKline company that was merged into Glaxo.  When I was hired, several years after the merger, there were SK employees who felt that they had been blackballed.  I can't say that I actually witnessed anything of this nature with any employees.

GSK is currently going through surgical re-invention because of changing market conditions.  The site where I worked was shut down in 2009 as a consequence of this and other reasons.  It is not a safe haven if all you are looking at is size.  The CEO is against large operations.

summary: Used to be the best place to work
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Good pay and benefits.
Opportunity to travel business class.
Respected company in local area.
cons_description:
Incompetent VP's who somehow work for incompetent SVP's thus remaining employed for longer  than they should.
Demanding work with little opportuity for success.
Quieten or move beyond the bad news.
Deliver at all costs, cutting Quality if necessary.

summary: Stiefel today!  Is it Stiefel at all or GSK?
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: In the past, it was a small/medium sized global company were you knew everyone.  It was a great place to work - more like a family than a work place.  Plus, your job could be highly varied and your career path flexible.  I hope this will continue....but with the purchase by GSK, this may change.  i would like to be more specific, but everything is in the air at the moment and this looks to continue for a while longer.
cons_description: We are now a small business unit in the behemoth that is GSK (although a desirable company, no doubt - it can not offer an individual the autonomy & varied job descriptions we have enjoyed in the past).  The company will be moving to Stockley Park...not a popular move for a good part of the work force who live on the wrong side of Maidenhead & watch A4./A40 traffic reports with some trepidation!  GSK seemto be making light of the impact of this.

summary: Training and career prospect in the organisation
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good organisation with good training. career prospect is quite good with postings overseas if you are one of the good staff.
cons_description: not so competitive salary in the country, management tend to benchmark salary with other big pharma companies but the smaller companies are paying better

summary: Great for Work/Life balance.  But stay on your toes.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Glaxo is still setup as one of the places you get a job and stay for life.  There are a lot of benefits to this - great work / life balance, great benifits, a pension plan, lower stress.
cons_description: The industry itself is facing issues and GSK has had a number of layoffs.  This was VERY stressful on people who had been at GSK for 10-25 years, just showed up, got great pay but didn't invest in themselves.  GSK is happy to let employees be average for years and years and pay them very well, but on the open market this means these employees are not desired.  And they know it.  So the con with GSK is you can be lulled slowly into a listless career..

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: GlaxoSmithKline is a well-established company which enjoys good reputation worldwide. GSK also offers some very good training opportunities, in areas like OE.
cons_description: Some of the downsides are that the work structure can be very bureaucratic. They are too many layers in the reporting hierarchy.

summary: Great benefits! BUT they over promise and under-deliver.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: GSK pays a very good salary; it's hard to beat.  It's a European company with similar European benefits for the NA team.
cons_description: Both the company structure  and senior management inhibit business and professional growth.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Talented colleagues, solid benefits and pay.
cons_description: Heavily siloed IT organizations.  Lack of R&D productivity over last decade has created cost pressures.  IT talent located all over the globe but organization must mature to become more productive.

summary: Great place to work depending on your position within the company
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Benefits and pay are outstanding; great co-workers and opportunities for personal development.
cons_description: My Director gives lip service to the empowerment initiative.  She continues to micromanage everyone in our area and has been doing so for 12 years.  Andrew, she does not watch your broadcasts, or go to our SVP town halls.  With the simplifcation taking place in IT, employees are at the mercy of those making decisions.  In my case, I was moved to a new building, new boss, new group only to find out that I will be 'scored' on my performance for this year only.  I have been with the company in various departments for almost 19 years and my score will NOT include my performance for the first 18 years.

summary: Respect for the orange pork chop
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Excellent benefits including vehicle, retirement, medical, along with competitive salary and above average bonus structure. 

Good position moving forward in the industry to stay towards the top with viable pipeline.
cons_description:
Transitionary phase has been challenging during the last year as instability due to significant movement in top level management has created a trickle-down effect to all levels of the company.

Do not view R&D as overhead and continue slashing this department, outside acquisitions will only get you so far.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
good pay and also good benifits.
some potential for growth 
pension and 401 k are also a good benifit to have
cons_description:
Promotions are based on level of educations, not level of knowledge or experience.
communication feom management could be better, they are very reluctant to tell anything, even when asked in person they like to dance around the questions.  I guess thats everywhere though

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Some great people
Resources ++++
Minimal micromanagement
cons_description:
Not evreyone is working for the same company
Some 'old boy' and 'cronies' circles (esp ex-SB)
Philadelphia offices are c*^p

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: The benefits are top of the line.  The people are friendly.  It is a good company, #2 Healthcare.
cons_description: Due to downsizing. . . .a lot of work has been placed on individuals.  Should be brought to management attentioni that the more work you place on people, the more shortcuts are going to be taken, errors are going to made and accidents will happen.

summary: Employees need to be treated with more respect
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Excellent pay. 
Benefits are outstanding (especially prescription drug coverage). 
Onsite cafeterias (with decent food). 
Several Fitness centers onsite.  
Twenty four hour security. 
Cutting technology in the labs. 
Safety is priority one.
cons_description:
Politics. It seems that folks who do the bulk of the work are never promoted, while the folks who simply compile data into charts move up the ladder.
There is a feeling of lack of trust and respect. 
If a few hours is spent away from work for personal errands/doctor appointments, every minute is expected to be made up. That is fine. However if extra time is spent or if there is unscheduled weekend work (in order to meet deadlines, etc.) there is NO comp time. If you work extra hours, you're working for free.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Flexibility, products are market leaders, great benefits, good training, large expense account, good tools for my customers, positive working environment
cons_description: some territories are very large, shrinking bonuses, limited room for advancement, some territory managers can be brutal, lots of shifting around

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: This company is exceptional when it comes to work-life balance.  The hours and benefits exceed industry standards and are truly the best part of working for GSK.
cons_description: This company is in the middle of a major transition.  Those who survived the restructuring are being left with less resources and more to do.  Their pipeline is marginal and it is left to be seen whether the 'new' strategy will pay off.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Good pay and good benefits.
Some departments better at allowing role expansion.
Some technologies managed well (upgrades, patches, versioning, etc).
cons_description:
Some areas have micro managers, not enough people who understand the big picture.
Senior management spending sprees for business trips and meals.
Promotions don't always go to the person with the highest talent and skill level.

summary: Company in flux. Good pros, consider the cons.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good Pay. Good Benefits. Some really excellent groups to work in on the technical side. Smart people in most cases. Some excellent technical management. Excellent training resources. Modern thinking generally.
cons_description:
You roll the dice on getting competent management. Once someone makes Director level it's like tenure. You see many people who used to be competent and work hard get complacent once they hit Director level - it's like retirement with a job.

Company values process over leadership.  Challenging the status-quo is frowned upon. If you're not a subject of the crown or willing to move to London, you can forget that promotion. A less qualified Londoner will get it first. High-achievers, entrepreneurs are leaving for greener pastures, and average, non-challenging people are staying.

Pulling more chips out of US and redistributing toward the Far East. (This is a 'Pro' if you're in the Far East obviously)

summary: Not for Skilled Employees, Management does not have a clue on what they expect?
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Flexible working environment
Adaption of new technology
cons_description:
'Not my problem' attitude among the superviors.
Too much travel for pleasure by senior management
Always look out for less cost effective process.

summary: Excellent culture, benefits, work-life balance, impact on society
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: impact on the society and patients, benefits, work-life balance, pension, bonus, culture
cons_description: limited opportunities for growth in IT, large company with bureaucracy, hard to get promotions

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Good product line
Competent management
Lots of chances to move up into other roles withing the company
Live-work balance is good
cons_description:
Micromanagement
Majoring in the minor
Only focusing on a specif model as opposed to doing what will drive sales long term

summary: GSK is a great place to work
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: The company researches, develops and delivers medicines to patients around the world.  Great benefits and one of the few big pharma companies that seems to be in the right direction while the industry faces major change.
cons_description: As is the case with any large corporation, it can be easy to get lost.  Company is undergoing significant change.

summary: GSK can be a good place to work.  Restructuring makes it feel unstable for workforce.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great people to work with, great pay and benefits.  The work is always challenging and interesting.  Opportunities for development have been generous in the past.
cons_description: Constant restructuring leaves employees with sense of fear.  Middle management is not clear in communicating their strategies.  Long hours and some departments are not willing to allow flexible work options.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good flex-work.  Allowed work from home for some days of the week.  Friendly coworkers as well as management.  Typically had optimistic attitudes.
cons_description:
Getting someone else to do their part of supporting an app or change to app or OS is near impossible at times.
Seemed to be a lot of unknown information...or where to go to get that information.  Always pointed to one place...and that one place would usually be ambiguous.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Plenty of opportunities given. Its a matter of just voicing out and saying that you are interested.
cons_description: Pay structure and remuneration scheme at the site level could be more transparent

summary: Good place to work, just don't get stuck.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
- Good pay and benefits, even compared to the rest of the industry.
- Worthwhile mission of developing useful products which prolong and enhance life.
cons_description:
- Highly instable as of 2008.
- Senior management touts common sense approach to business and then makes decisions that lack foresight and seem to defy any sense.
-Company is too politics driven, and deserving people are often passed over for promotions or lateral assignments.
- Over-outsourcing destroys employee morale and leads to lower quality service.

summary: Great global company. High % of contract 'contingent workers' per employee.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great international Fortune 500 company. Better than average share of fair and well-meaning management.  A top-tier pharmaceutical and consumer brand endeavor that is lean on funding, but not stingy.
cons_description: If it stands still, it gets outsourced.  So prevalent is the outsourcing that large meetings between business and IT can be made with real business-impacting decisions committed and only afterward that one notices that no actual employees were involved.  Teleconferences involving four or five counties, time zones and accents are so common that you cease to realize that you are picking-up slang from the other side of the planet.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Ethical company, thorough training with great product to represent. Having a great manager and team to work with makes a great difference!
cons_description: Only real negatives were the things you cannot control. Lack of access to doctors made doing your job difficult.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: great pay; if you work hard you'll be rewarded; high caliber of professionals on team; excellent ongoing training; excellent vacation and time off; can have work/life balance
cons_description: I was laid off and despite that would rave about the company.  I picked my poison so could expect that being the least tenured person on the team.  I had a wonderful experience during my time there.  I won a trip, made great money, felt proud of what I was doing.  Yes, the cons...NO STABILITY.  I agree.  The morale is very low right now.  Anyone who wants to get into pharma should wait.  Get sales experience elsewhere copier, telecommunications, insurance, whatever...and come back when things look up.  So cons, lack of stability, low morale, lack of motivation, no clear direction for professional development and growth, and most importantly, no sense of career advancement at all.

summary: It's what you make of it
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
it is a Convienient location close to major highways
i have nice co-workers
Credit union isexcellent
you get discounts on consumer products
cons_description:
Complete lack of recognition of work or dedication from employees
Still parts of 'good old boy' network left at top
can be long hours depending on project

summary: GSK...great if you like politics with beancounters in charge of research.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good scientific 'Community' with great support from peers. Ability to make a difference in peoples lives by developing new medicines.
cons_description: Promotions are few and far between...alot of politics involved. Company is WAY too large with layer upon layer of bureacracy.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Excellent benefits, culture and tools to excel.
cons_description: large and cumbersome, takes an act of congress and too many developmental programs to advance.  When funds got tight, company took to increasing size of compliance dept to trim salesforce.  Denied impending layoffs.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Pharma-sales is easy once you are established. Good health benefits, work hours and company car. Sales jobs with reasonable base salaries are always good. Very good compensation packages for reps recently layed off. GSK is not a pressure sales environment.
cons_description: Doctors don't  want to see reps. (This is an industry problem and not specific to GSK.) Often felt more like a caterer than a sales person. You can go an entire day and not see a Doctor legit.   GSK has gone through massive layoffs. Moral is low. Can't get promoted. No room for advancement. Industry is dying. Sales numbers were guess work. Bonus potential seemed capped. Wages were going down. Sales portfolio often depends on other sales reps which can be unfair.

summary: GlaxoSmithKline is a highly rewarding company where you are recognized for the value you bring to this company.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: -Direct line managers here at GSK are very committed to the growth and development of their employees as well as maintaining a dedicated path to success. Additionally, the current bonus structure is formulated based on your area's performance, as opposed to considering your own accomplishments, but that is changing starting next year. Overall, GSK offers tremendous benefits, is willing to ensure you excel at your abilities, and looks forward to your growth. Here you are not just an employee, but rather an investment in the company, and if you can prove your worth, you will be rewarded.
cons_description: While there are plenty of opportunities if your area of the business is doing well, there is also a downside for under-performing groups. When certain areas of the business are forced to shut down, many jobs are effected, and it can be increasingly difficult to relocate to another area. Additionally, it is more difficult then one would expect to move laterally between business groups.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great benefits, great hours, flexible schedule, vacations whenever you want to take them and lots of paid holidays. Expense account...
cons_description: Lack of competency in upper management, declining industry, lack of respect from doctors, urealistic sales goals and metrics expectations, no consistency or stability in upper management's expectations, lack of communication by upper management, terrible company morale

summary: Bad time to get into pharma
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: GSK is a well-respected, forward thinking, global leader in the healthcare industry. Salaries are fair, and as a sales rep, I can say that I am not micro-managed. This is a good company to work for, but I would not recommend joining us on the pharma side -- try vaccines, HIV, consumer health, etc.
cons_description: Because of the economic situation nationally, this is a bad time to get into pharma sales. I've had multiple managers in a very short time frame, experienced two recent lay-offs, and am certain another is looming. Bonus is almost impossible to make at this point, as well.

summary: Key talent gets lost in shuffle of large company politics.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
It was very nice to work for a company with such a good reputation;  the climate in pharma can change so quickly that although I was lured in with promises of advancement and additional opportunities my employment contract was not extended regardless of excellent reviews by my co-workers and supervisors. 

The science performed is top-notch and well-executed.
cons_description: It is a big company and the red tape can slow down progress. Research projects can get lost in the shuffle and peoples' hard work can go unrecognized or even unnoticed by senior management.

summary: One of the best companies in Pakistan in terms of learning, development and growth, but with exceedingly low salaries.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great opportunities for learning in a multinational environment.  Good culture, conducive to working harder and smarter.  Career development and chances for promotion more likely than at other similar sized multinationals in Pakistan.
cons_description: Compensation is well below industry averages, almost to the point of being unjust.  High turnover means low retention of good human capital and future leaders.  Pharmaceutical marketing practices sometimes questionable.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: dynamic, business driven, young, practical, adjust fast to the big environment. In 2008 it was the first big pharm company that dares to cut majority of discovery functions and adjust the structure orgnization to big extent. Good company overall. Good health benefit. Good dental benefit.
cons_description: Extremely low pay especially for those hired many years ago, do not encourage publishing paper, do not retain the best scientists. Need to have competative pay, do comaparable market analysis and equity research, so those at who have stayed at the same positions will get the same pay/ or even higher pay than those new hires.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
Multinational company operating in an interesting field - real life impact.
The sheer size of the company allows (if you are lucky) a good level of international exchanges.
cons_description:
Some parts of the company are not really working together. Opportunities are not the same in all sites.
Considering the multinational dimension of the company, this is a big downside: perceived inequalities, especially if fostered by a less-than-adequate local plant management, can result in excessive employees turnover and low motivation.
The pharma industry is still quite 'shielded' from competition: this is both a plus and a minus, since inefficiencies are allowed to survive.

summary: Excellent company who care about their employees
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: GSK is very family oriented and strives for a proper work-life balance for everyone.  The benefits & salary are very competitive in the pharma industry.  RTP & the Philadelphia are are two great places to work.  Mass transit available for workers in center city Philly.  On-site fitness centers and convenient parking too.  Big potential with new CEO Witty.
cons_description: Minimal amount of cross training.  Employees tend to work in same area for years without chance for mobility.  Only select few are given opportunity to job rotations and ultimate advancement.  Current environment of downsizing has all employees on edge waiting for the ax to fall in their department.

summary: Great place to work and grow for a long period IF you are lucky enough to find the right management
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Competitive pay, long term incentives and benefits once in the management band, work-life balance
cons_description: beauracracy, HR, beauracracy, HR, and HR

summary: Transparency and empowerment are just words in the dictionary
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
The beneifts at GSK are a great incentive.  I have yet to see a comparable benefits package from anyone in a pharmaceutical organization.  The employee health management is incredible.  There are many benefits available to GSK employees that assist in the work and personal life balance. 

 In most organizations, the dust has settled with re-organizations due to the current economic climate.  For the organizations that have been addressed, employees understand their job objectives and the opportunity for advancement is within reach for the employees putting out the extra effort.   

GSK also has incredible communication from Senior management to worker bee.  Communications are constantly being distributed to employees regarding pipeline drugs and opportunities in the community.
cons_description:
Currently, there is a lot of bureaucracy at GSK.  I would say this is specific to IT, but I hear this is an issue throughout all organizations.  Our former CEO expressed how much he disliked all the barriers employees have to complete their tasks.   A lot of legwork was performed to remedy this, and I feel the changing of Sr. Management has caused employees to feel less empowered.  The bureaucracy still exists and in 11 years now, it has never been more visible.   

Another downside would be the constant outsourcing efforts.  Granted, there is a obligation to stockholders to maximize their investments.   The effect that outsourcing has on employee performance and morale is off the chart.   The environment used to be a family environment.  It feels like a very selfish environment now.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Excellent benefits, competitive salaries, and name recognition.  They probably had the best benefits package of any employer I've worked for to date.  Vacation time was good, and the year end shut down around the holidays was great.  It's the second largest company in the industry, and I was proud to say that I worked for this company.  If you are willing to relocate, the career opportunities are endless.
cons_description: Poor communication from upper management downward.  At my particular site, there was the constant threat of the facility closing.  It was an older facility and not quite up to date in many ways as some of the other manufacturing sites.

summary: Work for a good manager and life will be great at GSK
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: high salary, generous benefits, many days of vacation, generous severance package
cons_description: in some management situations you can't take advantage of work/life balance benefits, lack of leadership in mid-level management, the constant fear of job cuts as this industry continues to downsize

summary: A insider's view of GlaxoSmithKline from one who has worked in several departments
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: In the IT sector, the benefits and pay at GSK are above the industry for people coming out of college and contractors.  They advocate a work-life balance and encourage people to look after their health in addition to your performance.  The people who work there are quite experienced and look out for one another.
cons_description:
GSK is a huge company with many departments so the bureaucracy can neutralize new ideas.  

Each department has its own unique culture depending on the management so I've seen people who feel completely open and able to bring themselves to work while other departments, it can be quite stifling.  

Pay and bonus is kept very secretive despite the move towards transparency.    At times, it feels like the bonus and pay is more based on how long you've been at GSK and less based on business performance.  

Recruitment tends to favor applicants with a pharmaceutical background.  Unfortunately, that leads to the same type of thinking and ideas.   New ideas are rarely introduced because if they fail, the bonus will also be affected.

The company is very risk adverse (rightfully so in certain areas because of regulatory reasons) but it spills over into areas that need not necessarily so.

summary: GSK will weather the current storm well
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Innovation, career opportinities within the company, sense of purpose, pride in products, working with very smart and passionate people, compensation and benefit package is hard to beat.
cons_description: Current economic climate and change in leadership resulting in many reoganizations, job insecurity.  The comapany is so large that there are many bureaucratic processes and effective communication is difficult.  Culture does not reward honesty and open communication. Maintaining 2 US headquarters and dual leadership in many areas did not allow the creation of a single corporate culture in the US.

summary: GSK - great job with little security
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: I still feel that GSK offers the best products in their respected classes, and that makes it easy to sell a product and be proud and able to sleep at night. I never feel like I am persuading a doctor to do something that is not the best possible treatment.  Aside from products, the health benefits are great, and you start with 3 weeks vacation plus year end shut down.
cons_description: I never feel like my job is safe. Layoffs two years in a row, and there was very little correlation to success and to those who were let go.

summary: Great place to work if you want a big pharma company.
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great pipeline of products and versatile portfolio of products.  If you want to move into a specialty sales force position, now is the time.  The company is in transition but is trying to be more specialized.  They are always looking for talented, hard working sales reps with proven sales success.
cons_description: Very big pharma.  Not a lot of room to manage your territory as you see fit.  Very little say into speakers or speaking opportunities.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: GSK has excellent training for new employees, training is intense and you must be prepared to leave home for minimum 3 weeks. GSK has good products, benefits, budgets, marketing materials, company cars, cell phone, credit card, computer, printer, expense account for supplies for your office and other materials.
cons_description: Manage Care is having a big impact  in Michigan and some other states. Physician's may like your products/drugs but if the insurance company will not pay for it, he can't use it with his patients and you will lose market share. Many of GSK best products have generic competition or in the case of Avandia (for diabetes), received some bad media coverage which cost the company billions of dollars. In the last 2 years the company has cut jobs 2 times. Rumors are out already they may have another round of cuts, year end 2009. It's not just GSK making cuts, it's the industry as a whole.

summary: Typical Large Pharma and large corporations, expect to feel insignificant.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Good benefits, employees are treated with respect
cons_description: Poor work/life balance, wages are ok, communication from upper management tend to be slow and unclear in terms of directions and objectives. Politics.

summary: it is a different company now with the restructuring
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: it's a large and respected company
cons_description: smithkline is running the company

summary: Good starter job, improvement needed with career advancement opportunities
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
GSK has a good reputation among the healthcare community. Their products are often best-in-class in many therapeutic areas. Personally, I did quite well working as a executive sales rep. finishing in the top 1% for performance three consecutive years in the Phoenix area.

The compensation and expectations were fair.
cons_description:
The company did nothing to retain my services when a personal crisis forced me to move back East. This experience really soured my image of the company and left me to believe that they do not value the needs of their employees despite what I had done for the company. 

Also, the company needs to improve the process for applying for career advancement opportunities.

summary: Good starter job, improvement needed with career advancement opportunities
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
GSK has a good reputation among the healthcare community. Their products are often best-in-class in many therapeutic areas. Personally, I did quite well working as a executive sales rep. finishing in the top 1% for performance three consecutive years in the Phoenix area.

The compensation and expectations were fair.
cons_description:
The company did nothing to retain my services when a personal crisis forced me to move back East. This experience really soured my image of the company and left me to believe that they do not value the needs of their employees despite what I had done for the company. 

Also, the company needs to improve the process for applying for career advancement opportunities.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Flexibility - as with any pharma job you basically make your own schedule (although the official hours are 8:30 - 5); decent car selection - Mercury Mariner is a nice little SUV; offer job share opportunities (but they are impossible to get)
cons_description: They don't have any loyalty to their employees; no clue what layoffs are based on; 2 day manager ride alongs can be painful.  Unrealistic goals.  Entire nation doesn't reach goals they set and they MAY lower it so some can actually get paid.  GSK's training is really hard and stressful compared to other pharma companies; very passable but lots of memorization and repeating back word for word.

summary: GSK is a good place to work, but there is always room for improvement
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: The company offers an excellent benefits package and work life balance, good opportunities for training.  The company spends a lot of time and effort on maximizing the health and wellbeing of its employees.  We have reimbursement for healthcare expenses and compensation for completing an annual health risk assessment questionnaire.  We frequently are offered training sessions on healthcare topics.  We have a generous amount of time off, and the retirment savings plan and medical, dental and vision care can't be beat.
cons_description: our site keeps losing employees but rarely replaces them, which puts a heavy burden on the employees at the company.

summary: Family-oriented, but not a satisfying place for a career
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: GSK has a great work-life balance. They have a shorter work week than most--never more than 40 hours. The facilities are great and they are very flexible with time off. RTP is now the US HQ so there is great opportunity to move up without having to relocate.
cons_description: Communication in IT is poor. There is very little sharing of information or goals across divisions. The company seems to be in contious lay-off mode which is destructive to employee morale. GW was a good co, but SmithKline has added a level of bureacracy that gets in the way of delivering to the business. The overall 'I'd rather not' attitude toward delivery and taking on tough projects is difficult for anyone interested in being productive.

summary: Pretty good company to work for overall.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Excellent Benefits.  Well repected industry leader.
cons_description: Salary could have been more competitive.

summary: Overall positive, but a few trap doors to watch out for.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Very dedicated, results-oriented organisation which is working to help improve people's lives.  Many people stay with the company for a long time, even their whole careers.  Very systematic and thorough performance review and development process; good support for advancement and development.  Some international opportunities for certain roles.  Compensation is competitive with other similar roles in Pharma or Consumer Healthcare companies.
cons_description: Senior management sometimes behaves like an 'old-lads club', and the personality cult can overshadow the straightforward focus on results at times.  For this reason it can be a frustrating place to work for people who just want to do their job well.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Great management, friendly folks and awesome atmosphere
cons_description: The industry is facing uncertain times in general. A lot of the jobs now are for contractor positions (like mine) and they don't seem to want to hire for full-time, permanent

summary: Used to be a good place to work
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Interesting work, smart, interesting people to work with.  A chance to contribute to new medicines and improve healthcare.  Good pay and benefits.  The company is socially responsible both in terms of charity, and in terms of contributing to improved healthcare in the developing world.
cons_description: A rolling reorganization has been running for 3 years now.  Recent business setbacks have increased pressure on budgets even further.  Some groups are in their 3rd or 4th round.  Poor morale in those who are left following the preceeding series of cuts.  No obvious plan for improving research output, but plenty of plans for cutting costs.  R&D appears to be run by MBA's at this point.  Currently GSK has the stability and security of a small company with the bureaucracy of a large company.  Job advancement is limited by the fact that the company is contracting, but losing employees faster than managers.

summary: GSK - Sal and benefits plus, bureaucracy a minus
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: Benefits are good, overall mission of the business is a positive one
cons_description: very bureaucratic and complicated decision making/approval processes.

summary: Friendly people, need to work to earn authority.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: I really felt that I was working for a company that was doing something to help other people to live a better life.  Even though I worked in consumer goods and not in pharmaceuticals, the products we offered helped people.  Also the peope eat GSKCH were great to work with and are probably what I miss most.  The benefits are also wonderful which I did not realize fully until I moved on to a new company.
cons_description: The atmospher can be quite hierarchical which makes it difficult for people lower on the totem pole to be more involved and develop their careers.  Also, some managers have a hard time accepting when people are promoted to very different roles within the organization and accepting their new position.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: GSK is a solid company with an outstanding reputation.  I think that the products are well-received by the physicians and staff.  I think you can lead a balanced life while working here.  Compensation seems to be competitive. The company recently adjusted salaries because they hired a consulting group to evaluate how competitive the pay is.  Co-workers are professional and are the type of people you would want as friends.  The people in my division work together as a team and we try to help each other by passing along information that has helped us in the field.  I have had to spend very little time at night or on the weekend doing administrative work.
cons_description: I can't think of any downsides to working for GSK.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: World's 2nd largest Pharmaceutical company.  The company is involved in meeting unmet medical needs. It also has been consistently rated as a responsible corporate citizen. GSK R&D work environment is very good with good work-life balance.
cons_description: Large organization. The Pharmaceutical industry in general is going through significant changes as drugs are coming off-patent and companies trying to replace them.  Therefore, lots of changes taking without waiting for changes implemented to deliver. GSK is not one of the best pay master relative to its peers.

summary: Good company that is going through a tough market in pharmaceuticals
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: The company has a good pay and benefits package with above average vacation and holidays.  The position I am at allows a lot of learning opportunities.  Currently, there are attempts to streamline the office setting (ie. meetings) and production oriented.
cons_description: The company is large and getting anything completed quickly is very tedious.  Each employee is expected to complete multiple tasks (2-3 jobs on average).  I guess this is the trend in the industry today.  Some of the senior management at the site could improve on their leadership skills and focus on supporting their employees more.  Some focus is lost on producing product efficiently due to all of the politics.

main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: GSK offers a competitive working environment that allows for many training opportunities.  The company continues to find resources to allow employees to further enhance their skill set.  GSK offers competitive pay and benefits.  This is a good place to get some solid training to develop your career in pharmaceuticals for the long term.
cons_description: Over the last few years the company has become more process oriented which stifles creativity and reduces an employees desire to take risks.  The company has become more top down in their strategies to grow sales and could care less if their sales reps actually believe in the strategy.  Should a sales rep dare state that a particular strategy or tactic is not effective they are labeled as negative and not willing to be a team player.  Sales reps are also encouraged to provide positive feedback regarding these ineffective tactics which causes an 'emporor has no clothes' situation.  The process oriented environment when married with inability to speak up also causes a box checking attitude among employees.  Employees spend more time worrying about checking the box versus actually improving results.  The company has also moved from one which rewards people for positive outcomes to one that threatens.  Threats are only usesful in the short term and that period faded out in 2007.  People are tired of the threats and are no longer scared but instead are demotivated.

summary: Beware of GSK as an employer right now
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: They provide great benefits.  There are many different areas of the company to work in and move too if you aren't satisfied with your current position.  It was a great place to learn different areas of the pharmaceutical business from marketing, product development to manufacturing.  The former Glaxo facilities were nice places to work while the former Burroughs buildings were very old.
cons_description: The company is going through major restructuring (ie downsizing).  They tend to promote people who are good at doing the work to be the manager of the department.  Those individuals tend to be inadequate managers.  They used to have a technical track to allow individual contributers to be promoted and move ahead, however, it was dissolved.

main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: decent pay and good benefits.
cons_description:
Over the years, I found the company to be less transparent with their directions in regards to marketing the products and long term plans with marketing and sales of the brands.  With the many FDA related issues pertaining to our products in the last several years, I found the company to be less open with the reasonings behind their decisons and strategies.  
Being an ethical pharmaceutical giant, head office has many policies on sales activites which regulates the sales staff in conducting business within the ethical pharma guidelines.  However, these policies were not being followed by the staff mainly because pressures from the competition within and outside the company.  The spirit of the ethical code is lost with the company.

summary: Glaxo world class but low class for its employees
main_text_description: I have been working at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: There is great value in accurately representing the benefits and limitations of pharmaceutical products.  Physicians and patients need solutions to treat ailments and we meet that need.  The benefits of a free car, free insurance, free gas,and good benefits is invaluable.  The freedom from daily scrutiny  by management is very  valuable.
cons_description: Glaxo uses its sales force as puppets. They have a tendency to stick their heads in the sand and repeat the same mistakes over and over again.  The management is driving their best talent out the door. The company takes for granted the work that is required to be successful and does not fairly compensate for overtime.  There is an overwhelming amount of stress associated with this company.

summary: Good site for the company...while it was open.
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description:
The senior management at the Northborough site was very intelligent and more than willing to share information with employees.

The human resources department and senior management provided a good work/life balance.  For example, flex time was offered, and an employee assistance program was provided.  There were also a number of company sponsored events (e.g. a softball team, family outings) that were good for morale.
cons_description: Compensation was generally below the level of other companies in the area.  In a biotech hotbed like Massachusetts, it was difficult to retain employees when salaries were for the most part not competitive.

summary: Great culture among scientists. Current environment is shaky
main_text_description: I worked at GlaxoSmithKline
pros_description: There are very good scientists there and good culture among the scientists.
cons_description: The current environment and the environment in Pharma in general is poor at the moment.  There is very little confidence about job security.
